<textM no="1696-1708" no="1709-1721" no="1722-1734" no="1735-1747" no="1748-1760" no="1761-1773" no="1774-1786" no="1787-1799" no="1800-1812" no="1813-1825" no="1826-1838" no="1839-1851" no="1852-1864" no="1865-1877" no="1878-1890" no="1891-1903" no="1904-1916" no="1917-1929" no="1930-1942" no="1943-1955" no="1956-1968" no="1969-1981" no="1982-1994" no="1995-2007" no="2008-2020">
<textC no="1698-1718" no="1719-1739" no="1740-1760" no="1761-1781" no="1782-1802" no="1803-1823" no="1824-1844" no="1845-1865" no="1866-1886" no="1887-1907" no="1908-1928" no="1929-1949" no="1950-1970" no="1971-1991" no="1992-2012" no="2013-2033">
According to the Amsterdam correspondent cf the Times, three Dutchmen have petitioned Queen Wilhelmina for a royal charter in connection with a company for the colonisation, exploration, and exploitation of Dutch New Guinea, with the right to levy import and export duties, excise and taxes, subject to a royalty of 10 per cent, to the Dutch Government, and the right of mining, subject also to a Government royalty of 10 per cent.
</text>

<text id="193eq329798117">
<textF no="1703-1709" no="1710-1716" no="1717-1723" no="1724-1730" no="1731-1737" no="1738-1744" no="1745-1751" no="1752-1758" no="1759-1765" no="1766-1772" no="1773-1779" no="1780-1786" no="1787-1793" no="1794-1800" no="1801-1807" no="1808-1814" no="1815-1821" no="1822-1828" no="1829-1835" no="1836-1842" no="1843-1849" no="1850-1856" no="1857-1863" no="1864-1870" no="1871-1877" no="1878-1884" no="1885-1891" no="1892-1898" no="1899-1905" no="1906-1912" no="1913-1919" no="1920-1926" no="1927-1933" no="1934-1940" no="1941-1947" no="1948-1954" no="1955-1961" no="1962-1968" no="1969-1975" no="1976-1982" no="1983-1989" no="1990-1996" no="1997-2003" no="2004-2010" no="2011-2017">

<textC no="1710-1730" no="1731-1751" no="1752-1772" no="1773-1793" no="1794-1814" no="1815-1835" no="1836-1856" no="1857-1877" no="1878-1898" no="1899-1919" no="1920-1940" no="1941-1961" no="1962-1982" no="1983-2003" no="2004-2024">
The Fox and Hares are hunted but no so much as with us; so that the Hares frequently fall to the Share of the Peasants who by a Gun or Snares kill them and sell privately to whoever buy them
</text>

<text id="275ct11010410132">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">

The principle is therefore the same. But then this virtuous answer was given to Bonaparte, and Switzerland is a poor country unable to help itself. And the persons attempting to tyrannize over its remaining freedom are Legitimate Sovereigns, to whom every thing is lawful.
</text>

<text id="263ip329711132">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">

Court being prepared for proceeding on the Cause of the Petticoat, I gave Orders to bring in a Criminal who was taken up as she went out of the Puppet-Show about Three Nights ago,and was now standing in the Street with a great Concurse of People about her.
</text>

<text id="123oi11010732100">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">

</text>

<textC no="1706-1726" no="1727-1747" no="1748-1768" no="1769-1789" no="1790-1810" no="1811-1831" no="1832-1852" no="1853-1873" no="1874-1894" no="1895-1915" no="1916-1936" no="1937-1957" no="1958-1978" no="1979-1999" no="2000-2020">
It is the Prescription of a Gentleman of good circumstances, who has made the Study of Physick. It is put in Tin-Boxes seal'd up and will keep several Years so that People may take it to Sea or into Foreign Countries.
</text>

<text id="444ba3210097116">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1707-1719" no="1720-1732" no="1733-1745" no="1746-1758" no="1759-1771" no="1772-1784" no="1785-1797" no="1798-1810" no="1811-1823" no="1824-1836" no="1837-1849" no="1850-1862" no="1863-1875" no="1876-1888" no="1889-1901" no="1902-1914" no="1915-1927" no="1928-1940" no="1941-1953" no="1954-1966" no="1967-1979" no="1980-1992" no="1993-2005" no="2006-2018">
<textC no="1702-1722" no="1723-1743" no="1744-1764" no="1765-1785" no="1786-1806" no="1807-1827" no="1828-1848" no="1849-1869" no="1870-1890" no="1891-1911" no="1912-1932" no="1933-1953" no="1954-1974" no="1975-1995" no="1996-2016">
GRAND CABINET and SQUARE PIANO- •FORTESS—T. BUTCHER, 41, Great Titchfield-street, begs to offer to the Public his Grand Cabinet, and Square Piano-fortes, both plain and elegant, made on the most improved principles, and at prices which cannot fail to: T. B, submits his instruments for inspection and offers them on trial, if disapproved of may be exchanged or returned,by paying the usual hire.:—Old instruments, taken in exchange.
</text>

<text id="514ge1023210532">
<textF no="1704-1710" no="1711-1717" no="1718-1724" no="1725-1731" no="1732-1738" no="1739-1745" no="1746-1752" no="1753-1759" no="1760-1766" no="1767-1773" no="1774-1780" no="1781-1787" no="1788-1794" no="1795-1801" no="1802-1808" no="1809-1815" no="1816-1822" no="1823-1829" no="1830-1836" no="1837-1843" no="1844-1850" no="1851-1857" no="1858-1864" no="1865-1871" no="1872-1878" no="1879-1885" no="1886-1892" no="1893-1899" no="1900-1906" no="1907-1913" no="1914-1920" no="1921-1927" no="1928-1934" no="1935-1941" no="1942-1948" no="1949-1955" no="1956-1962" no="1963-1969" no="1970-1976" no="1977-1983" no="1984-1990" no="1991-1997" no="1998-2004" no="2005-2011" no="2012-2018">
<textM no="1704-1716" no="1717-1729" no="1730-1742" no="1743-1755" no="1756-1768" no="1769-1781" no="1782-1794" no="1795-1807" no="1808-1820" no="1821-1833" no="1834-1846" no="1847-1859" no="1860-1872" no="1873-1885" no="1886-1898" no="1899-1911" no="1912-1924" no="1925-1937" no="1938-1950" no="1951-1963" no="1964-1976" no="1977-1989" no="1990-2002" no="2003-2015">
<textC no="1704-1724" no="1725-1745" no="1746-1766" no="1767-1787" no="1788-1808" no="1809-1829" no="1830-1850" no="1851-1871" no="1872-1892" no="1893-1913" no="1914-1934" no="1935-1955" no="1956-1976" no="1977-1997" no="1998-2018">
Well, if it is not war, what is it ? The Post says- " Strictly speaking, the force used mm time coast of Syria is not a war' at all. There has been no declaration of war. There is no strife of nation against nation, but merely assistance given to a Sovereign in alliance with the great Powers of Europe, to relieve part of his territory from the sway of a rebel chief. The European Powers would gladly have done this without strife or bloodshed. They did not hastily, nor wantonly, resort to measures of force.
</text>

<text id="490bf10432114101">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">
<textM no="1700-1712" no="1713-1725" no="1726-1738" no="1739-1751" no="1752-1764" no="1765-1777" no="1778-1790" no="1791-1803" no="1804-1816" no="1817-1829" no="1830-1842" no="1843-1855" no="1856-1868" no="1869-1881" no="1882-1894" no="1895-1907" no="1908-1920" no="1921-1933" no="1934-1946" no="1947-1959" no="1960-1972" no="1973-1985" no="1986-1998" no="1999-2011" no="2012-2024">
<textC no="1701-1721" no="1722-1742" no="1743-1763" no="1764-1784" no="1785-1805" no="1806-1826" no="1827-1847" no="1848-1868" no="1869-1889" no="1890-1910" no="1911-1931" no="1932-1952" no="1953-1973" no="1974-1994" no="1995-2015">
he had nothing to do to trouble himself with Affairs abroad ; which discouraged him from saying any more , he not being willing to be turned out of his Bread. Being asked, if Pledges had not been sufficient ; he said, that after the Last Sale, when People brought in their Defeazances, in order to receive their Surplusses, he made out an Account of their Pledges, and some of them proved deficient ; that Thomson had asked the Examinant to sign Bills of Sale ; but he refused.
</text>

<text id="179lj11211632115">
<textF no="1698-1704" no="1705-1711" no="1712-1718" no="1719-1725" no="1726-1732" no="1733-1739" no="1740-1746" no="1747-1753" no="1754-1760" no="1761-1767" no="1768-1774" no="1775-1781" no="1782-1788" no="1789-1795" no="1796-1802" no="1803-1809" no="1810-1816" no="1817-1823" no="1824-1830" no="1831-1837" no="1838-1844" no="1845-1851" no="1852-1858" no="1859-1865" no="1866-1872" no="1873-1879" no="1880-1886" no="1887-1893" no="1894-1900" no="1901-1907" no="1908-1914" no="1915-1921" no="1922-1928" no="1929-1935" no="1936-1942" no="1943-1949" no="1950-1956" no="1957-1963" no="1964-1970" no="1971-1977" no="1978-1984" no="1985-1991" no="1992-1998" no="1999-2005" no="2006-2012" no="2013-2019">
<textM no="1696-1708" no="1709-1721" no="1722-1734" no="1735-1747" no="1748-1760" no="1761-1773" no="1774-1786" no="1787-1799" no="1800-1812" no="1813-1825" no="1826-1838" no="1839-1851" no="1852-1864" no="1865-1877" no="1878-1890" no="1891-1903" no="1904-1916" no="1917-1929" no="1930-1942" no="1943-1955" no="1956-1968" no="1969-1981" no="1982-1994" no="1995-2007" no="2008-2020">
<textC no="1698-1718" no="1719-1739" no="1740-1760" no="1761-1781" no="1782-1802" no="1803-1823" no="1824-1844" no="1845-1865" no="1866-1886" no="1887-1907" no="1908-1928" no="1929-1949" no="1950-1970" no="1971-1991" no="1992-2012" no="2013-2033">
The Compagniedes telegraphes sous-Marins is commencing to lay cables fromGuadeloupe to the Saintes—St. Bartholomew and St. Martin—and will open an office at Basse Terre.
</text>

<text id="288cd105111105112">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1707-1719" no="1720-1732" no="1733-1745" no="1746-1758" no="1759-1771" no="1772-1784" no="1785-1797" no="1798-1810" no="1811-1823" no="1824-1836" no="1837-1849" no="1850-1862" no="1863-1875" no="1876-1888" no="1889-1901" no="1902-1914" no="1915-1927" no="1928-1940" no="1941-1953" no="1954-1966" no="1967-1979" no="1980-1992" no="1993-2005" no="2006-2018">
<textC no="1702-1722" no="1723-1743" no="1744-1764" no="1765-1785" no="1786-1806" no="1807-1827" no="1828-1848" no="1849-1869" no="1870-1890" no="1891-1911" no="1912-1932" no="1933-1953" no="1954-1974" no="1975-1995" no="1996-2016">
If any impediment or obstruction should prevent the action of the safely valve, and the engine cease working, then, according to the ratio of increase, the expansive force would accumulate, in less than three minutes, to the amount of 1,152 tons pressure upon the inside of the boiler.
</text>

<text id="403bm11197100102">
<textF no="1698-1704" no="1705-1711" no="1712-1718" no="1719-1725" no="1726-1732" no="1733-1739" no="1740-1746" no="1747-1753" no="1754-1760" no="1761-1767" no="1768-1774" no="1775-1781" no="1782-1788" no="1789-1795" no="1796-1802" no="1803-1809" no="1810-1816" no="1817-1823" no="1824-1830" no="1831-1837" no="1838-1844" no="1845-1851" no="1852-1858" no="1859-1865" no="1866-1872" no="1873-1879" no="1880-1886" no="1887-1893" no="1894-1900" no="1901-1907" no="1908-1914" no="1915-1921" no="1922-1928" no="1929-1935" no="1936-1942" no="1943-1949" no="1950-1956" no="1957-1963" no="1964-1970" no="1971-1977" no="1978-1984" no="1985-1991" no="1992-1998" no="1999-2005" no="2006-2012" no="2013-2019">
<textM no="1696-1708" no="1709-1721" no="1722-1734" no="1735-1747" no="1748-1760" no="1761-1773" no="1774-1786" no="1787-1799" no="1800-1812" no="1813-1825" no="1826-1838" no="1839-1851" no="1852-1864" no="1865-1877" no="1878-1890" no="1891-1903" no="1904-1916" no="1917-1929" no="1930-1942" no="1943-1955" no="1956-1968" no="1969-1981" no="1982-1994" no="1995-2007" no="2008-2020">
<textC no="1698-1718" no="1719-1739" no="1740-1760" no="1761-1781" no="1782-1802" no="1803-1823" no="1824-1844" no="1845-1865" no="1866-1886" no="1887-1907" no="1908-1928" no="1929-1949" no="1950-1970" no="1971-1991" no="1992-2012" no="2013-2033">
The Government have extended the time for receiving schemes, and will, no doubt, grant even a further extension if evidence is produced to Mr. Holmes or the Agent-General in London by intending competitors Surely the inventive mind of the day will be able to surmount all present difficulties ; the bonus is a strong incentive to machinists and chemists who give their attention to these matters.
</text>

<text id="124co10910132101">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1703-1715" no="1716-1728" no="1729-1741" no="1742-1754" no="1755-1767" no="1768-1780" no="1781-1793" no="1794-1806" no="1807-1819" no="1820-1832" no="1833-1845" no="1846-1858" no="1859-1871" no="1872-1884" no="1885-1897" no="1898-1910" no="1911-1923" no="1924-1936" no="1937-1949" no="1950-1962" no="1963-1975" no="1976-1988" no="1989-2001" no="2002-2014">
<textC no="1699-1719" no="1720-1740" no="1741-1761" no="1762-1782" no="1783-1803" no="1804-1824" no="1825-1845" no="1846-1866" no="1867-1887" no="1888-1908" no="1909-1929" no="1930-1950" no="1951-1971" no="1972-1992" no="1993-2013">
They immediately fell back to the lower End of the Room. You maybe sure they curtify'd low enough to me : But they began.
</text>

<text id="409ee102116115108">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1704-1716" no="1717-1729" no="1730-1742" no="1743-1755" no="1756-1768" no="1769-1781" no="1782-1794" no="1795-1807" no="1808-1820" no="1821-1833" no="1834-1846" no="1847-1859" no="1860-1872" no="1873-1885" no="1886-1898" no="1899-1911" no="1912-1924" no="1925-1937" no="1938-1950" no="1951-1963" no="1964-1976" no="1977-1989" no="1990-2002" no="2003-2015">
<textC no="1699-1719" no="1720-1740" no="1741-1761" no="1762-1782" no="1783-1803" no="1804-1824" no="1825-1845" no="1846-1866" no="1867-1887" no="1888-1908" no="1909-1929" no="1930-1950" no="1951-1971" no="1972-1992" no="1993-2013">
The fifth and sixth might justly be failed liquid Vowels; on account of the ease with which they flow into the other vowels without producing any hiatus; and it is their peculiarity to form a pant of all diphthongs, both in the English andFrench languages. In both the last mentioned vowels, thelong sounds are in some instances confounded with the short ones, even in the best orthoepical Dictionaries
</text>

<text id="248rd121101100115">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1703-1715" no="1716-1728" no="1729-1741" no="1742-1754" no="1755-1767" no="1768-1780" no="1781-1793" no="1794-1806" no="1807-1819" no="1820-1832" no="1833-1845" no="1846-1858" no="1859-1871" no="1872-1884" no="1885-1897" no="1898-1910" no="1911-1923" no="1924-1936" no="1937-1949" no="1950-1962" no="1963-1975" no="1976-1988" no="1989-2001" no="2002-2014">
<textC no="1706-1726" no="1727-1747" no="1748-1768" no="1769-1789" no="1790-1810" no="1811-1831" no="1832-1852" no="1853-1873" no="1874-1894" no="1895-1915" no="1916-1936" no="1937-1957" no="1958-1978" no="1979-1999" no="2000-2020">
If all your sentiments coincide with ours on this subjectand any proposal of this nature mould he submitted to the consideration of Parliament, we -trust you will use your utmost endeavours that the same may bepassed into a law. W e are, &c. &
</text>

<text id="456rp111104113116">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1696-1708" no="1709-1721" no="1722-1734" no="1735-1747" no="1748-1760" no="1761-1773" no="1774-1786" no="1787-1799" no="1800-1812" no="1813-1825" no="1826-1838" no="1839-1851" no="1852-1864" no="1865-1877" no="1878-1890" no="1891-1903" no="1904-1916" no="1917-1929" no="1930-1942" no="1943-1955" no="1956-1968" no="1969-1981" no="1982-1994" no="1995-2007" no="2008-2020">
<textC no="1709-1729" no="1730-1750" no="1751-1771" no="1772-1792" no="1793-1813" no="1814-1834" no="1835-1855" no="1856-1876" no="1877-1897" no="1898-1918" no="1919-1939" no="1940-1960" no="1961-1981" no="1982-2002" no="2003-2023">
In responding to the eager inquiries of these rabid democrats, as to his sentiments upon the question, his language was certainly uttered in a tone expressing an honest conviction ; it was certainly prompt and strong : his words were " To the Oregon our rights are clear and unquestionable." Whether these were the real sentiments of Mr. Polk, arrived after a mature deliberation or whether they were merely employed as stepping-stone to the Presidency.
</text>

<text id="514bl108119116114">
<textF no="1698-1704" no="1705-1711" no="1712-1718" no="1719-1725" no="1726-1732" no="1733-1739" no="1740-1746" no="1747-1753" no="1754-1760" no="1761-1767" no="1768-1774" no="1775-1781" no="1782-1788" no="1789-1795" no="1796-1802" no="1803-1809" no="1810-1816" no="1817-1823" no="1824-1830" no="1831-1837" no="1838-1844" no="1845-1851" no="1852-1858" no="1859-1865" no="1866-1872" no="1873-1879" no="1880-1886" no="1887-1893" no="1894-1900" no="1901-1907" no="1908-1914" no="1915-1921" no="1922-1928" no="1929-1935" no="1936-1942" no="1943-1949" no="1950-1956" no="1957-1963" no="1964-1970" no="1971-1977" no="1978-1984" no="1985-1991" no="1992-1998" no="1999-2005" no="2006-2012" no="2013-2019">
<textM no="1696-1708" no="1709-1721" no="1722-1734" no="1735-1747" no="1748-1760" no="1761-1773" no="1774-1786" no="1787-1799" no="1800-1812" no="1813-1825" no="1826-1838" no="1839-1851" no="1852-1864" no="1865-1877" no="1878-1890" no="1891-1903" no="1904-1916" no="1917-1929" no="1930-1942" no="1943-1955" no="1956-1968" no="1969-1981" no="1982-1994" no="1995-2007" no="2008-2020">
<textC no="1698-1718" no="1719-1739" no="1740-1760" no="1761-1781" no="1782-1802" no="1803-1823" no="1824-1844" no="1845-1865" no="1866-1886" no="1887-1907" no="1908-1928" no="1929-1949" no="1950-1970" no="1971-1991" no="1992-2012" no="2013-2033">
Mr. William Clark will not return to Sierra Leone on the expiration of his leave, as he has been selected to succeed Sir Neville Geary, Bart., as Attorney-General of the Gold Coast. Mr. Clark is to be congratulated on his promotion, which financially is an important one, as the salary of his new officecommences at 800£. and rises to 1,000?. a year. British Guiana is becoming well represented on the Gold Coast, both Mr. William Nicoll and Mr. William Clark now occupying important legal appointments there.
</text>

<text id="328qb133244108">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">
<textM no="1699-1711" no="1712-1724" no="1725-1737" no="1738-1750" no="1751-1763" no="1764-1776" no="1777-1789" no="1790-1802" no="1803-1815" no="1816-1828" no="1829-1841" no="1842-1854" no="1855-1867" no="1868-1880" no="1881-1893" no="1894-1906" no="1907-1919" no="1920-1932" no="1933-1945" no="1946-1958" no="1959-1971" no="1972-1984" no="1985-1997" no="1998-2010" no="2011-2023">
<textC no="1708-1728" no="1729-1749" no="1750-1770" no="1771-1791" no="1792-1812" no="1813-1833" no="1834-1854" no="1855-1875" no="1876-1896" no="1897-1917" no="1918-1938" no="1939-1959" no="1960-1980" no="1981-2001" no="2002-2022">
London, On Friday light last, between Eleven and Twelve , the Count de Perouie , Envoy - Extraordinary of the King of Sicily, receiv'd an express from his Master which came in five Days from Turin , with a Letter to the king of Great Britain , which he deliver'd on Saturday Morning in an Audience he had of his Majesty.
</text>

<text id="773bd101112104115">
<textF no="1700-1706" no="1707-1713" no="1714-1720" no="1721-1727" no="1728-1734" no="1735-1741" no="1742-1748" no="1749-1755" no="1756-1762" no="1763-1769" no="1770-1776" no="1777-1783" no="1784-1790" no="1791-1797" no="1798-1804" no="1805-1811" no="1812-1818" no="1819-1825" no="1826-1832" no="1833-1839" no="1840-1846" no="1847-1853" no="1854-1860" no="1861-1867" no="1868-1874" no="1875-1881" no="1882-1888" no="1889-1895" no="1896-1902" no="1903-1909" no="1910-1916" no="1917-1923" no="1924-1930" no="1931-1937" no="1938-1944" no="1945-1951" no="1952-1958" no="1959-1965" no="1966-1972" no="1973-1979" no="1980-1986" no="1987-1993" no="1994-2000" no="2001-2007" no="2008-2014">
<textM no="1701-1713" no="1714-1726" no="1727-1739" no="1740-1752" no="1753-1765" no="1766-1778" no="1779-1791" no="1792-1804" no="1805-1817" no="1818-1830" no="1831-1843" no="1844-1856" no="1857-1869" no="1870-1882" no="1883-1895" no="1896-1908" no="1909-1921" no="1922-1934" no="1935-1947" no="1948-1960" no="1961-1973" no="1974-1986" no="1987-1999" no="2000-2012" no="2013-2025">
<textC no="1693-1713" no="1714-1734" no="1735-1755" no="1756-1776" no="1777-1797" no="1798-1818" no="1819-1839" no="1840-1860" no="1861-1881" no="1882-1902" no="1903-1923" no="1924-1944" no="1945-1965" no="1966-1986" no="1987-2007" no="2008-2028">
Alexander Seed, a Policeman, has lost his life in Guy's Hospital from in- haling chloroform. About a year ago, his finger was bitten by a man whom he had taken prisoner ; it was necessary to amputate part of the finger,- recently he has suffered much pain in the hand and arm. He went to Guy's Hospital, and was advised to have the rest of the bone of the finger removed, as it was diseased. Mr. Cook, one of the surgeons, proposed to remove it in the usual way; but Scott begged so earnestly that chloroform might be given him, that Mr. Cock cemented. The vapour was first administered by a ma- chine, but did not take effect ; then a napkin was used, and the patient be- came unconscious. The bone was rapidly cut out ; but it was then found that the patient was dead.
</text>

<text id="164ik10511610897">
<textF no="1704-1710" no="1711-1717" no="1718-1724" no="1725-1731" no="1732-1738" no="1739-1745" no="1746-1752" no="1753-1759" no="1760-1766" no="1767-1773" no="1774-1780" no="1781-1787" no="1788-1794" no="1795-1801" no="1802-1808" no="1809-1815" no="1816-1822" no="1823-1829" no="1830-1836" no="1837-1843" no="1844-1850" no="1851-1857" no="1858-1864" no="1865-1871" no="1872-1878" no="1879-1885" no="1886-1892" no="1893-1899" no="1900-1906" no="1907-1913" no="1914-1920" no="1921-1927" no="1928-1934" no="1935-1941" no="1942-1948" no="1949-1955" no="1956-1962" no="1963-1969" no="1970-1976" no="1977-1983" no="1984-1990" no="1991-1997" no="1998-2004" no="2005-2011" no="2012-2018">
<textM no="1695-1707" no="1708-1720" no="1721-1733" no="1734-1746" no="1747-1759" no="1760-1772" no="1773-1785" no="1786-1798" no="1799-1811" no="1812-1824" no="1825-1837" no="1838-1850" no="1851-1863" no="1864-1876" no="1877-1889" no="1890-1902" no="1903-1915" no="1916-1928" no="1929-1941" no="1942-1954" no="1955-1967" no="1968-1980" no="1981-1993" no="1994-2006" no="2007-2019">
<textC no="1704-1724" no="1725-1745" no="1746-1766" no="1767-1787" no="1788-1808" no="1809-1829" no="1830-1850" no="1851-1871" no="1872-1892" no="1893-1913" no="1914-1934" no="1935-1955" no="1956-1976" no="1977-1997" no="1998-2018">
The King has sent Circular Letters to ail the General Officers, commanding them to repair to Court with all possible Speed;but upon what Account, is not known
</text>

<text id="518to11112832116">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1702-1714" no="1715-1727" no="1728-1740" no="1741-1753" no="1754-1766" no="1767-1779" no="1780-1792" no="1793-1805" no="1806-1818" no="1819-1831" no="1832-1844" no="1845-1857" no="1858-1870" no="1871-1883" no="1884-1896" no="1897-1909" no="1910-1922" no="1923-1935" no="1936-1948" no="1949-1961" no="1962-1974" no="1975-1987" no="1988-2000" no="2001-2013">
<textC no="1702-1722" no="1723-1743" no="1744-1764" no="1765-1785" no="1786-1806" no="1807-1827" no="1828-1848" no="1849-1869" no="1870-1890" no="1891-1911" no="1912-1932" no="1933-1953" no="1954-1974" no="1975-1995" no="1996-2016">
The Alton Affair.—The grand jury of Alton found bills of indictment against a number of individuals concerned in the affair of the 7th of November last, including those engaged in the attack as well as defence of the building. The trial of Rock, one of the assailants, came before the Municipal court on the 4th ult. The jury	 returned	a	special verdict	that the defendant, in their opinion, is guiltyof the various charges laid in the indictment, but that they return him not guilty on question of jurisdiction.
</text>

<text id="112so10432116115">
<textF no="1704-1710" no="1711-1717" no="1718-1724" no="1725-1731" no="1732-1738" no="1739-1745" no="1746-1752" no="1753-1759" no="1760-1766" no="1767-1773" no="1774-1780" no="1781-1787" no="1788-1794" no="1795-1801" no="1802-1808" no="1809-1815" no="1816-1822" no="1823-1829" no="1830-1836" no="1837-1843" no="1844-1850" no="1851-1857" no="1858-1864" no="1865-1871" no="1872-1878" no="1879-1885" no="1886-1892" no="1893-1899" no="1900-1906" no="1907-1913" no="1914-1920" no="1921-1927" no="1928-1934" no="1935-1941" no="1942-1948" no="1949-1955" no="1956-1962" no="1963-1969" no="1970-1976" no="1977-1983" no="1984-1990" no="1991-1997" no="1998-2004" no="2005-2011" no="2012-2018">

And that was how it was that little Gussie mustered up courage enough to propose to the beautiful athlete.
</text>

The New York Times, in view of present and prospective hard times, has a word of advice and warning to wives to practice economy for the sake of relieving the pressure on the pockets of their husbands.
</text>

<text id="103bf11497111112">
<textF no="1700-1706" no="1707-1713" no="1714-1720" no="1721-1727" no="1728-1734" no="1735-1741" no="1742-1748" no="1749-1755" no="1756-1762" no="1763-1769" no="1770-1776" no="1777-1783" no="1784-1790" no="1791-1797" no="1798-1804" no="1805-1811" no="1812-1818" no="1819-1825" no="1826-1832" no="1833-1839" no="1840-1846" no="1847-1853" no="1854-1860" no="1861-1867" no="1868-1874" no="1875-1881" no="1882-1888" no="1889-1895" no="1896-1902" no="1903-1909" no="1910-1916" no="1917-1923" no="1924-1930" no="1931-1937" no="1938-1944" no="1945-1951" no="1952-1958" no="1959-1965" no="1966-1972" no="1973-1979" no="1980-1986" no="1987-1993" no="1994-2000" no="2001-2007" no="2008-2014">

<text id="320sk97105101101">
<textF no="1703-1709" no="1710-1716" no="1717-1723" no="1724-1730" no="1731-1737" no="1738-1744" no="1745-1751" no="1752-1758" no="1759-1765" no="1766-1772" no="1773-1779" no="1780-1786" no="1787-1793" no="1794-1800" no="1801-1807" no="1808-1814" no="1815-1821" no="1822-1828" no="1829-1835" no="1836-1842" no="1843-1849" no="1850-1856" no="1857-1863" no="1864-1870" no="1871-1877" no="1878-1884" no="1885-1891" no="1892-1898" no="1899-1905" no="1906-1912" no="1913-1919" no="1920-1926" no="1927-1933" no="1934-1940" no="1941-1947" no="1948-1954" no="1955-1961" no="1962-1968" no="1969-1975" no="1976-1982" no="1983-1989" no="1990-1996" no="1997-2003" no="2004-2010" no="2011-2017">

<textC no="1703-1723" no="1724-1744" no="1745-1765" no="1766-1786" no="1787-1807" no="1808-1828" no="1829-1849" no="1850-1870" no="1871-1891" no="1892-1912" no="1913-1933" no="1934-1954" no="1955-1975" no="1976-1996" no="1997-2017">
If Mt Harper and his associates are sincere in their desire to punish, why do they not seek the man who printed the cards (whose name they know), instead of trying to make political capital out of the matter by trying to defeat two candidates for office who were in no way to blame for the use of the imitation label?
</text>

<text id="552bl3210932116">
<textF no="1703-1709" no="1710-1716" no="1717-1723" no="1724-1730" no="1731-1737" no="1738-1744" no="1745-1751" no="1752-1758" no="1759-1765" no="1766-1772" no="1773-1779" no="1780-1786" no="1787-1793" no="1794-1800" no="1801-1807" no="1808-1814" no="1815-1821" no="1822-1828" no="1829-1835" no="1836-1842" no="1843-1849" no="1850-1856" no="1857-1863" no="1864-1870" no="1871-1877" no="1878-1884" no="1885-1891" no="1892-1898" no="1899-1905" no="1906-1912" no="1913-1919" no="1920-1926" no="1927-1933" no="1934-1940" no="1941-1947" no="1948-1954" no="1955-1961" no="1962-1968" no="1969-1975" no="1976-1982" no="1983-1989" no="1990-1996" no="1997-2003" no="2004-2010" no="2011-2017">
<textM no="1696-1708" no="1709-1721" no="1722-1734" no="1735-1747" no="1748-1760" no="1761-1773" no="1774-1786" no="1787-1799" no="1800-1812" no="1813-1825" no="1826-1838" no="1839-1851" no="1852-1864" no="1865-1877" no="1878-1890" no="1891-1903" no="1904-1916" no="1917-1929" no="1930-1942" no="1943-1955" no="1956-1968" no="1969-1981" no="1982-1994" no="1995-2007" no="2008-2020">
<textC no="1710-1730" no="1731-1751" no="1752-1772" no="1773-1793" no="1794-1814" no="1815-1835" no="1836-1856" no="1857-1877" no="1878-1898" no="1899-1919" no="1920-1940" no="1941-1961" no="1962-1982" no="1983-2003" no="2004-2024">
The modern Germans do not differ in their Dress from other People; they have their Fashions and richest Stuffs from Paris, which City, by a sort of common Consens, has been the Standard for Taste and Fashions to most Nations. The "Silver and Gold Lace, however, being laid upon the German coarse Cloth, does not produce so good an Effect as when they are laid upon Italian Velvet, or the fine Wool of Spain and England ; but perhaps on this Occasion we may make use of a common Proverb, which says, That it is not all Gold that glitters.
</text>

<text id="197dd9910810132">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">
<textM no="1700-1712" no="1713-1725" no="1726-1738" no="1739-1751" no="1752-1764" no="1765-1777" no="1778-1790" no="1791-1803" no="1804-1816" no="1817-1829" no="1830-1842" no="1843-1855" no="1856-1868" no="1869-1881" no="1882-1894" no="1895-1907" no="1908-1920" no="1921-1933" no="1934-1946" no="1947-1959" no="1960-1972" no="1973-1985" no="1986-1998" no="1999-2011" no="2012-2024">
<textC no="1701-1721" no="1722-1742" no="1743-1763" no="1764-1784" no="1785-1805" no="1806-1826" no="1827-1847" no="1848-1868" no="1869-1889" no="1890-1910" no="1911-1931" no="1932-1952" no="1953-1973" no="1974-1994" no="1995-2015">
publick Tranquillity. and being, as we conceive, no ways necessary to support, may (we fear) endanger our Constitution, which hath never yet been entirely subverted, but by a Standing Army.
</text>

<text id="742af11611832111">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1695-1707" no="1708-1720" no="1721-1733" no="1734-1746" no="1747-1759" no="1760-1772" no="1773-1785" no="1786-1798" no="1799-1811" no="1812-1824" no="1825-1837" no="1838-1850" no="1851-1863" no="1864-1876" no="1877-1889" no="1890-1902" no="1903-1915" no="1916-1928" no="1929-1941" no="1942-1954" no="1955-1967" no="1968-1980" no="1981-1993" no="1994-2006" no="2007-2019">
<textC no="1706-1726" no="1727-1747" no="1748-1768" no="1769-1789" no="1790-1810" no="1811-1831" no="1832-1852" no="1853-1873" no="1874-1894" no="1895-1915" no="1916-1936" no="1937-1957" no="1958-1978" no="1979-1999" no="2000-2020">
At a time when every pen is ready to do justice to your abilities, in your public character , I can scarcely hope the following lines will be thought worthy of your private attention ; but as the greatest men in this, and every age, have given instances of the fallibility of human reasoning I shall venture with all due deference to your Lordship to give my sentiments upon your conduct relative to divorce bills. Permit me then to ask your Lordship, as the principal object of my letter, whether you have duly considered the tendency of those difficulties which you have hitherto thrown in the way of every parliamentary separation? I think with your Lordship that too much care cannot be taken to check the growing evil of adultery
</text>

<text id="437tf3911132117">
<textF no="1703-1709" no="1710-1716" no="1717-1723" no="1724-1730" no="1731-1737" no="1738-1744" no="1745-1751" no="1752-1758" no="1759-1765" no="1766-1772" no="1773-1779" no="1780-1786" no="1787-1793" no="1794-1800" no="1801-1807" no="1808-1814" no="1815-1821" no="1822-1828" no="1829-1835" no="1836-1842" no="1843-1849" no="1850-1856" no="1857-1863" no="1864-1870" no="1871-1877" no="1878-1884" no="1885-1891" no="1892-1898" no="1899-1905" no="1906-1912" no="1913-1919" no="1920-1926" no="1927-1933" no="1934-1940" no="1941-1947" no="1948-1954" no="1955-1961" no="1962-1968" no="1969-1975" no="1976-1982" no="1983-1989" no="1990-1996" no="1997-2003" no="2004-2010" no="2011-2017">
<textM no="1702-1714" no="1715-1727" no="1728-1740" no="1741-1753" no="1754-1766" no="1767-1779" no="1780-1792" no="1793-1805" no="1806-1818" no="1819-1831" no="1832-1844" no="1845-1857" no="1858-1870" no="1871-1883" no="1884-1896" no="1897-1909" no="1910-1922" no="1923-1935" no="1936-1948" no="1949-1961" no="1962-1974" no="1975-1987" no="1988-2000" no="2001-2013">
<textC no="1703-1723" no="1724-1744" no="1745-1765" no="1766-1786" no="1787-1807" no="1808-1828" no="1829-1849" no="1850-1870" no="1871-1891" no="1892-1912" no="1913-1933" no="1934-1954" no="1955-1975" no="1976-1996" no="1997-2017">
Rodgers'z famous Lozenges for the Heartburn in two or three Minutes Time effectally cure that Distemper, even in the most violent Degree whether proceeding from hard Drinking bad Digestion or any Cause whatsoever. They are a pleseant Medicine and excel any Thing that hath yet appear'd in the World in that Form; may be taken at any Time, and, if continued some While, will not only remove Effects but Certainly destroy the Cause.
</text>

<text id="405rl120110101103">
<textF no="1698-1704" no="1705-1711" no="1712-1718" no="1719-1725" no="1726-1732" no="1733-1739" no="1740-1746" no="1747-1753" no="1754-1760" no="1761-1767" no="1768-1774" no="1775-1781" no="1782-1788" no="1789-1795" no="1796-1802" no="1803-1809" no="1810-1816" no="1817-1823" no="1824-1830" no="1831-1837" no="1838-1844" no="1845-1851" no="1852-1858" no="1859-1865" no="1866-1872" no="1873-1879" no="1880-1886" no="1887-1893" no="1894-1900" no="1901-1907" no="1908-1914" no="1915-1921" no="1922-1928" no="1929-1935" no="1936-1942" no="1943-1949" no="1950-1956" no="1957-1963" no="1964-1970" no="1971-1977" no="1978-1984" no="1985-1991" no="1992-1998" no="1999-2005" no="2006-2012" no="2013-2019">

<textC no="1698-1718" no="1719-1739" no="1740-1760" no="1761-1781" no="1782-1802" no="1803-1823" no="1824-1844" no="1845-1865" no="1866-1886" no="1887-1907" no="1908-1928" no="1929-1949" no="1950-1970" no="1971-1991" no="1992-2012" no="2013-2033">
the exports during, the same year being : New South Wales,23,010,3492.; Victoria, 14,198,5182.; New Zealand, 9,321,1052.; Queensland, 9,163,5182. ; South Australia, 7,743,0632, ; Western Australia, 1,Q50,226Z.; and Tasmania, 1,496,5762. ; representing a total trade of 129,219,9902., of which the share enjoyed by New South Wales was>43,571,8592., or considerably more than one-third of the whole
</text>

<text id="394sl1213299115">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1700-1712" no="1713-1725" no="1726-1738" no="1739-1751" no="1752-1764" no="1765-1777" no="1778-1790" no="1791-1803" no="1804-1816" no="1817-1829" no="1830-1842" no="1843-1855" no="1856-1868" no="1869-1881" no="1882-1894" no="1895-1907" no="1908-1920" no="1921-1933" no="1934-1946" no="1947-1959" no="1960-1972" no="1973-1985" no="1986-1998" no="1999-2011" no="2012-2024">
<textC no="1709-1729" no="1730-1750" no="1751-1771" no="1772-1792" no="1793-1813" no="1814-1834" no="1835-1855" no="1856-1876" no="1877-1897" no="1898-1918" no="1919-1939" no="1940-1960" no="1961-1981" no="1982-2002" no="2003-2023">
Monday there was a Cabinet Council at St. James's, wherein the Deputy Recorder made a Report of the Condemn'd Malefactors. Sir Henry Penrice Judge of the High - Court of Admiralty attended likewise to make his Report of the Condemn'd Pirates. It was then turn'd into a General Council , and some Names of the Sherriffs which were misspelt upon the Roll , were order'd to be alter'd.
</text>

<text id="326iq11110232110">
<textF no="1704-1710" no="1711-1717" no="1718-1724" no="1725-1731" no="1732-1738" no="1739-1745" no="1746-1752" no="1753-1759" no="1760-1766" no="1767-1773" no="1774-1780" no="1781-1787" no="1788-1794" no="1795-1801" no="1802-1808" no="1809-1815" no="1816-1822" no="1823-1829" no="1830-1836" no="1837-1843" no="1844-1850" no="1851-1857" no="1858-1864" no="1865-1871" no="1872-1878" no="1879-1885" no="1886-1892" no="1893-1899" no="1900-1906" no="1907-1913" no="1914-1920" no="1921-1927" no="1928-1934" no="1935-1941" no="1942-1948" no="1949-1955" no="1956-1962" no="1963-1969" no="1970-1976" no="1977-1983" no="1984-1990" no="1991-1997" no="1998-2004" no="2005-2011" no="2012-2018">
<textM no="1697-1709" no="1710-1722" no="1723-1735" no="1736-1748" no="1749-1761" no="1762-1774" no="1775-1787" no="1788-1800" no="1801-1813" no="1814-1826" no="1827-1839" no="1840-1852" no="1853-1865" no="1866-1878" no="1879-1891" no="1892-1904" no="1905-1917" no="1918-1930" no="1931-1943" no="1944-1956" no="1957-1969" no="1970-1982" no="1983-1995" no="1996-2008" no="2009-2021">
<textC no="1711-1731" no="1732-1752" no="1753-1773" no="1774-1794" no="1795-1815" no="1816-1836" no="1837-1857" no="1858-1878" no="1879-1899" no="1900-1920" no="1921-1941" no="1942-1962" no="1963-1983" no="1984-2004" no="2005-2025">
the ROYAL BEAUTIFYING FLUID So exceedingly valued by Ladies of Quality and all who have used it for its transcedent Excellency in beautifying the Face, Neck and Hands to the most exquisite Perfection possible is to be had only at Mr. Radford's Teyshop at the Rose and Crown against St. Clement's Church yard in the Strand
</text>

<text id="844hl9711611432">
<textF no="1703-1709" no="1710-1716" no="1717-1723" no="1724-1730" no="1731-1737" no="1738-1744" no="1745-1751" no="1752-1758" no="1759-1765" no="1766-1772" no="1773-1779" no="1780-1786" no="1787-1793" no="1794-1800" no="1801-1807" no="1808-1814" no="1815-1821" no="1822-1828" no="1829-1835" no="1836-1842" no="1843-1849" no="1850-1856" no="1857-1863" no="1864-1870" no="1871-1877" no="1878-1884" no="1885-1891" no="1892-1898" no="1899-1905" no="1906-1912" no="1913-1919" no="1920-1926" no="1927-1933" no="1934-1940" no="1941-1947" no="1948-1954" no="1955-1961" no="1962-1968" no="1969-1975" no="1976-1982" no="1983-1989" no="1990-1996" no="1997-2003" no="2004-2010" no="2011-2017">
<textM no="1700-1712" no="1713-1725" no="1726-1738" no="1739-1751" no="1752-1764" no="1765-1777" no="1778-1790" no="1791-1803" no="1804-1816" no="1817-1829" no="1830-1842" no="1843-1855" no="1856-1868" no="1869-1881" no="1882-1894" no="1895-1907" no="1908-1920" no="1921-1933" no="1934-1946" no="1947-1959" no="1960-1972" no="1973-1985" no="1986-1998" no="1999-2011" no="2012-2024">
<textC no="1710-1730" no="1731-1751" no="1752-1772" no="1773-1793" no="1794-1814" no="1815-1835" no="1836-1856" no="1857-1877" no="1878-1898" no="1899-1919" no="1920-1940" no="1941-1961" no="1962-1982" no="1983-2003" no="2004-2024">
The data on which the engineer relies in designing structures cannot be fully understood without some knowledge of the methods by which they are ascertained, and this knowledge of those methods has become of late years of greater importance. With the introduction of new materials, the engineer has been forced to make greater use of the testing machine, both in estimating theconstructional value of materials, and in providing against the danger of employing material which is unsuitable. A considerable advance has also been made in the construction of all the apparatus used in testing, and the operations of testing are carried out with more care and skill; whilst the establishment of engineering laboratories, in connection with schools of engineering, has made experimental investigation an essential part of engineering education.
</text>

<text id="620nj11532100119">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1704-1716" no="1717-1729" no="1730-1742" no="1743-1755" no="1756-1768" no="1769-1781" no="1782-1794" no="1795-1807" no="1808-1820" no="1821-1833" no="1834-1846" no="1847-1859" no="1860-1872" no="1873-1885" no="1886-1898" no="1899-1911" no="1912-1924" no="1925-1937" no="1938-1950" no="1951-1963" no="1964-1976" no="1977-1989" no="1990-2002" no="2003-2015">
<textC no="1699-1719" no="1720-1740" no="1741-1761" no="1762-1782" no="1783-1803" no="1804-1824" no="1825-1845" no="1846-1866" no="1867-1887" no="1888-1908" no="1909-1929" no="1930-1950" no="1951-1971" no="1972-1992" no="1993-2013">
whereas, if it is merely laid over, it will be necessary to tighten it to such a degree, as to occasion a great measure of friction on the brasses, or centres of the shafts, by which means a great portion of power would be lost, and the motion or way of the vessel impeded. By adopt- ing this plan, all noise arising from the friction of the wheels would be avoided ; but in cases where it is necessary to use wheels, for the purpose of communicating the power of the engine to the water- wheel at the stern of the vessel, the cogs of one wheel should be iron, and the other wood, or the cogs of both may be of wood,
</text>

<text id="818nr11046115108">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">
<textM no="1702-1714" no="1715-1727" no="1728-1740" no="1741-1753" no="1754-1766" no="1767-1779" no="1780-1792" no="1793-1805" no="1806-1818" no="1819-1831" no="1832-1844" no="1845-1857" no="1858-1870" no="1871-1883" no="1884-1896" no="1897-1909" no="1910-1922" no="1923-1935" no="1936-1948" no="1949-1961" no="1962-1974" no="1975-1987" no="1988-2000" no="2001-2013">
<textC no="1694-1714" no="1715-1735" no="1736-1756" no="1757-1777" no="1778-1798" no="1799-1819" no="1820-1840" no="1841-1861" no="1862-1882" no="1883-1903" no="1904-1924" no="1925-1945" no="1946-1966" no="1967-1987" no="1988-2008" no="2009-2029">
Recommendations. 1. The waters filter well. 2. Being filtered, they are bright. 3. Palatable when cool. (These three recommendations are restricted to the ease when the waters are in good condition ; or, as we understand by the sequel, not flooded, nor with much organic matter in them, as in autumn.) 4. The mineral contents of the waters are not unwholesome. 5. The waters do not act dangerously on lead pipes or cisterns ; neither do they eat out hollows or cause bulky swellings in the iron pipes, as some other waters do. 6. Being hard, they are less favourable to putrefaction of the organic contents of them than softer waters would be. 7. The Thames offers what appears an inexhaustible source—from 600 to 800 million of gallons daily, or at least twelve times the present demand of the whole metropolis.
</text>

<text id="536fs1083210244">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1707-1719" no="1720-1732" no="1733-1745" no="1746-1758" no="1759-1771" no="1772-1784" no="1785-1797" no="1798-1810" no="1811-1823" no="1824-1836" no="1837-1849" no="1850-1862" no="1863-1875" no="1876-1888" no="1889-1901" no="1902-1914" no="1915-1927" no="1928-1940" no="1941-1953" no="1954-1966" no="1967-1979" no="1980-1992" no="1993-2005" no="2006-2018">
<textC no="1702-1722" no="1723-1743" no="1744-1764" no="1765-1785" no="1786-1806" no="1807-1827" no="1828-1848" no="1849-1869" no="1870-1890" no="1891-1911" no="1912-1932" no="1933-1953" no="1954-1974" no="1975-1995" no="1996-2016">
a ballot for the ELECTION of FOUR BOYS, to be Maintained, Clothed and Educated by this Society, will take place at the London Tavern, on Wednesday, the 18th February next. TheParents (if living) must be resident within the Bills of Mortality,ind either the	Father or Mother must have been born in York shire.	The Children to be between the age of 7 and 11, and will be provided for till they are 14 years old.	The forms of the necessary certificates, &c. with a list of the subscribe:s, may be had on application to the Secretary.
</text>

<text id="168cb119111110110">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">

<textC no="1701-1721" no="1722-1742" no="1743-1763" no="1764-1784" no="1785-1805" no="1806-1826" no="1827-1847" no="1848-1868" no="1869-1889" no="1890-1910" no="1911-1931" no="1932-1952" no="1953-1973" no="1974-1994" no="1995-2015">
upon which Thomson has given the Examinant old Defeazances, and ordered him to renew them, by making out on them new Bills of Sale, Certificates, and Defeazances:
</text>

<text id="116ak10032101103">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1695-1707" no="1708-1720" no="1721-1733" no="1734-1746" no="1747-1759" no="1760-1772" no="1773-1785" no="1786-1798" no="1799-1811" no="1812-1824" no="1825-1837" no="1838-1850" no="1851-1863" no="1864-1876" no="1877-1889" no="1890-1902" no="1903-1915" no="1916-1928" no="1929-1941" no="1942-1954" no="1955-1967" no="1968-1980" no="1981-1993" no="1994-2006" no="2007-2019">
<textC no="1706-1726" no="1727-1747" no="1748-1768" no="1769-1789" no="1790-1810" no="1811-1831" no="1832-1852" no="1853-1873" no="1874-1894" no="1895-1915" no="1916-1936" no="1937-1957" no="1958-1978" no="1979-1999" no="2000-2020">
SPLENDID ARTIICIAL FIREWORK Each Evening to begin precisely at SEVEN o'CLOCK Admittance Half a Crown each Person
</text>

<text id="423ne97329999">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">
<textM no="1701-1713" no="1714-1726" no="1727-1739" no="1740-1752" no="1753-1765" no="1766-1778" no="1779-1791" no="1792-1804" no="1805-1817" no="1818-1830" no="1831-1843" no="1844-1856" no="1857-1869" no="1870-1882" no="1883-1895" no="1896-1908" no="1909-1921" no="1922-1934" no="1935-1947" no="1948-1960" no="1961-1973" no="1974-1986" no="1987-1999" no="2000-2012" no="2013-2025">
<textC no="1701-1721" no="1722-1742" no="1743-1763" no="1764-1784" no="1785-1805" no="1806-1826" no="1827-1847" no="1848-1868" no="1869-1889" no="1890-1910" no="1911-1931" no="1932-1952" no="1953-1973" no="1974-1994" no="1995-2015">
Yesterday morning, at nine o'clock, Mr. Caritar, the coroner, and the jury reassembled at the Town-hall, Gravesend, to further investigate the circumstancesleading to the death of Mary A nn Jones, the stewardess of the Apollo	steam	vessel.Mr. Ryland, again attended for the General Steam Navigation Company, to which company the Monarch belongs, and Mr. Claison for the Commercial Steam Company, which owns the Apollo.
</text>

<text id="173sq9832105121">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1705-1717" no="1718-1730" no="1731-1743" no="1744-1756" no="1757-1769" no="1770-1782" no="1783-1795" no="1796-1808" no="1809-1821" no="1822-1834" no="1835-1847" no="1848-1860" no="1861-1873" no="1874-1886" no="1887-1899" no="1900-1912" no="1913-1925" no="1926-1938" no="1939-1951" no="1952-1964" no="1965-1977" no="1978-1990" no="1991-2003" no="2004-2016">
<textC no="1706-1726" no="1727-1747" no="1748-1768" no="1769-1789" no="1790-1810" no="1811-1831" no="1832-1852" no="1853-1873" no="1874-1894" no="1895-1915" no="1916-1936" no="1937-1957" no="1958-1978" no="1979-1999" no="2000-2020">
Petersbourg. Cont Munich arriv'd here Yesterday, and met with a most gracious Reception from the Empress. The Emperor's Minister is very assiduous in his Conferences
</text>

<text id="229sj110117107116">
<textF no="1700-1706" no="1707-1713" no="1714-1720" no="1721-1727" no="1728-1734" no="1735-1741" no="1742-1748" no="1749-1755" no="1756-1762" no="1763-1769" no="1770-1776" no="1777-1783" no="1784-1790" no="1791-1797" no="1798-1804" no="1805-1811" no="1812-1818" no="1819-1825" no="1826-1832" no="1833-1839" no="1840-1846" no="1847-1853" no="1854-1860" no="1861-1867" no="1868-1874" no="1875-1881" no="1882-1888" no="1889-1895" no="1896-1902" no="1903-1909" no="1910-1916" no="1917-1923" no="1924-1930" no="1931-1937" no="1938-1944" no="1945-1951" no="1952-1958" no="1959-1965" no="1966-1972" no="1973-1979" no="1980-1986" no="1987-1993" no="1994-2000" no="2001-2007" no="2008-2014">
<textM no="1698-1710" no="1711-1723" no="1724-1736" no="1737-1749" no="1750-1762" no="1763-1775" no="1776-1788" no="1789-1801" no="1802-1814" no="1815-1827" no="1828-1840" no="1841-1853" no="1854-1866" no="1867-1879" no="1880-1892" no="1893-1905" no="1906-1918" no="1919-1931" no="1932-1944" no="1945-1957" no="1958-1970" no="1971-1983" no="1984-1996" no="1997-2009" no="2010-2022">
<textC no="1707-1727" no="1728-1748" no="1749-1769" no="1770-1790" no="1791-1811" no="1812-1832" no="1833-1853" no="1854-1874" no="1875-1895" no="1896-1916" no="1917-1937" no="1938-1958" no="1959-1979" no="1980-2000" no="2001-2021">
I was never for putting the King to death, tho' there is a Scandal rais'd of me, that in a Sermon at Windsor, I should have these Word, That it would never be well with England, till the King were let blood in the Neck-Vein.
</text>

<text id="380go11111611632">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1705-1717" no="1718-1730" no="1731-1743" no="1744-1756" no="1757-1769" no="1770-1782" no="1783-1795" no="1796-1808" no="1809-1821" no="1822-1834" no="1835-1847" no="1848-1860" no="1861-1873" no="1874-1886" no="1887-1899" no="1900-1912" no="1913-1925" no="1926-1938" no="1939-1951" no="1952-1964" no="1965-1977" no="1978-1990" no="1991-2003" no="2004-2016">
<textC no="1706-1726" no="1727-1747" no="1748-1768" no="1769-1789" no="1790-1810" no="1811-1831" no="1832-1852" no="1853-1873" no="1874-1894" no="1895-1915" no="1916-1936" no="1937-1957" no="1958-1978" no="1979-1999" no="2000-2020">
THE Society for the Propagation of the Gospel in Foreign Parts, Executors and Residuary Legatees in the Last Will and Testament of the Rev. Mr. John Andleron, late of the Island of Sr. Chriftopher's, deceas'd intending to fell and dispose of all their Interest in his American Estate, Real and Personal, have appointed a Committee who will meet on Thursday the 27th Instant,
</text>

<text id="182mq114110114114">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">

A n Historical Account of the Rise and Growth of Heresy in the Christian Church to the 16th Century and farther with the Names of the Hereticks the Time when they lived and died.
</text>

<text id="212ht10511532114">
<textF no="1704-1710" no="1711-1717" no="1718-1724" no="1725-1731" no="1732-1738" no="1739-1745" no="1746-1752" no="1753-1759" no="1760-1766" no="1767-1773" no="1774-1780" no="1781-1787" no="1788-1794" no="1795-1801" no="1802-1808" no="1809-1815" no="1816-1822" no="1823-1829" no="1830-1836" no="1837-1843" no="1844-1850" no="1851-1857" no="1858-1864" no="1865-1871" no="1872-1878" no="1879-1885" no="1886-1892" no="1893-1899" no="1900-1906" no="1907-1913" no="1914-1920" no="1921-1927" no="1928-1934" no="1935-1941" no="1942-1948" no="1949-1955" no="1956-1962" no="1963-1969" no="1970-1976" no="1977-1983" no="1984-1990" no="1991-1997" no="1998-2004" no="2005-2011" no="2012-2018">

They write from Losten, that on the third of this month a fire broke out in the village of Tropendorf which burnt with such fury as to leave but avery final number of the houses and other building standing
</text>

<text id="197sq97993232">
<textF no="1703-1709" no="1710-1716" no="1717-1723" no="1724-1730" no="1731-1737" no="1738-1744" no="1745-1751" no="1752-1758" no="1759-1765" no="1766-1772" no="1773-1779" no="1780-1786" no="1787-1793" no="1794-1800" no="1801-1807" no="1808-1814" no="1815-1821" no="1822-1828" no="1829-1835" no="1836-1842" no="1843-1849" no="1850-1856" no="1857-1863" no="1864-1870" no="1871-1877" no="1878-1884" no="1885-1891" no="1892-1898" no="1899-1905" no="1906-1912" no="1913-1919" no="1920-1926" no="1927-1933" no="1934-1940" no="1941-1947" no="1948-1954" no="1955-1961" no="1962-1968" no="1969-1975" no="1976-1982" no="1983-1989" no="1990-1996" no="1997-2003" no="2004-2010" no="2011-2017">
