<text id="274qs9710599116">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1703-1715" no="1716-1728" no="1729-1741" no="1742-1754" no="1755-1767" no="1768-1780" no="1781-1793" no="1794-1806" no="1807-1819" no="1820-1832" no="1833-1845" no="1846-1858" no="1859-1871" no="1872-1884" no="1885-1897" no="1898-1910" no="1911-1923" no="1924-1936" no="1937-1949" no="1950-1962" no="1963-1975" no="1976-1988" no="1989-2001" no="2002-2014">
<textC no="1706-1726" no="1727-1747" no="1748-1768" no="1769-1789" no="1790-1810" no="1811-1831" no="1832-1852" no="1853-1873" no="1874-1894" no="1895-1915" no="1916-1936" no="1937-1957" no="1958-1978" no="1979-1999" no="2000-2020">
Yesterday the Sessions commenced before the Right Hon. Sir Wiliam Staines, (Lord Mayor,)Mr. Justice Grose, Mr. Justice Rooke, Mr. Recorder, & c when 2 0 prisoners were tried, fixof whom were capitally convicted ; eight were convicted of felony, and four were acquitted.
</text>

<text id="186bn101100115119">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">
<textM no="1699-1711" no="1712-1724" no="1725-1737" no="1738-1750" no="1751-1763" no="1764-1776" no="1777-1789" no="1790-1802" no="1803-1815" no="1816-1828" no="1829-1841" no="1842-1854" no="1855-1867" no="1868-1880" no="1881-1893" no="1894-1906" no="1907-1919" no="1920-1932" no="1933-1945" no="1946-1958" no="1959-1971" no="1972-1984" no="1985-1997" no="1998-2010" no="2011-2023">
<textC no="1708-1728" no="1729-1749" no="1750-1770" no="1771-1791" no="1792-1812" no="1813-1833" no="1834-1854" no="1855-1875" no="1876-1896" no="1897-1917" no="1918-1938" no="1939-1959" no="1960-1980" no="1981-2001" no="2002-2022">
Last Tuesday considerable Sums of Money were put into the Bank of England, whole Transfer-Books will be shut the 18th Instant, and are not to be open'd again till the 5th of March.
</text>

<text id="256bn115115100119">
<textF no="1703-1709" no="1710-1716" no="1717-1723" no="1724-1730" no="1731-1737" no="1738-1744" no="1745-1751" no="1752-1758" no="1759-1765" no="1766-1772" no="1773-1779" no="1780-1786" no="1787-1793" no="1794-1800" no="1801-1807" no="1808-1814" no="1815-1821" no="1822-1828" no="1829-1835" no="1836-1842" no="1843-1849" no="1850-1856" no="1857-1863" no="1864-1870" no="1871-1877" no="1878-1884" no="1885-1891" no="1892-1898" no="1899-1905" no="1906-1912" no="1913-1919" no="1920-1926" no="1927-1933" no="1934-1940" no="1941-1947" no="1948-1954" no="1955-1961" no="1962-1968" no="1969-1975" no="1976-1982" no="1983-1989" no="1990-1996" no="1997-2003" no="2004-2010" no="2011-2017">
<textM no="1701-1713" no="1714-1726" no="1727-1739" no="1740-1752" no="1753-1765" no="1766-1778" no="1779-1791" no="1792-1804" no="1805-1817" no="1818-1830" no="1831-1843" no="1844-1856" no="1857-1869" no="1870-1882" no="1883-1895" no="1896-1908" no="1909-1921" no="1922-1934" no="1935-1947" no="1948-1960" no="1961-1973" no="1974-1986" no="1987-1999" no="2000-2012" no="2013-2025">
<textC no="1703-1723" no="1724-1744" no="1745-1765" no="1766-1786" no="1787-1807" no="1808-1828" no="1829-1849" no="1850-1870" no="1871-1891" no="1892-1912" no="1913-1933" no="1934-1954" no="1955-1975" no="1976-1996" no="1997-2017">
Big G is a non-poisonous remedy for all wasting weakness, and any inflammation, irritation or ulceration of mucous membranes.Sold by Druggists, or sent in plain wrapper by express, , on receipt of $1,00, or 3 bottles of 12.75. Circular mail on request.
</text>

<text id="972qa97116108101">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">
<textM no="1706-1718" no="1719-1731" no="1732-1744" no="1745-1757" no="1758-1770" no="1771-1783" no="1784-1796" no="1797-1809" no="1810-1822" no="1823-1835" no="1836-1848" no="1849-1861" no="1862-1874" no="1875-1887" no="1888-1900" no="1901-1913" no="1914-1926" no="1927-1939" no="1940-1952" no="1953-1965" no="1966-1978" no="1979-1991" no="1992-2004" no="2005-2017">
<textC no="1708-1728" no="1729-1749" no="1750-1770" no="1771-1791" no="1792-1812" no="1813-1833" no="1834-1854" no="1855-1875" no="1876-1896" no="1897-1917" no="1918-1938" no="1939-1959" no="1960-1980" no="1981-2001" no="2002-2022">
On Monday Mr. Winston Churchill moved the second reading of the Transvaal Loan (Guarantee) Bill in a very long, animated, and provocative speech. He denied that there had been any bribe. The Home Government had simply enabled the Transvaal Government to raise the loan without going to the " defenders of the gilt-edged Union Jack " and pledging themselves to retain Chinese labour. Mr. Lyttelton moved the rejection of the Bill. If there had been no bargain, at any rate the wishes of the Government and of General Botha had been mutually gratified. In conclusion, Mr. Lyttelton severely condemned the Government for failing to avail themselves of the opportunity to negotiate for better treatment of the British Indians and the Civil servants. Mr. Asquith repudiated the charge of a bargain. As to the insinuation that this was a case of unfair Colonial preference, he pointed out that no word of protest had been uttered by any of the other self-governing Colonies.
</text>

<text id="293ts11497101108">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1703-1715" no="1716-1728" no="1729-1741" no="1742-1754" no="1755-1767" no="1768-1780" no="1781-1793" no="1794-1806" no="1807-1819" no="1820-1832" no="1833-1845" no="1846-1858" no="1859-1871" no="1872-1884" no="1885-1897" no="1898-1910" no="1911-1923" no="1924-1936" no="1937-1949" no="1950-1962" no="1963-1975" no="1976-1988" no="1989-2001" no="2002-2014">
<textC no="1699-1719" no="1720-1740" no="1741-1761" no="1762-1782" no="1783-1803" no="1804-1824" no="1825-1845" no="1846-1866" no="1867-1887" no="1888-1908" no="1909-1929" no="1930-1950" no="1951-1971" no="1972-1992" no="1993-2013">
TO THE RIGHT HONORABLE CHARLES LORD HALLIFAX WHEN I first resolved upon doing my self this Honour, I could not but indulge a certain Vanity in dating from this little Covert, where I have frequently had the Honour ofyour Lordship's Company, and received from you very many Obligations.
</text>

<text id="458if1143232108">
<textF no="1703-1709" no="1710-1716" no="1717-1723" no="1724-1730" no="1731-1737" no="1738-1744" no="1745-1751" no="1752-1758" no="1759-1765" no="1766-1772" no="1773-1779" no="1780-1786" no="1787-1793" no="1794-1800" no="1801-1807" no="1808-1814" no="1815-1821" no="1822-1828" no="1829-1835" no="1836-1842" no="1843-1849" no="1850-1856" no="1857-1863" no="1864-1870" no="1871-1877" no="1878-1884" no="1885-1891" no="1892-1898" no="1899-1905" no="1906-1912" no="1913-1919" no="1920-1926" no="1927-1933" no="1934-1940" no="1941-1947" no="1948-1954" no="1955-1961" no="1962-1968" no="1969-1975" no="1976-1982" no="1983-1989" no="1990-1996" no="1997-2003" no="2004-2010" no="2011-2017">
<textM no="1700-1712" no="1713-1725" no="1726-1738" no="1739-1751" no="1752-1764" no="1765-1777" no="1778-1790" no="1791-1803" no="1804-1816" no="1817-1829" no="1830-1842" no="1843-1855" no="1856-1868" no="1869-1881" no="1882-1894" no="1895-1907" no="1908-1920" no="1921-1933" no="1934-1946" no="1947-1959" no="1960-1972" no="1973-1985" no="1986-1998" no="1999-2011" no="2012-2024">
<textC no="1710-1730" no="1731-1751" no="1752-1772" no="1773-1793" no="1794-1814" no="1815-1835" no="1836-1856" no="1857-1877" no="1878-1898" no="1899-1919" no="1920-1940" no="1941-1961" no="1962-1982" no="1983-2003" no="2004-2024">
The track of the Suez canal comprises long straight reaches with curved reaches intervening. The points where two the straight reaches meet are termed angles, and it is at these of angles that the leading lights will be placed whenever possible. They will thus serve for two reaches, but if placed w at other points on the canal where they will only serve for B one reach they will be masked on one side and will only illumine one part of the horizon.
</text>

<text id="729gr10132108100">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1704-1716" no="1717-1729" no="1730-1742" no="1743-1755" no="1756-1768" no="1769-1781" no="1782-1794" no="1795-1807" no="1808-1820" no="1821-1833" no="1834-1846" no="1847-1859" no="1860-1872" no="1873-1885" no="1886-1898" no="1899-1911" no="1912-1924" no="1925-1937" no="1938-1950" no="1951-1963" no="1964-1976" no="1977-1989" no="1990-2002" no="2003-2015">
<textC no="1699-1719" no="1720-1740" no="1741-1761" no="1762-1782" no="1783-1803" no="1804-1824" no="1825-1845" no="1846-1866" no="1867-1887" no="1888-1908" no="1909-1929" no="1930-1950" no="1951-1971" no="1972-1992" no="1993-2013">
SIR,THE Rev. John Candler calls repeatedly the English Bible, " cur own authorized version," upon which I beg leave to observe: 1st. That I have shewn my high respect for the authorityof that -very valuable version by my making frequent use of it as an instrument of criticism, and as I shall continue to, avail myself of it. 2ndly. That there cannot be two opinions on the merit of the English Bible after the very clear and satisfactory account given of it,by Dr; Marsh, in the third part of his Lectures on Divinity. 3rdly. That no version whatever can be compared with the Hebrew originals for authority; and that such is the opinion of the Catholics themselves, every one may be convinced on examining the word Vulgate,
</text>

<text id="197tk3211132116">
<textF no="1704-1710" no="1711-1717" no="1718-1724" no="1725-1731" no="1732-1738" no="1739-1745" no="1746-1752" no="1753-1759" no="1760-1766" no="1767-1773" no="1774-1780" no="1781-1787" no="1788-1794" no="1795-1801" no="1802-1808" no="1809-1815" no="1816-1822" no="1823-1829" no="1830-1836" no="1837-1843" no="1844-1850" no="1851-1857" no="1858-1864" no="1865-1871" no="1872-1878" no="1879-1885" no="1886-1892" no="1893-1899" no="1900-1906" no="1907-1913" no="1914-1920" no="1921-1927" no="1928-1934" no="1935-1941" no="1942-1948" no="1949-1955" no="1956-1962" no="1963-1969" no="1970-1976" no="1977-1983" no="1984-1990" no="1991-1997" no="1998-2004" no="2005-2011" no="2012-2018">
<textM no="1695-1707" no="1708-1720" no="1721-1733" no="1734-1746" no="1747-1759" no="1760-1772" no="1773-1785" no="1786-1798" no="1799-1811" no="1812-1824" no="1825-1837" no="1838-1850" no="1851-1863" no="1864-1876" no="1877-1889" no="1890-1902" no="1903-1915" no="1916-1928" no="1929-1941" no="1942-1954" no="1955-1967" no="1968-1980" no="1981-1993" no="1994-2006" no="2007-2019">
<textC no="1711-1731" no="1732-1752" no="1753-1773" no="1774-1794" no="1795-1815" no="1816-1836" no="1837-1857" no="1858-1878" no="1879-1899" no="1900-1920" no="1921-1941" no="1942-1962" no="1963-1983" no="1984-2004" no="2005-2025">
“ We ought to do the girls credit, Betsy,” she said to her sister. “ Nothing a man of position fears so much as dowdy people-in-law. Old Mrs. Davenport dressed beautifully to the last.”
</text>

<text id="586ke117116116121">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1704-1716" no="1717-1729" no="1730-1742" no="1743-1755" no="1756-1768" no="1769-1781" no="1782-1794" no="1795-1807" no="1808-1820" no="1821-1833" no="1834-1846" no="1847-1859" no="1860-1872" no="1873-1885" no="1886-1898" no="1899-1911" no="1912-1924" no="1925-1937" no="1938-1950" no="1951-1963" no="1964-1976" no="1977-1989" no="1990-2002" no="2003-2015">
<textC no="1706-1726" no="1727-1747" no="1748-1768" no="1769-1789" no="1790-1810" no="1811-1831" no="1832-1852" no="1853-1873" no="1874-1894" no="1895-1915" no="1916-1936" no="1937-1957" no="1958-1978" no="1979-1999" no="2000-2020">
It is further pointed out that, if quarrying must go on, it can be carried out in the rear of the cliff, thus reducing the injury to the river-bank to a minimum; while if the river-bank were bought outright, at the owner's price, " the burden would be scarcely felt by Bristol, and the city would reap untold advantage in the salvation of a strikingly beautiful suburb." Surely the citizens of a city whose fame is " so ancient and so eminent among us" will not let surroundings among the most beautiful possessed by any British town be destroyed rather than find the money required.
</text>

<text id="389en110101111105">
<textF no="1703-1709" no="1710-1716" no="1717-1723" no="1724-1730" no="1731-1737" no="1738-1744" no="1745-1751" no="1752-1758" no="1759-1765" no="1766-1772" no="1773-1779" no="1780-1786" no="1787-1793" no="1794-1800" no="1801-1807" no="1808-1814" no="1815-1821" no="1822-1828" no="1829-1835" no="1836-1842" no="1843-1849" no="1850-1856" no="1857-1863" no="1864-1870" no="1871-1877" no="1878-1884" no="1885-1891" no="1892-1898" no="1899-1905" no="1906-1912" no="1913-1919" no="1920-1926" no="1927-1933" no="1934-1940" no="1941-1947" no="1948-1954" no="1955-1961" no="1962-1968" no="1969-1975" no="1976-1982" no="1983-1989" no="1990-1996" no="1997-2003" no="2004-2010" no="2011-2017">
<textM no="1700-1712" no="1713-1725" no="1726-1738" no="1739-1751" no="1752-1764" no="1765-1777" no="1778-1790" no="1791-1803" no="1804-1816" no="1817-1829" no="1830-1842" no="1843-1855" no="1856-1868" no="1869-1881" no="1882-1894" no="1895-1907" no="1908-1920" no="1921-1933" no="1934-1946" no="1947-1959" no="1960-1972" no="1973-1985" no="1986-1998" no="1999-2011" no="2012-2024">
<textC no="1710-1730" no="1731-1751" no="1752-1772" no="1773-1793" no="1794-1814" no="1815-1835" no="1836-1856" no="1857-1877" no="1878-1898" no="1899-1919" no="1920-1940" no="1941-1961" no="1962-1982" no="1983-2003" no="2004-2024">
Tuyere nozzles have been improved by making them of bronze and fitting them, metal and metal, to the tuyere nose, which prevents them from burning, and allows them to be placed nearer the nose of the tuyere, thereby avoid Ing expansion of blast in the end of the tuyere. Nozzles with spiral grooves, giving a twisting motion to the blast, are used when a Strong penetration is required.
</text>

<text id="573pa971169732">
<textF no="1703-1709" no="1710-1716" no="1717-1723" no="1724-1730" no="1731-1737" no="1738-1744" no="1745-1751" no="1752-1758" no="1759-1765" no="1766-1772" no="1773-1779" no="1780-1786" no="1787-1793" no="1794-1800" no="1801-1807" no="1808-1814" no="1815-1821" no="1822-1828" no="1829-1835" no="1836-1842" no="1843-1849" no="1850-1856" no="1857-1863" no="1864-1870" no="1871-1877" no="1878-1884" no="1885-1891" no="1892-1898" no="1899-1905" no="1906-1912" no="1913-1919" no="1920-1926" no="1927-1933" no="1934-1940" no="1941-1947" no="1948-1954" no="1955-1961" no="1962-1968" no="1969-1975" no="1976-1982" no="1983-1989" no="1990-1996" no="1997-2003" no="2004-2010" no="2011-2017">
<textM no="1700-1712" no="1713-1725" no="1726-1738" no="1739-1751" no="1752-1764" no="1765-1777" no="1778-1790" no="1791-1803" no="1804-1816" no="1817-1829" no="1830-1842" no="1843-1855" no="1856-1868" no="1869-1881" no="1882-1894" no="1895-1907" no="1908-1920" no="1921-1933" no="1934-1946" no="1947-1959" no="1960-1972" no="1973-1985" no="1986-1998" no="1999-2011" no="2012-2024">
<textC no="1696-1716" no="1717-1737" no="1738-1758" no="1759-1779" no="1780-1800" no="1801-1821" no="1822-1842" no="1843-1863" no="1864-1884" no="1885-1905" no="1906-1926" no="1927-1947" no="1948-1968" no="1969-1989" no="1990-2010" no="2011-2031">
Yesterday Morning the Cumberland of this Port,, Matthias Gale Master; arrived here from Virginia: The Master reports, That he came from thence in Company of 200 Sail, under Convoy of Her Majesty's ships the Greenwich, Hazardous, Woolwich, and Advice, Men of War; but was separated from them in, bad Weather near the Banks of Newfoundland about 3 Weeks ago; That Colonel Nott, who was Governor of Virginia, Was dead.but that the Country in general, as also the Fleet, was very healthy. This Day arrived also the Patience of this Place, Paker Ail y Matter, from Virginia.
</text>

<text id="325lp11911597101">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1705-1717" no="1718-1730" no="1731-1743" no="1744-1756" no="1757-1769" no="1770-1782" no="1783-1795" no="1796-1808" no="1809-1821" no="1822-1834" no="1835-1847" no="1848-1860" no="1861-1873" no="1874-1886" no="1887-1899" no="1900-1912" no="1913-1925" no="1926-1938" no="1939-1951" no="1952-1964" no="1965-1977" no="1978-1990" no="1991-2003" no="2004-2016">
<textC no="1706-1726" no="1727-1747" no="1748-1768" no="1769-1789" no="1790-1810" no="1811-1831" no="1832-1852" no="1853-1873" no="1874-1894" no="1895-1915" no="1916-1936" no="1937-1957" no="1958-1978" no="1979-1999" no="2000-2020">
The outward-bound Ships are fail'd. Came down and is fail'd the Three Sifters, Grindall, for Virginia. Arriv'd the Garlintine, Watts, from Guiney and Carolina. Wind N . Deal, Jan. No Ship in the Downs. Came down and sail'd thro', the Monmouth, Cock, for Maryland, and the Elizabeth, Tiowles, for Antigua. Wind N W .
</text>

<text id="299no105101100110">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1707-1719" no="1720-1732" no="1733-1745" no="1746-1758" no="1759-1771" no="1772-1784" no="1785-1797" no="1798-1810" no="1811-1823" no="1824-1836" no="1837-1849" no="1850-1862" no="1863-1875" no="1876-1888" no="1889-1901" no="1902-1914" no="1915-1927" no="1928-1940" no="1941-1953" no="1954-1966" no="1967-1979" no="1980-1992" no="1993-2005" no="2006-2018">
<textC no="1702-1722" no="1723-1743" no="1744-1764" no="1765-1785" no="1786-1806" no="1807-1827" no="1828-1848" no="1849-1869" no="1870-1890" no="1891-1911" no="1912-1932" no="1933-1953" no="1954-1974" no="1975-1995" no="1996-2016">
The Police Committee recommends a penitentiary system for juvenile offenders in the metropolis. But probably a more suitable place may be found at Dartmoor prison, formely occupied by French prisoners; and that, after due trial, employment might be found for them in the Newfoundland fishery, &c.
</text>

<text id="583np10399109108">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1707-1719" no="1720-1732" no="1733-1745" no="1746-1758" no="1759-1771" no="1772-1784" no="1785-1797" no="1798-1810" no="1811-1823" no="1824-1836" no="1837-1849" no="1850-1862" no="1863-1875" no="1876-1888" no="1889-1901" no="1902-1914" no="1915-1927" no="1928-1940" no="1941-1953" no="1954-1966" no="1967-1979" no="1980-1992" no="1993-2005" no="2006-2018">
<textC no="1702-1722" no="1723-1743" no="1744-1764" no="1765-1785" no="1786-1806" no="1807-1827" no="1828-1848" no="1849-1869" no="1870-1890" no="1891-1911" no="1912-1932" no="1933-1953" no="1954-1974" no="1975-1995" no="1996-2016">
I have given an account of some new results on flame, which show that the intensity of the light of flames depends principally upon the production and ignition of solid matter in combustion, and that the heat andlight in this process are in a great measure independent phenomena. Since this notice has been printed, I have made a number of researches on flame : and as they appear to me to throw some new lights on this important subject, and to lead to some practical views connected with the useful arts, I shall, without any farther apology,present them to the Royal Society.
</text>

<text id="431le321109732">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">
<textM no="1705-1717" no="1718-1730" no="1731-1743" no="1744-1756" no="1757-1769" no="1770-1782" no="1783-1795" no="1796-1808" no="1809-1821" no="1822-1834" no="1835-1847" no="1848-1860" no="1861-1873" no="1874-1886" no="1887-1899" no="1900-1912" no="1913-1925" no="1926-1938" no="1939-1951" no="1952-1964" no="1965-1977" no="1978-1990" no="1991-2003" no="2004-2016">
<textC no="1694-1714" no="1715-1735" no="1736-1756" no="1757-1777" no="1778-1798" no="1799-1819" no="1820-1840" no="1841-1861" no="1862-1882" no="1883-1903" no="1904-1924" no="1925-1945" no="1946-1966" no="1967-1987" no="1988-2008" no="2009-2029">
Perhaps there is one point that needs to be borne in mind. Whatever this Parliament may do, and I hope it will pass a ' Welsh Disestablishment through the Commons, itis certain that the final decision will not be taken until there has been a General Election. As a preparation for that we must have an honest Registration Bill. The time spent in passing that would be a gain for every reform, Disestablishment among the number.
</text>

<text id="471jp1053211799">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1707-1719" no="1720-1732" no="1733-1745" no="1746-1758" no="1759-1771" no="1772-1784" no="1785-1797" no="1798-1810" no="1811-1823" no="1824-1836" no="1837-1849" no="1850-1862" no="1863-1875" no="1876-1888" no="1889-1901" no="1902-1914" no="1915-1927" no="1928-1940" no="1941-1953" no="1954-1966" no="1967-1979" no="1980-1992" no="1993-2005" no="2006-2018">
<textC no="1702-1722" no="1723-1743" no="1744-1764" no="1765-1785" no="1786-1806" no="1807-1827" no="1828-1848" no="1849-1869" no="1870-1890" no="1891-1911" no="1912-1932" no="1933-1953" no="1954-1974" no="1975-1995" no="1996-2016">
The ANTI-CALLOSITY or CORNS BUNIONS and CHIRLAINS however bad or of long standing effectually CURED not by the usual mode of cutting the Corn or bunnion which is always attended with extreme danger but by gradually dispersing the eallous substance and relieving those exquisitely painful throbbings felt at every change of the weather. the application is perfectly easy which is only placing the plaster and playing it on the Corn when it will produce immediate ease.
</text>

<text id="352ic329732119">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">
<textM no="1704-1716" no="1717-1729" no="1730-1742" no="1743-1755" no="1756-1768" no="1769-1781" no="1782-1794" no="1795-1807" no="1808-1820" no="1821-1833" no="1834-1846" no="1847-1859" no="1860-1872" no="1873-1885" no="1886-1898" no="1899-1911" no="1912-1924" no="1925-1937" no="1938-1950" no="1951-1963" no="1964-1976" no="1977-1989" no="1990-2002" no="2003-2015">
<textC no="1701-1721" no="1722-1742" no="1743-1763" no="1764-1784" no="1785-1805" no="1806-1826" no="1827-1847" no="1848-1868" no="1869-1889" no="1890-1910" no="1911-1931" no="1932-1952" no="1953-1973" no="1974-1994" no="1995-2015">
exhibit a considerable number of band-sawing machines, of which the most noticeable was a new implement, in two sizes, for cutting timber at any bevil or angle. This is effected in this machine by the table sliding, so as to vary the angle of the saw, whilst the table still remains horizontal, which is a great convenience in handling the material.
</text>

<text id="327bo11197101112">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1696-1708" no="1709-1721" no="1722-1734" no="1735-1747" no="1748-1760" no="1761-1773" no="1774-1786" no="1787-1799" no="1800-1812" no="1813-1825" no="1826-1838" no="1839-1851" no="1852-1864" no="1865-1877" no="1878-1890" no="1891-1903" no="1904-1916" no="1917-1929" no="1930-1942" no="1943-1955" no="1956-1968" no="1969-1981" no="1982-1994" no="1995-2007" no="2008-2020">
<textC no="1709-1729" no="1730-1750" no="1751-1771" no="1772-1792" no="1793-1813" no="1814-1834" no="1835-1855" no="1856-1876" no="1877-1897" no="1898-1918" no="1919-1939" no="1940-1960" no="1961-1981" no="1982-2002" no="2003-2023">
The Portuguese had armed themselves especially for the protection and vindication of the Constitution, and for the restriction of the royal authority within a reasonable and legal limits. Heartily do we confess that s we have not the inclination to analyse either the language s or the sentiments of this odious manifesto.
</text>

<text id="177qm323244105">
<textF no="1700-1706" no="1707-1713" no="1714-1720" no="1721-1727" no="1728-1734" no="1735-1741" no="1742-1748" no="1749-1755" no="1756-1762" no="1763-1769" no="1770-1776" no="1777-1783" no="1784-1790" no="1791-1797" no="1798-1804" no="1805-1811" no="1812-1818" no="1819-1825" no="1826-1832" no="1833-1839" no="1840-1846" no="1847-1853" no="1854-1860" no="1861-1867" no="1868-1874" no="1875-1881" no="1882-1888" no="1889-1895" no="1896-1902" no="1903-1909" no="1910-1916" no="1917-1923" no="1924-1930" no="1931-1937" no="1938-1944" no="1945-1951" no="1952-1958" no="1959-1965" no="1966-1972" no="1973-1979" no="1980-1986" no="1987-1993" no="1994-2000" no="2001-2007" no="2008-2014">
<textM no="1704-1716" no="1717-1729" no="1730-1742" no="1743-1755" no="1756-1768" no="1769-1781" no="1782-1794" no="1795-1807" no="1808-1820" no="1821-1833" no="1834-1846" no="1847-1859" no="1860-1872" no="1873-1885" no="1886-1898" no="1899-1911" no="1912-1924" no="1925-1937" no="1938-1950" no="1951-1963" no="1964-1976" no="1977-1989" no="1990-2002" no="2003-2015">
<textC no="1700-1720" no="1721-1741" no="1742-1762" no="1763-1783" no="1784-1804" no="1805-1825" no="1826-1846" no="1847-1867" no="1868-1888" no="1889-1909" no="1910-1930" no="1931-1951" no="1952-1972" no="1973-1993" no="1994-2014">
WHereas for some Years past, and at this Time also, a very malicious Report is industriously spread, That Mrs. Bell in the College-Green in Worcester is leaving her School.
</text>

<text id="286jg10111032114">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1707-1719" no="1720-1732" no="1733-1745" no="1746-1758" no="1759-1771" no="1772-1784" no="1785-1797" no="1798-1810" no="1811-1823" no="1824-1836" no="1837-1849" no="1850-1862" no="1863-1875" no="1876-1888" no="1889-1901" no="1902-1914" no="1915-1927" no="1928-1940" no="1941-1953" no="1954-1966" no="1967-1979" no="1980-1992" no="1993-2005" no="2006-2018">
<textC no="1702-1722" no="1723-1743" no="1744-1764" no="1765-1785" no="1786-1806" no="1807-1827" no="1828-1848" no="1849-1869" no="1870-1890" no="1891-1911" no="1912-1932" no="1933-1953" no="1954-1974" no="1975-1995" no="1996-2016">
TO AMATEURS in TURNING. To be Sold, a TURNING LATHE complete,with the appurtenances for ornamental and plain Turning; the whole is the property ofa Gentleman who is going for some time on the Continent, and may be seen at the tool manufactory, 10, Cockspur-strcet; price 35 guineas.
</text>

<text id="260om1121113299">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1697-1709" no="1710-1722" no="1723-1735" no="1736-1748" no="1749-1761" no="1762-1774" no="1775-1787" no="1788-1800" no="1801-1813" no="1814-1826" no="1827-1839" no="1840-1852" no="1853-1865" no="1866-1878" no="1879-1891" no="1892-1904" no="1905-1917" no="1918-1930" no="1931-1943" no="1944-1956" no="1957-1969" no="1970-1982" no="1983-1995" no="1996-2008" no="2009-2021">
<textC no="1706-1726" no="1727-1747" no="1748-1768" no="1769-1789" no="1790-1810" no="1811-1831" no="1832-1852" no="1853-1873" no="1874-1894" no="1895-1915" no="1916-1936" no="1937-1957" no="1958-1978" no="1979-1999" no="2000-2020">
That Upon the Importation of Senn, (which is a Drug used in Medicine, anti not in the Dying Trade) the same be charg'd. with the respective Duties payable to his Majesty as a Medicinal Drug, without being exempted under the Notion of a Drug us'd in Dying.
</text>

<text id="349ee10132108105">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">
<textM no="1707-1719" no="1720-1732" no="1733-1745" no="1746-1758" no="1759-1771" no="1772-1784" no="1785-1797" no="1798-1810" no="1811-1823" no="1824-1836" no="1837-1849" no="1850-1862" no="1863-1875" no="1876-1888" no="1889-1901" no="1902-1914" no="1915-1927" no="1928-1940" no="1941-1953" no="1954-1966" no="1967-1979" no="1980-1992" no="1993-2005" no="2006-2018">
<textC no="1708-1728" no="1729-1749" no="1750-1770" no="1771-1791" no="1792-1812" no="1813-1833" no="1834-1854" no="1855-1875" no="1876-1896" no="1897-1917" no="1918-1938" no="1939-1959" no="1960-1980" no="1981-2001" no="2002-2022">
Last Week the Ship of Mark Allan, belonging to York, laden with Salt and Coals from this Port, was lost some Leagues to the North of Scarborough, but-the Crew were sav'd. Also the Ship of Thomas Girdler of the same Place, laden with Wood for Sunderland, was lost some Days before betwixt Burlington and Scarborough but none of the Crew perished.
</text>

<text id="516cg100111110101">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">
<textM no="1700-1712" no="1713-1725" no="1726-1738" no="1739-1751" no="1752-1764" no="1765-1777" no="1778-1790" no="1791-1803" no="1804-1816" no="1817-1829" no="1830-1842" no="1843-1855" no="1856-1868" no="1869-1881" no="1882-1894" no="1895-1907" no="1908-1920" no="1921-1933" no="1934-1946" no="1947-1959" no="1960-1972" no="1973-1985" no="1986-1998" no="1999-2011" no="2012-2024">
<textC no="1701-1721" no="1722-1742" no="1743-1763" no="1764-1784" no="1785-1805" no="1806-1826" no="1827-1847" no="1848-1868" no="1869-1889" no="1890-1910" no="1911-1931" no="1932-1952" no="1953-1973" no="1974-1994" no="1995-2015">
It would be dangerous to begin to raise even the Taxes we now pay by the Method of Excise, both because it would be a bad Precedent, and because of the Uncertainty of the Produce : If the railing them by Excise should produce lest than they now do, they could not answer those Payments for which they are appointed ; and if it raised more, it might considering the present Establishment of the Civil Lift throw more Money into the Hands of the Crown, than would be consistent with the Freedom of the People.
</text>

<text id="337te32103111114">
<textF no="1703-1709" no="1710-1716" no="1717-1723" no="1724-1730" no="1731-1737" no="1738-1744" no="1745-1751" no="1752-1758" no="1759-1765" no="1766-1772" no="1773-1779" no="1780-1786" no="1787-1793" no="1794-1800" no="1801-1807" no="1808-1814" no="1815-1821" no="1822-1828" no="1829-1835" no="1836-1842" no="1843-1849" no="1850-1856" no="1857-1863" no="1864-1870" no="1871-1877" no="1878-1884" no="1885-1891" no="1892-1898" no="1899-1905" no="1906-1912" no="1913-1919" no="1920-1926" no="1927-1933" no="1934-1940" no="1941-1947" no="1948-1954" no="1955-1961" no="1962-1968" no="1969-1975" no="1976-1982" no="1983-1989" no="1990-1996" no="1997-2003" no="2004-2010" no="2011-2017">
<textM no="1702-1714" no="1715-1727" no="1728-1740" no="1741-1753" no="1754-1766" no="1767-1779" no="1780-1792" no="1793-1805" no="1806-1818" no="1819-1831" no="1832-1844" no="1845-1857" no="1858-1870" no="1871-1883" no="1884-1896" no="1897-1909" no="1910-1922" no="1923-1935" no="1936-1948" no="1949-1961" no="1962-1974" no="1975-1987" no="1988-2000" no="2001-2013">
<textC no="1703-1723" no="1724-1744" no="1745-1765" no="1766-1786" no="1787-1807" no="1808-1828" no="1829-1849" no="1850-1870" no="1871-1891" no="1892-1912" no="1913-1933" no="1934-1954" no="1955-1975" no="1976-1996" no="1997-2017">
Containing all sort ofNursery Fruit Trees Ever Green Eglish and Dutch Elms Standards of all Sizes likewise for Hedge Limes Oak Orbeils Horse Chestnuts English Chestnuts fine Yews for Hedges Scoth Firs. Any Gentleman that will come or send may be further satisfied for the Stock will be dispos'd of at a very reasonable Rate.
</text>

<text id="237mk117101101105">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1707-1719" no="1720-1732" no="1733-1745" no="1746-1758" no="1759-1771" no="1772-1784" no="1785-1797" no="1798-1810" no="1811-1823" no="1824-1836" no="1837-1849" no="1850-1862" no="1863-1875" no="1876-1888" no="1889-1901" no="1902-1914" no="1915-1927" no="1928-1940" no="1941-1953" no="1954-1966" no="1967-1979" no="1980-1992" no="1993-2005" no="2006-2018">
<textC no="1699-1719" no="1720-1740" no="1741-1761" no="1762-1782" no="1783-1803" no="1804-1824" no="1825-1845" no="1846-1866" no="1867-1887" no="1888-1908" no="1909-1929" no="1930-1950" no="1951-1971" no="1972-1992" no="1993-2013">
Unfortunately like every other description of "self acting" mechanism these points are liable to get liable to get out of order. assuming them to be in efficient working order would render unnecessary the attendance of a "switchman".
</text>

<text id="780fo110116100101">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1705-1717" no="1718-1730" no="1731-1743" no="1744-1756" no="1757-1769" no="1770-1782" no="1783-1795" no="1796-1808" no="1809-1821" no="1822-1834" no="1835-1847" no="1848-1860" no="1861-1873" no="1874-1886" no="1887-1899" no="1900-1912" no="1913-1925" no="1926-1938" no="1939-1951" no="1952-1964" no="1965-1977" no="1978-1990" no="1991-2003" no="2004-2016">
<textC no="1692-1712" no="1713-1733" no="1734-1754" no="1755-1775" no="1776-1796" no="1797-1817" no="1818-1838" no="1839-1859" no="1860-1880" no="1881-1901" no="1902-1922" no="1923-1943" no="1944-1964" no="1965-1985" no="1986-2006" no="2007-2027">
A German Paper states that a Dr. Von Mayerly has lately invented a pair of boots made of block tin, and surrounded by a hollow body, by means of which he can pass over the most rapid river, lie has lately exhibited his contrivance at Pest, at which place he walked upwards of 500 fathoms in the Danube, where it is very rapid and deep, in the presence of a great number of spectators."—The above paragraph has made the round of all the papers during the last month, but we confess we do not understand it.a long article to prove its absurdity, inasmuch as, in order to enable the wearer of these boots to keep his equilibrium on the water, they must be edged with a ruff, which, when one of his legs is out of the water, would totally prevent his raising the other.—Globe.
</text>

<text id="341cc10199110115">
<textF no="1700-1706" no="1707-1713" no="1714-1720" no="1721-1727" no="1728-1734" no="1735-1741" no="1742-1748" no="1749-1755" no="1756-1762" no="1763-1769" no="1770-1776" no="1777-1783" no="1784-1790" no="1791-1797" no="1798-1804" no="1805-1811" no="1812-1818" no="1819-1825" no="1826-1832" no="1833-1839" no="1840-1846" no="1847-1853" no="1854-1860" no="1861-1867" no="1868-1874" no="1875-1881" no="1882-1888" no="1889-1895" no="1896-1902" no="1903-1909" no="1910-1916" no="1917-1923" no="1924-1930" no="1931-1937" no="1938-1944" no="1945-1951" no="1952-1958" no="1959-1965" no="1966-1972" no="1973-1979" no="1980-1986" no="1987-1993" no="1994-2000" no="2001-2007" no="2008-2014">
<textM no="1704-1716" no="1717-1729" no="1730-1742" no="1743-1755" no="1756-1768" no="1769-1781" no="1782-1794" no="1795-1807" no="1808-1820" no="1821-1833" no="1834-1846" no="1847-1859" no="1860-1872" no="1873-1885" no="1886-1898" no="1899-1911" no="1912-1924" no="1925-1937" no="1938-1950" no="1951-1963" no="1964-1976" no="1977-1989" no="1990-2002" no="2003-2015">
<textC no="1700-1720" no="1721-1741" no="1742-1762" no="1763-1783" no="1784-1804" no="1805-1825" no="1826-1846" no="1847-1867" no="1868-1888" no="1889-1909" no="1910-1930" no="1931-1951" no="1952-1972" no="1973-1993" no="1994-2014">
If these Menhave committed any Robberies, or done any other Thing contrary to Law, it is desired that Notice thereof be given within a reasonable Time to Mr. Mace in York, Clerk of the Peace forthe East Riding of Yorkshire, or else these Men will be discharged, being as yet only committed for want of Sureties for their good Behaviour.
</text>

<text id="141bq32111100100">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">
<textM no="1699-1711" no="1712-1724" no="1725-1737" no="1738-1750" no="1751-1763" no="1764-1776" no="1777-1789" no="1790-1802" no="1803-1815" no="1816-1828" no="1829-1841" no="1842-1854" no="1855-1867" no="1868-1880" no="1881-1893" no="1894-1906" no="1907-1919" no="1920-1932" no="1933-1945" no="1946-1958" no="1959-1971" no="1972-1984" no="1985-1997" no="1998-2010" no="2011-2023">
<textC no="1708-1728" no="1729-1749" no="1750-1770" no="1771-1791" no="1792-1812" no="1813-1833" no="1834-1854" no="1855-1875" no="1876-1896" no="1897-1917" no="1918-1938" no="1939-1959" no="1960-1980" no="1981-2001" no="2002-2022">
We hear the Lord Forbes is made a Rear Admiral and that he will Command a Squadron in the Mediterranean which is to carry Imperial Colours
</text>

<text id="714th3211711432">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1704-1716" no="1717-1729" no="1730-1742" no="1743-1755" no="1756-1768" no="1769-1781" no="1782-1794" no="1795-1807" no="1808-1820" no="1821-1833" no="1834-1846" no="1847-1859" no="1860-1872" no="1873-1885" no="1886-1898" no="1899-1911" no="1912-1924" no="1925-1937" no="1938-1950" no="1951-1963" no="1964-1976" no="1977-1989" no="1990-2002" no="2003-2015">
<textC no="1706-1726" no="1727-1747" no="1748-1768" no="1769-1789" no="1790-1810" no="1811-1831" no="1832-1852" no="1853-1873" no="1874-1894" no="1895-1915" no="1916-1936" no="1937-1957" no="1958-1978" no="1979-1999" no="2000-2020">
it must not be assumed that great events are not being planned or in process of being carried out. Remember, there are now no war correspondents with the Japanese forces, and none that are audible with the Russians, and thus we only obtain the official despatches. Of this, however, we may be sure, that the Japanese will not for ever stand idle before the Russian lines. Meantime, according to a telegram from St. Petersburg in Friday's Express," the Russian Government is at last face to face with the greatest crisis of the war," in the shape of the fact that the Siberian Railway is no longer capable of meeting the demands made upon it, and that therefore the army in Manchuria is in danger of starvation.
</text>

<text id="421la994632101">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1707-1719" no="1720-1732" no="1733-1745" no="1746-1758" no="1759-1771" no="1772-1784" no="1785-1797" no="1798-1810" no="1811-1823" no="1824-1836" no="1837-1849" no="1850-1862" no="1863-1875" no="1876-1888" no="1889-1901" no="1902-1914" no="1915-1927" no="1928-1940" no="1941-1953" no="1954-1966" no="1967-1979" no="1980-1992" no="1993-2005" no="2006-2018">
<textC no="1702-1722" no="1723-1743" no="1744-1764" no="1765-1785" no="1786-1806" no="1807-1827" no="1828-1848" no="1849-1869" no="1870-1890" no="1891-1911" no="1912-1932" no="1933-1953" no="1954-1974" no="1975-1995" no="1996-2016">
WATCHES— J.P.ACKLAM has now on sale several hundreds, both new and second-hand, of every description from two to fifty guineas each, which he strenuously recommends to those in want of a good watch, The particular attention he always exerts in the selection of the best workman- ship enables him to offer to purchasers the advantage;Watches taken in exchange or purchased, 423, Strand, corner of Redford-street.
</text>

<text id="142sl117111116108">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">

<textC no="1708-1728" no="1729-1749" no="1750-1770" no="1771-1791" no="1792-1812" no="1813-1833" no="1834-1854" no="1855-1875" no="1876-1896" no="1897-1917" no="1918-1938" no="1939-1959" no="1960-1980" no="1981-2001" no="2002-2022">
JOHN STUART MILL for WESTMINSTER . A PUBLIC MEETING of the parishioners favourable to the Return of Mr. Mill will be held polygraphic hall.
</text>

<text id="707hk9711110813">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">
<textM no="1704-1716" no="1717-1729" no="1730-1742" no="1743-1755" no="1756-1768" no="1769-1781" no="1782-1794" no="1795-1807" no="1808-1820" no="1821-1833" no="1834-1846" no="1847-1859" no="1860-1872" no="1873-1885" no="1886-1898" no="1899-1911" no="1912-1924" no="1925-1937" no="1938-1950" no="1951-1963" no="1964-1976" no="1977-1989" no="1990-2002" no="2003-2015">
<textC no="1701-1721" no="1722-1742" no="1743-1763" no="1764-1784" no="1785-1805" no="1806-1826" no="1827-1847" no="1848-1868" no="1869-1889" no="1890-1910" no="1911-1931" no="1932-1952" no="1953-1973" no="1974-1994" no="1995-2015">
LORD BEACONSFIELD ON TECHNICAL EDUCATION There are many Instances also in this exhibition which, Were it not too long, would illustrate the point which I wish to place before you. But there is one point of great importance Which must be impressed upon your attention more and more as you advance in this proceeding, and that is the necessity of cultivating technical skill. Now, it is very curious in this exhibition, where you would expect that the vast majority of tHe articles exhibited would be of a mechanical kind, that although this exhibition is rich in articles of a mechanical kind—I think between 500 and 600 are under this roof—still, those of an artistic character equal them in number.
</text>

<text id="283gf3211632114">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">
<textM no="1699-1711" no="1712-1724" no="1725-1737" no="1738-1750" no="1751-1763" no="1764-1776" no="1777-1789" no="1790-1802" no="1803-1815" no="1816-1828" no="1829-1841" no="1842-1854" no="1855-1867" no="1868-1880" no="1881-1893" no="1894-1906" no="1907-1919" no="1920-1932" no="1933-1945" no="1946-1958" no="1959-1971" no="1972-1984" no="1985-1997" no="1998-2010" no="2011-2023">
<textC no="1708-1728" no="1729-1749" no="1750-1770" no="1771-1791" no="1792-1812" no="1813-1833" no="1834-1854" no="1855-1875" no="1876-1896" no="1897-1917" no="1918-1938" no="1939-1959" no="1960-1980" no="1981-2001" no="2002-2022">
'Tis is confirm'd that Orders are come from Madrid to all Ports of Spain to seize all the Shipping of whatsoever Nation, till two hundred Transports are ready to take on board som e thousands of Men more with great Magazines of Provisions and Forage design'd for the Army in Italy
</text>

<text id="940rq110108111112">
<textF no="1700-1706" no="1707-1713" no="1714-1720" no="1721-1727" no="1728-1734" no="1735-1741" no="1742-1748" no="1749-1755" no="1756-1762" no="1763-1769" no="1770-1776" no="1777-1783" no="1784-1790" no="1791-1797" no="1798-1804" no="1805-1811" no="1812-1818" no="1819-1825" no="1826-1832" no="1833-1839" no="1840-1846" no="1847-1853" no="1854-1860" no="1861-1867" no="1868-1874" no="1875-1881" no="1882-1888" no="1889-1895" no="1896-1902" no="1903-1909" no="1910-1916" no="1917-1923" no="1924-1930" no="1931-1937" no="1938-1944" no="1945-1951" no="1952-1958" no="1959-1965" no="1966-1972" no="1973-1979" no="1980-1986" no="1987-1993" no="1994-2000" no="2001-2007" no="2008-2014">
<textM no="1700-1712" no="1713-1725" no="1726-1738" no="1739-1751" no="1752-1764" no="1765-1777" no="1778-1790" no="1791-1803" no="1804-1816" no="1817-1829" no="1830-1842" no="1843-1855" no="1856-1868" no="1869-1881" no="1882-1894" no="1895-1907" no="1908-1920" no="1921-1933" no="1934-1946" no="1947-1959" no="1960-1972" no="1973-1985" no="1986-1998" no="1999-2011" no="2012-2024">
<textC no="1700-1720" no="1721-1741" no="1742-1762" no="1763-1783" no="1784-1804" no="1805-1825" no="1826-1846" no="1847-1867" no="1868-1888" no="1889-1909" no="1910-1930" no="1931-1951" no="1952-1972" no="1973-1993" no="1994-2014">
placing the muzzle in his mouth, attempted to blow out his brains. The ball, however, passed through the lower jaw, and lodged in the roof of his mouth. So determined was the wretched man upon committing suicide, that finding the work of self-destruction un- accomplished by his first attempt the seized a knife and plunged it into his abdomen. The wound thus inflicted not having instantly deprived him of life, he endeavoured to throw himself on the point of his sword, which bent under the weight of his body. At this moment the adjutant of the regiment rushed, into the apartment, accompanied by the guard, and the former having struck Several with the flat of his sabre on the wrist the assassin dropped his weapon, and was immediately secured.	He was then taken to the hospital with three of bis victims. The officers wounded are eight in number, exclusive of the frantic perpetrator of the horrible acts which we have detailed.	
</text>

<text id="300cs1143211944">
<textF no="1704-1710" no="1711-1717" no="1718-1724" no="1725-1731" no="1732-1738" no="1739-1745" no="1746-1752" no="1753-1759" no="1760-1766" no="1767-1773" no="1774-1780" no="1781-1787" no="1788-1794" no="1795-1801" no="1802-1808" no="1809-1815" no="1816-1822" no="1823-1829" no="1830-1836" no="1837-1843" no="1844-1850" no="1851-1857" no="1858-1864" no="1865-1871" no="1872-1878" no="1879-1885" no="1886-1892" no="1893-1899" no="1900-1906" no="1907-1913" no="1914-1920" no="1921-1927" no="1928-1934" no="1935-1941" no="1942-1948" no="1949-1955" no="1956-1962" no="1963-1969" no="1970-1976" no="1977-1983" no="1984-1990" no="1991-1997" no="1998-2004" no="2005-2011" no="2012-2018">
<textM no="1695-1707" no="1708-1720" no="1721-1733" no="1734-1746" no="1747-1759" no="1760-1772" no="1773-1785" no="1786-1798" no="1799-1811" no="1812-1824" no="1825-1837" no="1838-1850" no="1851-1863" no="1864-1876" no="1877-1889" no="1890-1902" no="1903-1915" no="1916-1928" no="1929-1941" no="1942-1954" no="1955-1967" no="1968-1980" no="1981-1993" no="1994-2006" no="2007-2019">
<textC no="1704-1724" no="1725-1745" no="1746-1766" no="1767-1787" no="1788-1808" no="1809-1829" no="1830-1850" no="1851-1871" no="1872-1892" no="1893-1913" no="1914-1934" no="1935-1955" no="1956-1976" no="1977-1997" no="1998-2018">
There are only all about the Walls Cocks, from which there comes. Water according to the several Degrees of Heat that is requisite. Those Waters are naturally hot, and come from a spring about a quarter of a League from the City. and they affirm this Water is a sovereign Remedy for Rheumatisms.
</text>

<text id="340sa10432111115">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">
<textM no="1707-1719" no="1720-1732" no="1733-1745" no="1746-1758" no="1759-1771" no="1772-1784" no="1785-1797" no="1798-1810" no="1811-1823" no="1824-1836" no="1837-1849" no="1850-1862" no="1863-1875" no="1876-1888" no="1889-1901" no="1902-1914" no="1915-1927" no="1928-1940" no="1941-1953" no="1954-1966" no="1967-1979" no="1980-1992" no="1993-2005" no="2006-2018">
<textC no="1708-1728" no="1729-1749" no="1750-1770" no="1771-1791" no="1792-1812" no="1813-1833" no="1834-1854" no="1855-1875" no="1876-1896" no="1897-1917" no="1918-1938" no="1939-1959" no="1960-1980" no="1981-2001" no="2002-2022">
THE COMPLEAT HOUSEWIFE Or Accomplish'd Gentlewoman's Companion Being a Collection of upwards of six Hundred of the most approv'd Receipts in COOKERY PASTRY PICKLES With copper Plates curiously engraven for the regular Disposition of placing the various Dishes and Courses. And also Bills of Fare for every Month in the Year.
</text>

<text id="199go3211610532">
<textF no="1700-1706" no="1707-1713" no="1714-1720" no="1721-1727" no="1728-1734" no="1735-1741" no="1742-1748" no="1749-1755" no="1756-1762" no="1763-1769" no="1770-1776" no="1777-1783" no="1784-1790" no="1791-1797" no="1798-1804" no="1805-1811" no="1812-1818" no="1819-1825" no="1826-1832" no="1833-1839" no="1840-1846" no="1847-1853" no="1854-1860" no="1861-1867" no="1868-1874" no="1875-1881" no="1882-1888" no="1889-1895" no="1896-1902" no="1903-1909" no="1910-1916" no="1917-1923" no="1924-1930" no="1931-1937" no="1938-1944" no="1945-1951" no="1952-1958" no="1959-1965" no="1966-1972" no="1973-1979" no="1980-1986" no="1987-1993" no="1994-2000" no="2001-2007" no="2008-2014">
<textM no="1698-1710" no="1711-1723" no="1724-1736" no="1737-1749" no="1750-1762" no="1763-1775" no="1776-1788" no="1789-1801" no="1802-1814" no="1815-1827" no="1828-1840" no="1841-1853" no="1854-1866" no="1867-1879" no="1880-1892" no="1893-1905" no="1906-1918" no="1919-1931" no="1932-1944" no="1945-1957" no="1958-1970" no="1971-1983" no="1984-1996" no="1997-2009" no="2010-2022">
<textC no="1707-1727" no="1728-1748" no="1749-1769" no="1770-1790" no="1791-1811" no="1812-1832" no="1833-1853" no="1854-1874" no="1875-1895" no="1896-1916" no="1917-1937" no="1938-1958" no="1959-1979" no="1980-2000" no="2001-2021">
trading to the East Indies, viz Bombay Stuff;, 700 Pieces Carmeia Wool , 5600 l b . Coffee , lb Pepper , 348000 lb . besides several Parcels of Goods,, the Particulars where of are not known.
</text>

<text id="299rd11132104100">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1696-1708" no="1709-1721" no="1722-1734" no="1735-1747" no="1748-1760" no="1761-1773" no="1774-1786" no="1787-1799" no="1800-1812" no="1813-1825" no="1826-1838" no="1839-1851" no="1852-1864" no="1865-1877" no="1878-1890" no="1891-1903" no="1904-1916" no="1917-1929" no="1930-1942" no="1943-1955" no="1956-1968" no="1969-1981" no="1982-1994" no="1995-2007" no="2008-2020">
<textC no="1709-1729" no="1730-1750" no="1751-1771" no="1772-1792" no="1793-1813" no="1814-1834" no="1835-1855" no="1856-1876" no="1877-1897" no="1898-1918" no="1919-1939" no="1940-1960" no="1961-1981" no="1982-2002" no="2003-2023">
Mr. Baron Alderson told her that it would be better that he should have medical testimony in future. The duty of a Coroner's Jury was to ascertain the cause of death. Her account of the transaction was that the deceased was uneasy during the night and that she had a fit and called out Murderer
</text>

<text id="70cq101105110108">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">
<textM no="1699-1711" no="1712-1724" no="1725-1737" no="1738-1750" no="1751-1763" no="1764-1776" no="1777-1789" no="1790-1802" no="1803-1815" no="1816-1828" no="1829-1841" no="1842-1854" no="1855-1867" no="1868-1880" no="1881-1893" no="1894-1906" no="1907-1919" no="1920-1932" no="1933-1945" no="1946-1958" no="1959-1971" no="1972-1984" no="1985-1997" no="1998-2010" no="2011-2023">
<textC no="1708-1728" no="1729-1749" no="1750-1770" no="1771-1791" no="1792-1812" no="1813-1833" no="1834-1854" no="1855-1875" no="1876-1896" no="1897-1917" no="1918-1938" no="1939-1959" no="1960-1980" no="1981-2001" no="2002-2022">
to be kept in Publick House in Eccleshall from the Time of Entrance
</text>

<text id="553ho116115115116">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1707-1719" no="1720-1732" no="1733-1745" no="1746-1758" no="1759-1771" no="1772-1784" no="1785-1797" no="1798-1810" no="1811-1823" no="1824-1836" no="1837-1849" no="1850-1862" no="1863-1875" no="1876-1888" no="1889-1901" no="1902-1914" no="1915-1927" no="1928-1940" no="1941-1953" no="1954-1966" no="1967-1979" no="1980-1992" no="1993-2005" no="2006-2018">
<textC no="1702-1722" no="1723-1743" no="1744-1764" no="1765-1785" no="1786-1806" no="1807-1827" no="1828-1848" no="1849-1869" no="1870-1890" no="1891-1911" no="1912-1932" no="1933-1953" no="1954-1974" no="1975-1995" no="1996-2016">
During the progress of the distillation the liquor in the retort became turbid, especially towards the end, and it collected into a white matter, rather divided, which did not appear to be albumen. The evaporation of this liquor, with its sediment, was accomplished in a small porcelain capsula, and there remained a residuum, tolerably dry, of a pale yellow, slightly attracting	the	moisture,	and	weighing	1 g.	2 8 : it was treated with a small quantity of warm water, to give it the consistence of a syrup, and then some alcohol was poured into it;
</text>

<text id="296ao11432105101">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1702-1714" no="1715-1727" no="1728-1740" no="1741-1753" no="1754-1766" no="1767-1779" no="1780-1792" no="1793-1805" no="1806-1818" no="1819-1831" no="1832-1844" no="1845-1857" no="1858-1870" no="1871-1883" no="1884-1896" no="1897-1909" no="1910-1922" no="1923-1935" no="1936-1948" no="1949-1961" no="1962-1974" no="1975-1987" no="1988-2000" no="2001-2013">
<textC no="1702-1722" no="1723-1743" no="1744-1764" no="1765-1785" no="1786-1806" no="1807-1827" no="1828-1848" no="1849-1869" no="1870-1890" no="1891-1911" no="1912-1932" no="1933-1953" no="1954-1974" no="1975-1995" no="1996-2016">
A letter, dated on the 25th, in reference to the state of Upper Canada, observes The rebels have been completely dispersed in all parts of this province We have no apprehensions here, but that the faction will be dispersed by the forces to be brought against them by our excellent Governor.
</text>

<text id="527mq11110446110">
<textF no="1698-1704" no="1705-1711" no="1712-1718" no="1719-1725" no="1726-1732" no="1733-1739" no="1740-1746" no="1747-1753" no="1754-1760" no="1761-1767" no="1768-1774" no="1775-1781" no="1782-1788" no="1789-1795" no="1796-1802" no="1803-1809" no="1810-1816" no="1817-1823" no="1824-1830" no="1831-1837" no="1838-1844" no="1845-1851" no="1852-1858" no="1859-1865" no="1866-1872" no="1873-1879" no="1880-1886" no="1887-1893" no="1894-1900" no="1901-1907" no="1908-1914" no="1915-1921" no="1922-1928" no="1929-1935" no="1936-1942" no="1943-1949" no="1950-1956" no="1957-1963" no="1964-1970" no="1971-1977" no="1978-1984" no="1985-1991" no="1992-1998" no="1999-2005" no="2006-2012" no="2013-2019">
<textM no="1696-1708" no="1709-1721" no="1722-1734" no="1735-1747" no="1748-1760" no="1761-1773" no="1774-1786" no="1787-1799" no="1800-1812" no="1813-1825" no="1826-1838" no="1839-1851" no="1852-1864" no="1865-1877" no="1878-1890" no="1891-1903" no="1904-1916" no="1917-1929" no="1930-1942" no="1943-1955" no="1956-1968" no="1969-1981" no="1982-1994" no="1995-2007" no="2008-2020">
<textC no="1698-1718" no="1719-1739" no="1740-1760" no="1761-1781" no="1782-1802" no="1803-1823" no="1824-1844" no="1845-1865" no="1866-1886" no="1887-1907" no="1908-1928" no="1929-1949" no="1950-1970" no="1971-1991" no="1992-2012" no="2013-2033">
The announcement that the Hon. Alfred Kingdom, the Solicitor-General of British Guiana, was retiring from the service was made in error, but was based upon an advertisement which appears in the Demerara Argosy of October 10, announcing the sale of all his furniture, plate, and glassware and general effects. it appears, however , that Mr . Kingdom intends returning to the Colony on the expiration of his leave,which intimation will be received with satisfaction by his numerous friends and clients throughout the Colony.
</text>

<text id="480de3211532115">
<textF no="1698-1704" no="1705-1711" no="1712-1718" no="1719-1725" no="1726-1732" no="1733-1739" no="1740-1746" no="1747-1753" no="1754-1760" no="1761-1767" no="1768-1774" no="1775-1781" no="1782-1788" no="1789-1795" no="1796-1802" no="1803-1809" no="1810-1816" no="1817-1823" no="1824-1830" no="1831-1837" no="1838-1844" no="1845-1851" no="1852-1858" no="1859-1865" no="1866-1872" no="1873-1879" no="1880-1886" no="1887-1893" no="1894-1900" no="1901-1907" no="1908-1914" no="1915-1921" no="1922-1928" no="1929-1935" no="1936-1942" no="1943-1949" no="1950-1956" no="1957-1963" no="1964-1970" no="1971-1977" no="1978-1984" no="1985-1991" no="1992-1998" no="1999-2005" no="2006-2012" no="2013-2019">
<textM no="1696-1708" no="1709-1721" no="1722-1734" no="1735-1747" no="1748-1760" no="1761-1773" no="1774-1786" no="1787-1799" no="1800-1812" no="1813-1825" no="1826-1838" no="1839-1851" no="1852-1864" no="1865-1877" no="1878-1890" no="1891-1903" no="1904-1916" no="1917-1929" no="1930-1942" no="1943-1955" no="1956-1968" no="1969-1981" no="1982-1994" no="1995-2007" no="2008-2020">
<textC no="1698-1718" no="1719-1739" no="1740-1760" no="1761-1781" no="1782-1802" no="1803-1823" no="1824-1844" no="1845-1865" no="1866-1886" no="1887-1907" no="1908-1928" no="1929-1949" no="1950-1970" no="1971-1991" no="1992-2012" no="2013-2033">
who has in the present, as in most of his previous venturesgiven a picture in his own inimitable manner of life in some of the fairest portions of the earth south of the Equator.One, reading of the present conditions of the islanders, cannot wonder that such a great and important change has come about inthe disposition of the people towards strangers, and "Sundowner" speaks in a hopeful tone with regard to the growing favour of these Antipodean Archipelagos with visitors
</text>

<text id="1nm0000">
<textF no="1704-1710" no="1711-1717" no="1718-1724" no="1725-1731" no="1732-1738" no="1739-1745" no="1746-1752" no="1753-1759" no="1760-1766" no="1767-1773" no="1774-1780" no="1781-1787" no="1788-1794" no="1795-1801" no="1802-1808" no="1809-1815" no="1816-1822" no="1823-1829" no="1830-1836" no="1837-1843" no="1844-1850" no="1851-1857" no="1858-1864" no="1865-1871" no="1872-1878" no="1879-1885" no="1886-1892" no="1893-1899" no="1900-1906" no="1907-1913" no="1914-1920" no="1921-1927" no="1928-1934" no="1935-1941" no="1942-1948" no="1949-1955" no="1956-1962" no="1963-1969" no="1970-1976" no="1977-1983" no="1984-1990" no="1991-1997" no="1998-2004" no="2005-2011" no="2012-2018">
