<textC no="1708-1728" no="1729-1749" no="1750-1770" no="1771-1791" no="1792-1812" no="1813-1833" no="1834-1854" no="1855-1875" no="1876-1896" no="1897-1917" no="1918-1938" no="1939-1959" no="1960-1980" no="1981-2001" no="2002-2022">
To be measur'd and entred at the George in Winston the 5th of the said August between 10 and 12 in the Morning. One Guinea Entance
</text>

<text id="144qg99114104104">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1701-1713" no="1714-1726" no="1727-1739" no="1740-1752" no="1753-1765" no="1766-1778" no="1779-1791" no="1792-1804" no="1805-1817" no="1818-1830" no="1831-1843" no="1844-1856" no="1857-1869" no="1870-1882" no="1883-1895" no="1896-1908" no="1909-1921" no="1922-1934" no="1935-1947" no="1948-1960" no="1961-1973" no="1974-1986" no="1987-1999" no="2000-2012" no="2013-2025">
<textC no="1702-1722" no="1723-1743" no="1744-1764" no="1765-1785" no="1786-1806" no="1807-1827" no="1828-1848" no="1849-1869" no="1870-1890" no="1891-1911" no="1912-1932" no="1933-1953" no="1954-1974" no="1975-1995" no="1996-2016">
The Price to Subscribers is Three British Half-crowns one Half-crown to be paid at subscribing and the Remainder on the Delivery of the Book.
</text>

<text id="903jb100109101119">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1704-1716" no="1717-1729" no="1730-1742" no="1743-1755" no="1756-1768" no="1769-1781" no="1782-1794" no="1795-1807" no="1808-1820" no="1821-1833" no="1834-1846" no="1847-1859" no="1860-1872" no="1873-1885" no="1886-1898" no="1899-1911" no="1912-1924" no="1925-1937" no="1938-1950" no="1951-1963" no="1964-1976" no="1977-1989" no="1990-2002" no="2003-2015">
<textC no="1706-1726" no="1727-1747" no="1748-1768" no="1769-1789" no="1790-1810" no="1811-1831" no="1832-1852" no="1853-1873" no="1874-1894" no="1895-1915" no="1916-1936" no="1937-1957" no="1958-1978" no="1979-1999" no="2000-2020">
THE word " improvement " is getting a new meaning. The alterations now being carried on in the Mall have resulted in the bettering of conditions of life in London by the abolition of a three-hundred-year-old Milk Fair,—no doubt a quite unnecessary institution, but one which there were certain reasons for retaining, possibly on another site. However, the old women who kept the Fair sat up through Tuesday night only to see their stalls smashed with pickaxes in the morning, and one more improvement has been made in the London parks. It must in fairness be admitted that it is always difficult to abolish anything old without incurring resentment, even though the old may stand in the way of what is new and necessary ; and there is, indeed—though not, we think, in this particular case—often enough nothing but congratulation to be given when this or that is " improved " out of existence.
</text>

<text id="592bg1161019732">
<textF no="1703-1709" no="1710-1716" no="1717-1723" no="1724-1730" no="1731-1737" no="1738-1744" no="1745-1751" no="1752-1758" no="1759-1765" no="1766-1772" no="1773-1779" no="1780-1786" no="1787-1793" no="1794-1800" no="1801-1807" no="1808-1814" no="1815-1821" no="1822-1828" no="1829-1835" no="1836-1842" no="1843-1849" no="1850-1856" no="1857-1863" no="1864-1870" no="1871-1877" no="1878-1884" no="1885-1891" no="1892-1898" no="1899-1905" no="1906-1912" no="1913-1919" no="1920-1926" no="1927-1933" no="1934-1940" no="1941-1947" no="1948-1954" no="1955-1961" no="1962-1968" no="1969-1975" no="1976-1982" no="1983-1989" no="1990-1996" no="1997-2003" no="2004-2010" no="2011-2017">
<textM no="1700-1712" no="1713-1725" no="1726-1738" no="1739-1751" no="1752-1764" no="1765-1777" no="1778-1790" no="1791-1803" no="1804-1816" no="1817-1829" no="1830-1842" no="1843-1855" no="1856-1868" no="1869-1881" no="1882-1894" no="1895-1907" no="1908-1920" no="1921-1933" no="1934-1946" no="1947-1959" no="1960-1972" no="1973-1985" no="1986-1998" no="1999-2011" no="2012-2024">
<textC no="1710-1730" no="1731-1751" no="1752-1772" no="1773-1793" no="1794-1814" no="1815-1835" no="1836-1856" no="1857-1877" no="1878-1898" no="1899-1919" no="1920-1940" no="1941-1961" no="1962-1982" no="1983-2003" no="2004-2024">
Cast-iron jackets, with water coil w and thin walls, have been used; but the iron, working through the cracks in the brickwork, melted through the cast iron, and, cutting down to the water coil, paused explosions that burned the furnace men and destroyed the jacket The hearth also cuts down 2 to 3 feet, leaving the Iron at a lower level. The iron trough is then lowered to it the iron. This is an error; It is better to let the iron lie in the bottom, and let fresh iron accumulate on top of a it to be drawn off at regular casting time, than to lowerthe hearth from time to time.
</text>

<text id="527ah10111610432">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">
<textM no="1703-1715" no="1716-1728" no="1729-1741" no="1742-1754" no="1755-1767" no="1768-1780" no="1781-1793" no="1794-1806" no="1807-1819" no="1820-1832" no="1833-1845" no="1846-1858" no="1859-1871" no="1872-1884" no="1885-1897" no="1898-1910" no="1911-1923" no="1924-1936" no="1937-1949" no="1950-1962" no="1963-1975" no="1976-1988" no="1989-2001" no="2002-2014">
<textC no="1708-1728" no="1729-1749" no="1750-1770" no="1771-1791" no="1792-1812" no="1813-1833" no="1834-1854" no="1855-1875" no="1876-1896" no="1897-1917" no="1918-1938" no="1939-1959" no="1960-1980" no="1981-2001" no="2002-2022">
On the qualifications for the elective franchise the President's proclamation will be regarded as satisfactory. 1 His views are not only constitutional, but they are pronounced with a decision and emphasis which evince the firmness with which they are held. Is voting for members of the Convention to form the new constitution, the oath of allegiance to the United States must first be taken, and then the electors must have the qualifications prescribed by the State laws as they stood immediately previousto secession.
</text>

<text id="788hn10832112111">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1703-1715" no="1716-1728" no="1729-1741" no="1742-1754" no="1755-1767" no="1768-1780" no="1781-1793" no="1794-1806" no="1807-1819" no="1820-1832" no="1833-1845" no="1846-1858" no="1859-1871" no="1872-1884" no="1885-1897" no="1898-1910" no="1911-1923" no="1924-1936" no="1937-1949" no="1950-1962" no="1963-1975" no="1976-1988" no="1989-2001" no="2002-2014">
<textC no="1699-1719" no="1720-1740" no="1741-1761" no="1762-1782" no="1783-1803" no="1804-1824" no="1825-1845" no="1846-1866" no="1867-1887" no="1888-1908" no="1909-1929" no="1930-1950" no="1951-1971" no="1972-1992" no="1993-2013">
the Italian Engine for the imprisonment of those who go abroad with it: Both which I hereby order to be taken down, or else he may expect to have his Letters-Patents for making Punch superseded, be debarr'd wearing his Muff next Winter,or ever coming, to London without his wife. It may be perhaps thought I have dwelt too long upon the Affairs of this Operator ; but I desire the Reader to remember, that it is my Way to consider Men as they stand in Merit, an not according to their Fortune or Figure and if he is in a Coffee-house at the reading hereof, let him look round, and he will find there may be more Characters drawn in this Account than that of Don Echory; for half the Politicians about him, he may observe, are by their Place in Nature of. the Class of Tooth-Drawers.
</text>

<text id="798cn115101101111">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1698-1710" no="1711-1723" no="1724-1736" no="1737-1749" no="1750-1762" no="1763-1775" no="1776-1788" no="1789-1801" no="1802-1814" no="1815-1827" no="1828-1840" no="1841-1853" no="1854-1866" no="1867-1879" no="1880-1892" no="1893-1905" no="1906-1918" no="1919-1931" no="1932-1944" no="1945-1957" no="1958-1970" no="1971-1983" no="1984-1996" no="1997-2009" no="2010-2022">
<textC no="1695-1715" no="1716-1736" no="1737-1757" no="1758-1778" no="1779-1799" no="1800-1820" no="1821-1841" no="1842-1862" no="1863-1883" no="1884-1904" no="1905-1925" no="1926-1946" no="1947-1967" no="1968-1988" no="1989-2009" no="2010-2030">
It seems pretty clear that these provisions will be nugatory for a long time to come, for there is no reason to suppose that nations will lend their sanction to them. The example of the peaceful relations of the States of our Union, cited by Mr. Field as an illustration of harmony and e obedience tinder a common law, is not ine point, because the interests of the members e of the Federal Government are clearly identical, and no questions of boundaries, of religion or race, handed down from generations, g come in to disturb their friendly relations. Yet no arbitrament such as Mr. Field pro- poses would have been accepted by North or South, in secession days; and when the States of the Union grow to the size prefigured by him the dangers of disruption will by nomeans have disappeared.
</text>

<text id="328le3211911732">
<textF no="1700-1706" no="1707-1713" no="1714-1720" no="1721-1727" no="1728-1734" no="1735-1741" no="1742-1748" no="1749-1755" no="1756-1762" no="1763-1769" no="1770-1776" no="1777-1783" no="1784-1790" no="1791-1797" no="1798-1804" no="1805-1811" no="1812-1818" no="1819-1825" no="1826-1832" no="1833-1839" no="1840-1846" no="1847-1853" no="1854-1860" no="1861-1867" no="1868-1874" no="1875-1881" no="1882-1888" no="1889-1895" no="1896-1902" no="1903-1909" no="1910-1916" no="1917-1923" no="1924-1930" no="1931-1937" no="1938-1944" no="1945-1951" no="1952-1958" no="1959-1965" no="1966-1972" no="1973-1979" no="1980-1986" no="1987-1993" no="1994-2000" no="2001-2007" no="2008-2014">
<textM no="1704-1716" no="1717-1729" no="1730-1742" no="1743-1755" no="1756-1768" no="1769-1781" no="1782-1794" no="1795-1807" no="1808-1820" no="1821-1833" no="1834-1846" no="1847-1859" no="1860-1872" no="1873-1885" no="1886-1898" no="1899-1911" no="1912-1924" no="1925-1937" no="1938-1950" no="1951-1963" no="1964-1976" no="1977-1989" no="1990-2002" no="2003-2015">
<textC no="1700-1720" no="1721-1741" no="1742-1762" no="1763-1783" no="1784-1804" no="1805-1825" no="1826-1846" no="1847-1867" no="1868-1888" no="1889-1909" no="1910-1930" no="1931-1951" no="1952-1972" no="1973-1993" no="1994-2014">
So that sometimes when I am put into the best Humour in the World, after having read. Panegyrick upon my Performance, and looked upon my self as a Benefactor to the British Nation, the next Letter perhaps I open, begins with, You old Doting Scorndrel-- Are not you not a sad Dog-- Sirrah, you deserve to have your Nose slit.
</text>

<text id="329nq104115111101">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1702-1714" no="1715-1727" no="1728-1740" no="1741-1753" no="1754-1766" no="1767-1779" no="1780-1792" no="1793-1805" no="1806-1818" no="1819-1831" no="1832-1844" no="1845-1857" no="1858-1870" no="1871-1883" no="1884-1896" no="1897-1909" no="1910-1922" no="1923-1935" no="1936-1948" no="1949-1961" no="1962-1974" no="1975-1987" no="1988-2000" no="2001-2013">
<textC no="1702-1722" no="1723-1743" no="1744-1764" no="1765-1785" no="1786-1806" no="1807-1827" no="1828-1848" no="1849-1869" no="1870-1890" no="1891-1911" no="1912-1932" no="1933-1953" no="1954-1974" no="1975-1995" no="1996-2016">
At the wish of several profesional genlemen who had witnessed of the experiments which had from time to time been performed on Elizabeth and Jane O'Key by Dr. Elliot with a view to prove the influence of the mesmerism on the human frame an appointment was made for the attendance of the girls at the house of Mr. Wakley.
</text>

<text id="804bf116110104114">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1707-1719" no="1720-1732" no="1733-1745" no="1746-1758" no="1759-1771" no="1772-1784" no="1785-1797" no="1798-1810" no="1811-1823" no="1824-1836" no="1837-1849" no="1850-1862" no="1863-1875" no="1876-1888" no="1889-1901" no="1902-1914" no="1915-1927" no="1928-1940" no="1941-1953" no="1954-1966" no="1967-1979" no="1980-1992" no="1993-2005" no="2006-2018">
<textC no="1702-1722" no="1723-1743" no="1744-1764" no="1765-1785" no="1786-1806" no="1807-1827" no="1828-1848" no="1849-1869" no="1870-1890" no="1891-1911" no="1912-1932" no="1933-1953" no="1954-1974" no="1975-1995" no="1996-2016">
The next year, being the sixth year after sowing the acorns, the potatoe crop ceased, as the branches had formed too much shade: had not this been the case, the potatoe crop would have been continued, as the principal object in view is to keep up a continual smothering crop, until the oaks become such themselves: after that period, there is nothing to impede a most rapid growth, forming straight, clean, handsome bolls ; and, by proper attention to thinning at certain periods, soon become a valuable plantation of superior oaks. These oaks having been sown only eight years, many of them are eleven feet high, and ten inches in circumference ; and so fine and clean in their growth, that every judge who sees them is surprised at their progress ; and this is certainly owing to the method pursued.
</text>

<text id="232bd10010111832">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1707-1719" no="1720-1732" no="1733-1745" no="1746-1758" no="1759-1771" no="1772-1784" no="1785-1797" no="1798-1810" no="1811-1823" no="1824-1836" no="1837-1849" no="1850-1862" no="1863-1875" no="1876-1888" no="1889-1901" no="1902-1914" no="1915-1927" no="1928-1940" no="1941-1953" no="1954-1966" no="1967-1979" no="1980-1992" no="1993-2005" no="2006-2018">
<textC no="1699-1719" no="1720-1740" no="1741-1761" no="1762-1782" no="1783-1803" no="1804-1824" no="1825-1845" no="1846-1866" no="1867-1887" no="1888-1908" no="1909-1929" no="1930-1950" no="1951-1971" no="1972-1992" no="1993-2013">
Lord and Lady Palmerston arrived in town for the sea son on Saturday afternoon, from Broadlands, Hants, at their new residence, Cambridge-house, Piccadilly. The noble lord will pay a visit to Manchester in the course of the week.
</text>

<text id="543kk104323299">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">
<textM no="1701-1713" no="1714-1726" no="1727-1739" no="1740-1752" no="1753-1765" no="1766-1778" no="1779-1791" no="1792-1804" no="1805-1817" no="1818-1830" no="1831-1843" no="1844-1856" no="1857-1869" no="1870-1882" no="1883-1895" no="1896-1908" no="1909-1921" no="1922-1934" no="1935-1947" no="1948-1960" no="1961-1973" no="1974-1986" no="1987-1999" no="2000-2012" no="2013-2025">
<textC no="1701-1721" no="1722-1742" no="1743-1763" no="1764-1784" no="1785-1805" no="1806-1826" no="1827-1847" no="1848-1868" no="1869-1889" no="1890-1910" no="1911-1931" no="1932-1952" no="1953-1973" no="1974-1994" no="1995-2015">
their children are brought up to be as accomplished and well behaved to all lasting purposes as those of their superiors and hence a change in the society which if it has not yet completed the justice to be done in like manner to all classes (far, God Knows, from it) has at any rate put an end for ever lo the fine marriageable distinctions between a gentlewoman off the stage, whose attractions lie in the tombs of her ancestors, and a gentlewoman who un it delights the eyes and understandings of living thousands.—Monthly Repository.
</text>

<text id="168nf11611432101">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">
<textM no="1705-1717" no="1718-1730" no="1731-1743" no="1744-1756" no="1757-1769" no="1770-1782" no="1783-1795" no="1796-1808" no="1809-1821" no="1822-1834" no="1835-1847" no="1848-1860" no="1861-1873" no="1874-1886" no="1887-1899" no="1900-1912" no="1913-1925" no="1926-1938" no="1939-1951" no="1952-1964" no="1965-1977" no="1978-1990" no="1991-2003" no="2004-2016">
<textC no="1701-1721" no="1722-1742" no="1743-1763" no="1764-1784" no="1785-1805" no="1806-1826" no="1827-1847" no="1848-1868" no="1869-1889" no="1890-1910" no="1911-1931" no="1932-1952" no="1953-1973" no="1974-1994" no="1995-2015">
Lastly, That if there shall be two or more Competitors for the same Vacancy, caeteris paribus, 'he Alt has. the that have the thickest Skin in to have the Preference.
</text>

<text id="518kf101100101104">
<textF no="1698-1704" no="1705-1711" no="1712-1718" no="1719-1725" no="1726-1732" no="1733-1739" no="1740-1746" no="1747-1753" no="1754-1760" no="1761-1767" no="1768-1774" no="1775-1781" no="1782-1788" no="1789-1795" no="1796-1802" no="1803-1809" no="1810-1816" no="1817-1823" no="1824-1830" no="1831-1837" no="1838-1844" no="1845-1851" no="1852-1858" no="1859-1865" no="1866-1872" no="1873-1879" no="1880-1886" no="1887-1893" no="1894-1900" no="1901-1907" no="1908-1914" no="1915-1921" no="1922-1928" no="1929-1935" no="1936-1942" no="1943-1949" no="1950-1956" no="1957-1963" no="1964-1970" no="1971-1977" no="1978-1984" no="1985-1991" no="1992-1998" no="1999-2005" no="2006-2012" no="2013-2019">
<textM no="1696-1708" no="1709-1721" no="1722-1734" no="1735-1747" no="1748-1760" no="1761-1773" no="1774-1786" no="1787-1799" no="1800-1812" no="1813-1825" no="1826-1838" no="1839-1851" no="1852-1864" no="1865-1877" no="1878-1890" no="1891-1903" no="1904-1916" no="1917-1929" no="1930-1942" no="1943-1955" no="1956-1968" no="1969-1981" no="1982-1994" no="1995-2007" no="2008-2020">
<textC no="1698-1718" no="1719-1739" no="1740-1760" no="1761-1781" no="1782-1802" no="1803-1823" no="1824-1844" no="1845-1865" no="1866-1886" no="1887-1907" no="1908-1928" no="1929-1949" no="1950-1970" no="1971-1991" no="1992-2012" no="2013-2033">
we believe we can discoverthe hand of the wanderer, whose roaming through the unbeaten wastes of the world has not been without its mission. With his shrewd, keen gaze, and his kindly observation of men and things, he has often before now taught half the world—and that the morecivilised, too—how the other half lives. And the picture revealed by the showman of races and countries, upon which the dawn ofcivilisation is but breaking, affords much subject for reflection to the philosophic and thinking mind.
</text>

<text id="550ep11699101115">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">
<textM no="1701-1713" no="1714-1726" no="1727-1739" no="1740-1752" no="1753-1765" no="1766-1778" no="1779-1791" no="1792-1804" no="1805-1817" no="1818-1830" no="1831-1843" no="1844-1856" no="1857-1869" no="1870-1882" no="1883-1895" no="1896-1908" no="1909-1921" no="1922-1934" no="1935-1947" no="1948-1960" no="1961-1973" no="1974-1986" no="1987-1999" no="2000-2012" no="2013-2025">
<textC no="1701-1721" no="1722-1742" no="1743-1763" no="1764-1784" no="1785-1805" no="1806-1826" no="1827-1847" no="1848-1868" no="1869-1889" no="1890-1910" no="1911-1931" no="1932-1952" no="1953-1973" no="1974-1994" no="1995-2015">
During the week, accounts have reached us of struggle in various parts of the kingdom, for and against church rates. In some instances the prorate party have triumphed ; in others they have sustained a defeat. At Rugby the question has been agitated. At a vestry meeting held there last week, a rate of sixpence in the pound was asked ; an amendment to postpone the rate for twelve months was made but defeated, and the sixpenny rate imposed. A sharp contest took place at Rotherbam, on Saturday, when therewas a majority against the rate of 102.
</text>

<text id="430tg114104108112">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1707-1719" no="1720-1732" no="1733-1745" no="1746-1758" no="1759-1771" no="1772-1784" no="1785-1797" no="1798-1810" no="1811-1823" no="1824-1836" no="1837-1849" no="1850-1862" no="1863-1875" no="1876-1888" no="1889-1901" no="1902-1914" no="1915-1927" no="1928-1940" no="1941-1953" no="1954-1966" no="1967-1979" no="1980-1992" no="1993-2005" no="2006-2018">
<textC no="1699-1719" no="1720-1740" no="1741-1761" no="1762-1782" no="1783-1803" no="1804-1824" no="1825-1845" no="1846-1866" no="1867-1887" no="1888-1908" no="1909-1929" no="1930-1950" no="1951-1971" no="1972-1992" no="1993-2013">
TheEmpress takes her meals alone ; her physician,Dr. Karrel, inhabits the house next to the villa.In another house close by are lodged Count Meyendorfl and Count Seouwalolf, her masters of ceremonies, and chamberlains with their suite. CountStackelberg, the Russian envoy to the Court ofthePiedmont, will inhabit the villa Lavil. TwelveCossacks act as domestics, and a carbineer is placed at each entrance of the villa.
</text>

<text id="905tg97100110100">
<textF no="1700-1706" no="1707-1713" no="1714-1720" no="1721-1727" no="1728-1734" no="1735-1741" no="1742-1748" no="1749-1755" no="1756-1762" no="1763-1769" no="1770-1776" no="1777-1783" no="1784-1790" no="1791-1797" no="1798-1804" no="1805-1811" no="1812-1818" no="1819-1825" no="1826-1832" no="1833-1839" no="1840-1846" no="1847-1853" no="1854-1860" no="1861-1867" no="1868-1874" no="1875-1881" no="1882-1888" no="1889-1895" no="1896-1902" no="1903-1909" no="1910-1916" no="1917-1923" no="1924-1930" no="1931-1937" no="1938-1944" no="1945-1951" no="1952-1958" no="1959-1965" no="1966-1972" no="1973-1979" no="1980-1986" no="1987-1993" no="1994-2000" no="2001-2007" no="2008-2014">
<textM no="1700-1712" no="1713-1725" no="1726-1738" no="1739-1751" no="1752-1764" no="1765-1777" no="1778-1790" no="1791-1803" no="1804-1816" no="1817-1829" no="1830-1842" no="1843-1855" no="1856-1868" no="1869-1881" no="1882-1894" no="1895-1907" no="1908-1920" no="1921-1933" no="1934-1946" no="1947-1959" no="1960-1972" no="1973-1985" no="1986-1998" no="1999-2011" no="2012-2024">
<textC no="1700-1720" no="1721-1741" no="1742-1762" no="1763-1783" no="1784-1804" no="1805-1825" no="1826-1846" no="1847-1867" no="1868-1888" no="1889-1909" no="1910-1930" no="1931-1951" no="1952-1972" no="1973-1993" no="1994-2014">
Fires have occurred on in Manchester and Liverpool and Leicester and Swanington Railways from cinders falling out of the grates. The chimney is hooded with wire gauze.	Placing the bars of the grates nearer has prevented fires.	A field of corn was fired on the Leicester Railway.	Tunnels twenty-five or thirty feet high will allow of a hood.	Companies should be compelled to use coke, and to have hoods in passing through towns.	Would not place gunpowder near a railway	Spiral meshes should he used to about one-eighth of an inch aperture. Accidents have not occurred in the streets of America.	Thinking more danger would occur in the country. On the Euson-square Railroad, in addition to the chimney-capwould be desirable to put sides of wire-gauze round the fire-place.	(Both these witnesses said they did not anticipate danger themselves, but suggested precautions to tranquillize the public mind.)
</text>

<text id="111rc10432101115">
<textF no="1700-1706" no="1707-1713" no="1714-1720" no="1721-1727" no="1728-1734" no="1735-1741" no="1742-1748" no="1749-1755" no="1756-1762" no="1763-1769" no="1770-1776" no="1777-1783" no="1784-1790" no="1791-1797" no="1798-1804" no="1805-1811" no="1812-1818" no="1819-1825" no="1826-1832" no="1833-1839" no="1840-1846" no="1847-1853" no="1854-1860" no="1861-1867" no="1868-1874" no="1875-1881" no="1882-1888" no="1889-1895" no="1896-1902" no="1903-1909" no="1910-1916" no="1917-1923" no="1924-1930" no="1931-1937" no="1938-1944" no="1945-1951" no="1952-1958" no="1959-1965" no="1966-1972" no="1973-1979" no="1980-1986" no="1987-1993" no="1994-2000" no="2001-2007" no="2008-2014">
<textM no="1698-1710" no="1711-1723" no="1724-1736" no="1737-1749" no="1750-1762" no="1763-1775" no="1776-1788" no="1789-1801" no="1802-1814" no="1815-1827" no="1828-1840" no="1841-1853" no="1854-1866" no="1867-1879" no="1880-1892" no="1893-1905" no="1906-1918" no="1919-1931" no="1932-1944" no="1945-1957" no="1958-1970" no="1971-1983" no="1984-1996" no="1997-2009" no="2010-2022">
<textC no="1707-1727" no="1728-1748" no="1749-1769" no="1770-1790" no="1791-1811" no="1812-1832" no="1833-1853" no="1854-1874" no="1875-1895" no="1896-1916" no="1917-1937" no="1938-1958" no="1959-1979" no="1980-2000" no="2001-2021">
which His Majesty received very graciously and all the Gentlemen had the Honour to kiss His Majesty's Hand.
</text>

<text id="341rh1003297110">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">
<textM no="1700-1712" no="1713-1725" no="1726-1738" no="1739-1751" no="1752-1764" no="1765-1777" no="1778-1790" no="1791-1803" no="1804-1816" no="1817-1829" no="1830-1842" no="1843-1855" no="1856-1868" no="1869-1881" no="1882-1894" no="1895-1907" no="1908-1920" no="1921-1933" no="1934-1946" no="1947-1959" no="1960-1972" no="1973-1985" no="1986-1998" no="1999-2011" no="2012-2024">
<textC no="1701-1721" no="1722-1742" no="1743-1763" no="1764-1784" no="1785-1805" no="1806-1826" no="1827-1847" no="1848-1868" no="1869-1889" no="1890-1910" no="1911-1931" no="1932-1952" no="1953-1973" no="1974-1994" no="1995-2015">
The Land-Tax, Sir, is but an annual Diminution of a Gentleman's Estate ; he may be free of it, or of a Part of it the succeeding Year : But if by the Decay of our Trade,and the Charge that is laid upon the poor Farmer, he be obliged to lower the Rents of his Estate, that will be a Diminution which I am afraid will endure for ever.
</text>

<text id="200cd9732101110">
<textF no="1700-1706" no="1707-1713" no="1714-1720" no="1721-1727" no="1728-1734" no="1735-1741" no="1742-1748" no="1749-1755" no="1756-1762" no="1763-1769" no="1770-1776" no="1777-1783" no="1784-1790" no="1791-1797" no="1798-1804" no="1805-1811" no="1812-1818" no="1819-1825" no="1826-1832" no="1833-1839" no="1840-1846" no="1847-1853" no="1854-1860" no="1861-1867" no="1868-1874" no="1875-1881" no="1882-1888" no="1889-1895" no="1896-1902" no="1903-1909" no="1910-1916" no="1917-1923" no="1924-1930" no="1931-1937" no="1938-1944" no="1945-1951" no="1952-1958" no="1959-1965" no="1966-1972" no="1973-1979" no="1980-1986" no="1987-1993" no="1994-2000" no="2001-2007" no="2008-2014">
<textM no="1698-1710" no="1711-1723" no="1724-1736" no="1737-1749" no="1750-1762" no="1763-1775" no="1776-1788" no="1789-1801" no="1802-1814" no="1815-1827" no="1828-1840" no="1841-1853" no="1854-1866" no="1867-1879" no="1880-1892" no="1893-1905" no="1906-1918" no="1919-1931" no="1932-1944" no="1945-1957" no="1958-1970" no="1971-1983" no="1984-1996" no="1997-2009" no="2010-2022">
<textC no="1707-1727" no="1728-1748" no="1749-1769" no="1770-1790" no="1791-1811" no="1812-1832" no="1833-1853" no="1854-1874" no="1875-1895" no="1896-1916" no="1917-1937" no="1938-1958" no="1959-1979" no="1980-2000" no="2001-2021">
,Thursday 7-Night, died at the Bath, John Child, Esq of Guilford in the County of Surrey: A Gentleman justly esteem'd in his Country, for his singular Charity; Affability, and other good Qualities.
</text>

<text id="777jg101121102101">
<textF no="1703-1709" no="1710-1716" no="1717-1723" no="1724-1730" no="1731-1737" no="1738-1744" no="1745-1751" no="1752-1758" no="1759-1765" no="1766-1772" no="1773-1779" no="1780-1786" no="1787-1793" no="1794-1800" no="1801-1807" no="1808-1814" no="1815-1821" no="1822-1828" no="1829-1835" no="1836-1842" no="1843-1849" no="1850-1856" no="1857-1863" no="1864-1870" no="1871-1877" no="1878-1884" no="1885-1891" no="1892-1898" no="1899-1905" no="1906-1912" no="1913-1919" no="1920-1926" no="1927-1933" no="1934-1940" no="1941-1947" no="1948-1954" no="1955-1961" no="1962-1968" no="1969-1975" no="1976-1982" no="1983-1989" no="1990-1996" no="1997-2003" no="2004-2010" no="2011-2017">
<textM no="1700-1712" no="1713-1725" no="1726-1738" no="1739-1751" no="1752-1764" no="1765-1777" no="1778-1790" no="1791-1803" no="1804-1816" no="1817-1829" no="1830-1842" no="1843-1855" no="1856-1868" no="1869-1881" no="1882-1894" no="1895-1907" no="1908-1920" no="1921-1933" no="1934-1946" no="1947-1959" no="1960-1972" no="1973-1985" no="1986-1998" no="1999-2011" no="2012-2024">
<textC no="1710-1730" no="1731-1751" no="1752-1772" no="1773-1793" no="1794-1814" no="1815-1835" no="1836-1856" no="1857-1877" no="1878-1898" no="1899-1919" no="1920-1940" no="1941-1961" no="1962-1982" no="1983-2003" no="2004-2024">
The next ordinary meeting ofthis society will be held on Monday, April 9, at the b Westminster Town Hall. A paper will be read on "The Wimbledon Main Drainage and Sewage Disposal Works," i by Mr. William 8anto Crimp, Assoc M.I.C.E., of whichthe following is a synopsis : History of the works. Population, area, and shape of district—High, mid, and low level outfalls.Sizes and gradients of sewers.—Use of brick sewers, cast-iron pipes, and concrete tubes.Application of the separate system, " the rain-fall to the river, and the sewage to the land." Chemioal treatment and filter-presses.—Pumping stations, steam power, and gas engines.—Ventilation of the sewers.—Cost, working expenses, and general conclusions. The chair will be taken at 7.30 p.m. precisely.
</text>

<text id="585pb11612211097">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">
<textM no="1706-1718" no="1719-1731" no="1732-1744" no="1745-1757" no="1758-1770" no="1771-1783" no="1784-1796" no="1797-1809" no="1810-1822" no="1823-1835" no="1836-1848" no="1849-1861" no="1862-1874" no="1875-1887" no="1888-1900" no="1901-1913" no="1914-1926" no="1927-1939" no="1940-1952" no="1953-1965" no="1966-1978" no="1979-1991" no="1992-2004" no="2005-2017">
<textC no="1708-1728" no="1729-1749" no="1750-1770" no="1771-1791" no="1792-1812" no="1813-1833" no="1834-1854" no="1855-1875" no="1876-1896" no="1897-1917" no="1918-1938" no="1939-1959" no="1960-1980" no="1981-2001" no="2002-2022">
The Westminster Gazette of Monday draws attention to a very curious incident described in the Norwood Observer of last Saturday. It appears that Mr. Stewart Bowles, the anti-Tariff Reform Unionist Member, on the previous Monday attended a meeting of the Conservative Council to explain his views, votes, and future intentions,—these having been arraigned by the Tariff Reformers. After Mr. Bowles bad declared that he would never lend a hand to taxing the food of the people, a resolution was carried, a certain number of delegates refraining from voting, to the following effect
</text>

<text id="133ks101114108101">
<textF no="1700-1706" no="1707-1713" no="1714-1720" no="1721-1727" no="1728-1734" no="1735-1741" no="1742-1748" no="1749-1755" no="1756-1762" no="1763-1769" no="1770-1776" no="1777-1783" no="1784-1790" no="1791-1797" no="1798-1804" no="1805-1811" no="1812-1818" no="1819-1825" no="1826-1832" no="1833-1839" no="1840-1846" no="1847-1853" no="1854-1860" no="1861-1867" no="1868-1874" no="1875-1881" no="1882-1888" no="1889-1895" no="1896-1902" no="1903-1909" no="1910-1916" no="1917-1923" no="1924-1930" no="1931-1937" no="1938-1944" no="1945-1951" no="1952-1958" no="1959-1965" no="1966-1972" no="1973-1979" no="1980-1986" no="1987-1993" no="1994-2000" no="2001-2007" no="2008-2014">
<textM no="1698-1710" no="1711-1723" no="1724-1736" no="1737-1749" no="1750-1762" no="1763-1775" no="1776-1788" no="1789-1801" no="1802-1814" no="1815-1827" no="1828-1840" no="1841-1853" no="1854-1866" no="1867-1879" no="1880-1892" no="1893-1905" no="1906-1918" no="1919-1931" no="1932-1944" no="1945-1957" no="1958-1970" no="1971-1983" no="1984-1996" no="1997-2009" no="2010-2022">
<textC no="1707-1727" no="1728-1748" no="1749-1769" no="1770-1790" no="1791-1811" no="1812-1832" no="1833-1853" no="1854-1874" no="1875-1895" no="1896-1916" no="1917-1937" no="1938-1958" no="1959-1979" no="1980-2000" no="2001-2021">
His Majesty hath granted his Letters Patents to Clement Joynes Esq & c. for the sole making of Starch from Potatoes by Extraction.
</text>

<text id="172mm1011143297">
<textF no="1700-1706" no="1707-1713" no="1714-1720" no="1721-1727" no="1728-1734" no="1735-1741" no="1742-1748" no="1749-1755" no="1756-1762" no="1763-1769" no="1770-1776" no="1777-1783" no="1784-1790" no="1791-1797" no="1798-1804" no="1805-1811" no="1812-1818" no="1819-1825" no="1826-1832" no="1833-1839" no="1840-1846" no="1847-1853" no="1854-1860" no="1861-1867" no="1868-1874" no="1875-1881" no="1882-1888" no="1889-1895" no="1896-1902" no="1903-1909" no="1910-1916" no="1917-1923" no="1924-1930" no="1931-1937" no="1938-1944" no="1945-1951" no="1952-1958" no="1959-1965" no="1966-1972" no="1973-1979" no="1980-1986" no="1987-1993" no="1994-2000" no="2001-2007" no="2008-2014">
<textM no="1698-1710" no="1711-1723" no="1724-1736" no="1737-1749" no="1750-1762" no="1763-1775" no="1776-1788" no="1789-1801" no="1802-1814" no="1815-1827" no="1828-1840" no="1841-1853" no="1854-1866" no="1867-1879" no="1880-1892" no="1893-1905" no="1906-1918" no="1919-1931" no="1932-1944" no="1945-1957" no="1958-1970" no="1971-1983" no="1984-1996" no="1997-2009" no="2010-2022">
<textC no="1707-1727" no="1728-1748" no="1749-1769" no="1770-1790" no="1791-1811" no="1812-1832" no="1833-1853" no="1854-1874" no="1875-1895" no="1896-1916" no="1917-1937" no="1938-1958" no="1959-1979" no="1980-2000" no="2001-2021">
where several other Gentlemen of their Nation met them, stript him of his Livery which they sent back to the Great Master of Horse and carry'd him off in a post Chaise.
</text>

<text id="387hk104101105109">
<textF no="1698-1704" no="1705-1711" no="1712-1718" no="1719-1725" no="1726-1732" no="1733-1739" no="1740-1746" no="1747-1753" no="1754-1760" no="1761-1767" no="1768-1774" no="1775-1781" no="1782-1788" no="1789-1795" no="1796-1802" no="1803-1809" no="1810-1816" no="1817-1823" no="1824-1830" no="1831-1837" no="1838-1844" no="1845-1851" no="1852-1858" no="1859-1865" no="1866-1872" no="1873-1879" no="1880-1886" no="1887-1893" no="1894-1900" no="1901-1907" no="1908-1914" no="1915-1921" no="1922-1928" no="1929-1935" no="1936-1942" no="1943-1949" no="1950-1956" no="1957-1963" no="1964-1970" no="1971-1977" no="1978-1984" no="1985-1991" no="1992-1998" no="1999-2005" no="2006-2012" no="2013-2019">
<textM no="1696-1708" no="1709-1721" no="1722-1734" no="1735-1747" no="1748-1760" no="1761-1773" no="1774-1786" no="1787-1799" no="1800-1812" no="1813-1825" no="1826-1838" no="1839-1851" no="1852-1864" no="1865-1877" no="1878-1890" no="1891-1903" no="1904-1916" no="1917-1929" no="1930-1942" no="1943-1955" no="1956-1968" no="1969-1981" no="1982-1994" no="1995-2007" no="2008-2020">
<textC no="1698-1718" no="1719-1739" no="1740-1760" no="1761-1781" no="1782-1802" no="1803-1823" no="1824-1844" no="1845-1865" no="1866-1886" no="1887-1907" no="1908-1928" no="1929-1949" no="1950-1970" no="1971-1991" no="1992-2012" no="2013-2033">
The author of these entertaining papers must not be offended if they are taken with a grain of salt.He draws such an enchanting picture of the Islands of the South Pacific that we are easilypersuaded that there is no part of the earth so fair, and We earnestly hope that his forecast c will be realised , and that Polynesia will shortly become a favourite winter haunt of tourists.
</text>

<text id="242ti101101116105">
<textF no="1700-1706" no="1707-1713" no="1714-1720" no="1721-1727" no="1728-1734" no="1735-1741" no="1742-1748" no="1749-1755" no="1756-1762" no="1763-1769" no="1770-1776" no="1777-1783" no="1784-1790" no="1791-1797" no="1798-1804" no="1805-1811" no="1812-1818" no="1819-1825" no="1826-1832" no="1833-1839" no="1840-1846" no="1847-1853" no="1854-1860" no="1861-1867" no="1868-1874" no="1875-1881" no="1882-1888" no="1889-1895" no="1896-1902" no="1903-1909" no="1910-1916" no="1917-1923" no="1924-1930" no="1931-1937" no="1938-1944" no="1945-1951" no="1952-1958" no="1959-1965" no="1966-1972" no="1973-1979" no="1980-1986" no="1987-1993" no="1994-2000" no="2001-2007" no="2008-2014">
<textM no="1698-1710" no="1711-1723" no="1724-1736" no="1737-1749" no="1750-1762" no="1763-1775" no="1776-1788" no="1789-1801" no="1802-1814" no="1815-1827" no="1828-1840" no="1841-1853" no="1854-1866" no="1867-1879" no="1880-1892" no="1893-1905" no="1906-1918" no="1919-1931" no="1932-1944" no="1945-1957" no="1958-1970" no="1971-1983" no="1984-1996" no="1997-2009" no="2010-2022">
<textC no="1707-1727" no="1728-1748" no="1749-1769" no="1770-1790" no="1791-1811" no="1812-1832" no="1833-1853" no="1854-1874" no="1875-1895" no="1896-1916" no="1917-1937" no="1938-1958" no="1959-1979" no="1980-2000" no="2001-2021">
But after he had been two or three Days in that Prison, he found means to make his Escape, before the Party from hence was come up to receive him and is gone again to the Hills; at which his grace being very much concern'd he has sent the
</text>

<text id="448ee111116105116">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1702-1714" no="1715-1727" no="1728-1740" no="1741-1753" no="1754-1766" no="1767-1779" no="1780-1792" no="1793-1805" no="1806-1818" no="1819-1831" no="1832-1844" no="1845-1857" no="1858-1870" no="1871-1883" no="1884-1896" no="1897-1909" no="1910-1922" no="1923-1935" no="1936-1948" no="1949-1961" no="1962-1974" no="1975-1987" no="1988-2000" no="2001-2013">
<textC no="1702-1722" no="1723-1743" no="1744-1764" no="1765-1785" no="1786-1806" no="1807-1827" no="1828-1848" no="1849-1869" no="1870-1890" no="1891-1911" no="1912-1932" no="1933-1953" no="1954-1974" no="1975-1995" no="1996-2016">
We cannot pretend to he acquainted with the particulars (and we waited for some time, in order to learn if the general statement were correct before we gave it additional currency, but it is asserted that very recently every member of the sub-committee of management of Drury-lane, with one exception, was called upon, with a hostile message from a party formerly in connection with them, and upon whom a claim for certain arrears has been made.
</text>

<text id="227at3210311159">
<textF no="1700-1706" no="1707-1713" no="1714-1720" no="1721-1727" no="1728-1734" no="1735-1741" no="1742-1748" no="1749-1755" no="1756-1762" no="1763-1769" no="1770-1776" no="1777-1783" no="1784-1790" no="1791-1797" no="1798-1804" no="1805-1811" no="1812-1818" no="1819-1825" no="1826-1832" no="1833-1839" no="1840-1846" no="1847-1853" no="1854-1860" no="1861-1867" no="1868-1874" no="1875-1881" no="1882-1888" no="1889-1895" no="1896-1902" no="1903-1909" no="1910-1916" no="1917-1923" no="1924-1930" no="1931-1937" no="1938-1944" no="1945-1951" no="1952-1958" no="1959-1965" no="1966-1972" no="1973-1979" no="1980-1986" no="1987-1993" no="1994-2000" no="2001-2007" no="2008-2014">
<textM no="1698-1710" no="1711-1723" no="1724-1736" no="1737-1749" no="1750-1762" no="1763-1775" no="1776-1788" no="1789-1801" no="1802-1814" no="1815-1827" no="1828-1840" no="1841-1853" no="1854-1866" no="1867-1879" no="1880-1892" no="1893-1905" no="1906-1918" no="1919-1931" no="1932-1944" no="1945-1957" no="1958-1970" no="1971-1983" no="1984-1996" no="1997-2009" no="2010-2022">
<textC no="1707-1727" no="1728-1748" no="1749-1769" no="1770-1790" no="1791-1811" no="1812-1832" no="1833-1853" no="1854-1874" no="1875-1895" no="1896-1916" no="1917-1937" no="1938-1958" no="1959-1979" no="1980-2000" no="2001-2021">
But you was talking just now of Martyrs ; who do you reckon the chief in our Calendar. Those worthy Patriots, the Earl of Derwentwater, Viscount Kenmure, Justice Hall, and Parson Paul, Colonel Oxburgh, and M r . Gascoign.
</text>

<text id="179cg9798101100">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">
<textM no="1697-1709" no="1710-1722" no="1723-1735" no="1736-1748" no="1749-1761" no="1762-1774" no="1775-1787" no="1788-1800" no="1801-1813" no="1814-1826" no="1827-1839" no="1840-1852" no="1853-1865" no="1866-1878" no="1879-1891" no="1892-1904" no="1905-1917" no="1918-1930" no="1931-1943" no="1944-1956" no="1957-1969" no="1970-1982" no="1983-1995" no="1996-2008" no="2009-2021">
<textC no="1708-1728" no="1729-1749" no="1750-1770" no="1771-1791" no="1792-1812" no="1813-1833" no="1834-1854" no="1855-1875" no="1876-1896" no="1897-1917" no="1918-1938" no="1939-1959" no="1960-1980" no="1981-2001" no="2002-2022">
It appears these abandoned wretches are driven to a repetition of their crime from the rapacity of the receivers of stolen goods who seldom give more than a third of the value.
</text>

<text id="610tn12011711998">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">
<textM no="1702-1714" no="1715-1727" no="1728-1740" no="1741-1753" no="1754-1766" no="1767-1779" no="1780-1792" no="1793-1805" no="1806-1818" no="1819-1831" no="1832-1844" no="1845-1857" no="1858-1870" no="1871-1883" no="1884-1896" no="1897-1909" no="1910-1922" no="1923-1935" no="1936-1948" no="1949-1961" no="1962-1974" no="1975-1987" no="1988-2000" no="2001-2013">
<textC no="1694-1714" no="1715-1735" no="1736-1756" no="1757-1777" no="1778-1798" no="1799-1819" no="1820-1840" no="1841-1861" no="1862-1882" no="1883-1903" no="1904-1924" no="1925-1945" no="1946-1966" no="1967-1987" no="1988-2008" no="2009-2029">
THE EXPOSITION SURPLUS. " WHAT shall be done with the surplus of the Crystal Palace ? " is a question now agitated in such a manner as to promise a clear and pleasant reply from all concerned, public and public officers. About the main facts there can be no doubt: there will be great money means ; and there is a general concurrence in the desire to perpetuate the beautiful structure as a winter garden and spacious forum of the Arts. From Richard Steele, whose suggestion we will boast of first applying to this edifice, down to the last pamphlet, by the designer himself, all fall in with that idea.
</text>

<text id="520ia116117100110">
<textF no="1698-1704" no="1705-1711" no="1712-1718" no="1719-1725" no="1726-1732" no="1733-1739" no="1740-1746" no="1747-1753" no="1754-1760" no="1761-1767" no="1768-1774" no="1775-1781" no="1782-1788" no="1789-1795" no="1796-1802" no="1803-1809" no="1810-1816" no="1817-1823" no="1824-1830" no="1831-1837" no="1838-1844" no="1845-1851" no="1852-1858" no="1859-1865" no="1866-1872" no="1873-1879" no="1880-1886" no="1887-1893" no="1894-1900" no="1901-1907" no="1908-1914" no="1915-1921" no="1922-1928" no="1929-1935" no="1936-1942" no="1943-1949" no="1950-1956" no="1957-1963" no="1964-1970" no="1971-1977" no="1978-1984" no="1985-1991" no="1992-1998" no="1999-2005" no="2006-2012" no="2013-2019">
<textM no="1696-1708" no="1709-1721" no="1722-1734" no="1735-1747" no="1748-1760" no="1761-1773" no="1774-1786" no="1787-1799" no="1800-1812" no="1813-1825" no="1826-1838" no="1839-1851" no="1852-1864" no="1865-1877" no="1878-1890" no="1891-1903" no="1904-1916" no="1917-1929" no="1930-1942" no="1943-1955" no="1956-1968" no="1969-1981" no="1982-1994" no="1995-2007" no="2008-2020">
<textC no="1698-1718" no="1719-1739" no="1740-1760" no="1761-1781" no="1782-1802" no="1803-1823" no="1824-1844" no="1845-1865" no="1866-1886" no="1887-1907" no="1908-1928" no="1929-1949" no="1950-1970" no="1971-1991" no="1992-2012" no="2013-2033">
The Australasian public expenditure during the same period was 30,359,1352., or 331,0912. less than the annual revenue, showing the manner in which the various Colonial Governments are endeavouring to live within their respective incomes. The sums deposited in the various Australasian savings banks at the end of 1896 was 28,255,008*., of which 8,552,6232. belonged to New SouthWales, where the average amount of deposits was considerably higher than in any of the other Colonies, with the exception of Queensland.
</text>

<text id="672lp9711532110">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1702-1714" no="1715-1727" no="1728-1740" no="1741-1753" no="1754-1766" no="1767-1779" no="1780-1792" no="1793-1805" no="1806-1818" no="1819-1831" no="1832-1844" no="1845-1857" no="1858-1870" no="1871-1883" no="1884-1896" no="1897-1909" no="1910-1922" no="1923-1935" no="1936-1948" no="1949-1961" no="1962-1974" no="1975-1987" no="1988-2000" no="2001-2013">
<textC no="1702-1722" no="1723-1743" no="1744-1764" no="1765-1785" no="1786-1806" no="1807-1827" no="1828-1848" no="1849-1869" no="1870-1890" no="1891-1911" no="1912-1932" no="1933-1953" no="1954-1974" no="1975-1995" no="1996-2016">
On Sunday there was a partial thaw, having veered rousa to the south-west; but on Monday hight the wind again got roun, to the north east, and the frost was renewed, and has continued throughout the week with much severity. The supply of water in most of the houses in London has been stopped. and in every street temporary pipes have been placed for the convenience of the habitants, who have to fetch all the winter necessary for household purposes. The greatest distress prevails among the humblest class; but we are glad to find the subscriptions have been raised to most every parish to afford temporary relief the distribution of coals, food, and warm clothing.
</text>

<text id="893tk10510197107">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1704-1716" no="1717-1729" no="1730-1742" no="1743-1755" no="1756-1768" no="1769-1781" no="1782-1794" no="1795-1807" no="1808-1820" no="1821-1833" no="1834-1846" no="1847-1859" no="1860-1872" no="1873-1885" no="1886-1898" no="1899-1911" no="1912-1924" no="1925-1937" no="1938-1950" no="1951-1963" no="1964-1976" no="1977-1989" no="1990-2002" no="2003-2015">
<textC no="1706-1726" no="1727-1747" no="1748-1768" no="1769-1789" no="1790-1810" no="1811-1831" no="1832-1852" no="1853-1873" no="1874-1894" no="1895-1915" no="1916-1936" no="1937-1957" no="1958-1978" no="1979-1999" no="2000-2020">
Arab tribes outside are constantly attacking French positions with great boldness, and continual sniping goes on at long distances. Mr. Hands holds that the only way to stop this ridiculous situation is for General prude to be allowed to advance and attack the Arabs. But this at present he is forbidden to do by distinct orders from Paris. On Wednesday a very picturesque but unsuccessful charge took place. At twenty minutes to one a body of Moorish horsemen, riding in close order, came over the crest of the nearest hill, firing from the saddle, and quite indifferent to the artillery and rifle fire which they had to face, and got within five hundred yards of the camp. The latter part of the charge seems to have been specially picturesque, for about two hundred white-clad warriors were led to within five hundred yards of the entrenched infantry by a Kaid dressed entirely in red.
</text>

<text id="188hm1043211297">
<textF no="1700-1706" no="1707-1713" no="1714-1720" no="1721-1727" no="1728-1734" no="1735-1741" no="1742-1748" no="1749-1755" no="1756-1762" no="1763-1769" no="1770-1776" no="1777-1783" no="1784-1790" no="1791-1797" no="1798-1804" no="1805-1811" no="1812-1818" no="1819-1825" no="1826-1832" no="1833-1839" no="1840-1846" no="1847-1853" no="1854-1860" no="1861-1867" no="1868-1874" no="1875-1881" no="1882-1888" no="1889-1895" no="1896-1902" no="1903-1909" no="1910-1916" no="1917-1923" no="1924-1930" no="1931-1937" no="1938-1944" no="1945-1951" no="1952-1958" no="1959-1965" no="1966-1972" no="1973-1979" no="1980-1986" no="1987-1993" no="1994-2000" no="2001-2007" no="2008-2014">
<textM no="1698-1710" no="1711-1723" no="1724-1736" no="1737-1749" no="1750-1762" no="1763-1775" no="1776-1788" no="1789-1801" no="1802-1814" no="1815-1827" no="1828-1840" no="1841-1853" no="1854-1866" no="1867-1879" no="1880-1892" no="1893-1905" no="1906-1918" no="1919-1931" no="1932-1944" no="1945-1957" no="1958-1970" no="1971-1983" no="1984-1996" no="1997-2009" no="2010-2022">
<textC no="1707-1727" no="1728-1748" no="1749-1769" no="1770-1790" no="1791-1811" no="1812-1832" no="1833-1853" no="1854-1874" no="1875-1895" no="1896-1916" no="1917-1937" no="1938-1958" no="1959-1979" no="1980-2000" no="2001-2021">
or if they escap'd sent into perpetual Banishment : As the Dodor, was first of all scourg'd by the common Executioner beyond all Precedent, and then condem'd to perpetual Imprisonment.
</text>

<text id="1037ms121979119">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1704-1716" no="1717-1729" no="1730-1742" no="1743-1755" no="1756-1768" no="1769-1781" no="1782-1794" no="1795-1807" no="1808-1820" no="1821-1833" no="1834-1846" no="1847-1859" no="1860-1872" no="1873-1885" no="1886-1898" no="1899-1911" no="1912-1924" no="1925-1937" no="1938-1950" no="1951-1963" no="1964-1976" no="1977-1989" no="1990-2002" no="2003-2015">
<textC no="1699-1719" no="1720-1740" no="1741-1761" no="1762-1782" no="1783-1803" no="1804-1824" no="1825-1845" no="1846-1866" no="1867-1887" no="1888-1908" no="1909-1929" no="1930-1950" no="1951-1971" no="1972-1992" no="1993-2013">
Lastly, That	organic	motion	is	endued with the properties not only of enfolding organization, but of multiplyingthe organsand their appropriate functions. After having expounded these grandconsiderations, which appear to me to present incontrovertible truths, though hitherto unperceived, I shall inquire what are the faculties that are common to all animals and shall then pass in review the most remarkable of those which are necessarily peculiar to certain animals and incompatible with the condition of others. An object which I ought not to over- look, in this second part of my work, is the consideration of the immediate results of life in any body.	Now I can demonstrate that these results give rise to combinations among principles, which, independently of this circumstance, could never coalesce. These combinations even teemand multiply, in proportion as the vital energy increases; insomuch that, in the more perfect animals, they present muchintricacy, and a considerable accumulation of their combined principles.
</text>

<text id="681qa1093210132">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1698-1710" no="1711-1723" no="1724-1736" no="1737-1749" no="1750-1762" no="1763-1775" no="1776-1788" no="1789-1801" no="1802-1814" no="1815-1827" no="1828-1840" no="1841-1853" no="1854-1866" no="1867-1879" no="1880-1892" no="1893-1905" no="1906-1918" no="1919-1931" no="1932-1944" no="1945-1957" no="1958-1970" no="1971-1983" no="1984-1996" no="1997-2009" no="2010-2022">
<textC no="1695-1715" no="1716-1736" no="1737-1757" no="1758-1778" no="1779-1799" no="1800-1820" no="1821-1841" no="1842-1862" no="1863-1883" no="1884-1904" no="1905-1925" no="1926-1946" no="1947-1967" no="1968-1988" no="1989-2009" no="2010-2030">
Of the Mississippi legislative troubles, the Detroit Tribune says: The plain truth of tho whole matter, however, appears to be that the present State officers and members of the Legislature, being warm in their seats and not caring to leave them, are scheming to repeal the law which provides for the election of. their successors this Fall, and stave over t.hoelection until the Fall of 1874,thus giving themselves another year of office without the expense or risk of another election. Accord- ing to the facts now before us, this business appears to us one of the worst outrages upon law and liberty that have occurred in the whole history of the Southern State Governments.
</text>

<text id="380ml111118115116">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1700-1712" no="1713-1725" no="1726-1738" no="1739-1751" no="1752-1764" no="1765-1777" no="1778-1790" no="1791-1803" no="1804-1816" no="1817-1829" no="1830-1842" no="1843-1855" no="1856-1868" no="1869-1881" no="1882-1894" no="1895-1907" no="1908-1920" no="1921-1933" no="1934-1946" no="1947-1959" no="1960-1972" no="1973-1985" no="1986-1998" no="1999-2011" no="2012-2024">
<textC no="1709-1729" no="1730-1750" no="1751-1771" no="1772-1792" no="1793-1813" no="1814-1834" no="1835-1855" no="1856-1876" no="1877-1897" no="1898-1918" no="1919-1939" no="1940-1960" no="1961-1981" no="1982-2002" no="2003-2023">
And in order to give the necessary Assistance in that Service , Sir George Byng is going to Port Mahone to refit the Ships that have been a cruzing all the Winter off Sicily, leaving a Squadron of six or seven Ships off Reggio, to attend the Motions of the Spanish Squadron on that is in Messina : Besides which , some Cruizers will be employed between Sicily and Sardinia.
</text>

<text id="239pd103110101105">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1703-1715" no="1716-1728" no="1729-1741" no="1742-1754" no="1755-1767" no="1768-1780" no="1781-1793" no="1794-1806" no="1807-1819" no="1820-1832" no="1833-1845" no="1846-1858" no="1859-1871" no="1872-1884" no="1885-1897" no="1898-1910" no="1911-1923" no="1924-1936" no="1937-1949" no="1950-1962" no="1963-1975" no="1976-1988" no="1989-2001" no="2002-2014">
<textC no="1699-1719" no="1720-1740" no="1741-1761" no="1762-1782" no="1783-1803" no="1804-1824" no="1825-1845" no="1846-1866" no="1867-1887" no="1888-1908" no="1909-1929" no="1930-1950" no="1951-1971" no="1972-1992" no="1993-2013">
HAving taken upon me to cure all theDistempers which, proceed from Affections of the Mind, I have labour'd, since I first kept this publick Stage, todo all the Good I could possibly, and have perfected many Cures at my own Lodgings
</text>

<text id="239el3232104101">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">

<textC no="1708-1728" no="1729-1749" no="1750-1770" no="1771-1791" no="1792-1812" no="1813-1833" no="1834-1854" no="1855-1875" no="1876-1896" no="1897-1917" no="1918-1938" no="1939-1959" no="1960-1980" no="1981-2001" no="2002-2022">
After the signal Kindness shewn to the Dolghorucki, we expected, that, touch'd with a due Sense-of Gratitude, and sincerely repenting their Crimes; they would have lived quietly in their Exile,- praying to God for our Preservation
</text>

<text id="189sa104109101105">
<textF no="1698-1704" no="1705-1711" no="1712-1718" no="1719-1725" no="1726-1732" no="1733-1739" no="1740-1746" no="1747-1753" no="1754-1760" no="1761-1767" no="1768-1774" no="1775-1781" no="1782-1788" no="1789-1795" no="1796-1802" no="1803-1809" no="1810-1816" no="1817-1823" no="1824-1830" no="1831-1837" no="1838-1844" no="1845-1851" no="1852-1858" no="1859-1865" no="1866-1872" no="1873-1879" no="1880-1886" no="1887-1893" no="1894-1900" no="1901-1907" no="1908-1914" no="1915-1921" no="1922-1928" no="1929-1935" no="1936-1942" no="1943-1949" no="1950-1956" no="1957-1963" no="1964-1970" no="1971-1977" no="1978-1984" no="1985-1991" no="1992-1998" no="1999-2005" no="2006-2012" no="2013-2019">

He exhorts his Imperial Majesty to defit from such violent Courses, in which case his Holiness offers to forgive all past Injuries, and to embrace him as the First-born of the Church.
</text>

<text id="123rj1193211432">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">

They write, that the said Pretender is not fully recover'd but that as soon as he is well he is to remove into Italy;
</text>

<text id="465gq9797111116">
<textF no="1704-1710" no="1711-1717" no="1718-1724" no="1725-1731" no="1732-1738" no="1739-1745" no="1746-1752" no="1753-1759" no="1760-1766" no="1767-1773" no="1774-1780" no="1781-1787" no="1788-1794" no="1795-1801" no="1802-1808" no="1809-1815" no="1816-1822" no="1823-1829" no="1830-1836" no="1837-1843" no="1844-1850" no="1851-1857" no="1858-1864" no="1865-1871" no="1872-1878" no="1879-1885" no="1886-1892" no="1893-1899" no="1900-1906" no="1907-1913" no="1914-1920" no="1921-1927" no="1928-1934" no="1935-1941" no="1942-1948" no="1949-1955" no="1956-1962" no="1963-1969" no="1970-1976" no="1977-1983" no="1984-1990" no="1991-1997" no="1998-2004" no="2005-2011" no="2012-2018">
<textM no="1697-1709" no="1710-1722" no="1723-1735" no="1736-1748" no="1749-1761" no="1762-1774" no="1775-1787" no="1788-1800" no="1801-1813" no="1814-1826" no="1827-1839" no="1840-1852" no="1853-1865" no="1866-1878" no="1879-1891" no="1892-1904" no="1905-1917" no="1918-1930" no="1931-1943" no="1944-1956" no="1957-1969" no="1970-1982" no="1983-1995" no="1996-2008" no="2009-2021">
<textC no="1711-1731" no="1732-1752" no="1753-1773" no="1774-1794" no="1795-1815" no="1816-1836" no="1837-1857" no="1858-1878" no="1879-1899" no="1900-1920" no="1921-1941" no="1942-1962" no="1963-1983" no="1984-2004" no="2005-2025">
many Seamen, who have been from time to time put on Shoar sick from his Majesty's Ships either into Hospitals or Sick Quarter have made so ill a Return to the Care taken from their Healths as to desert from his Majesty's Service when so far recovered as to be able to withdraw themselves from the/aid Hospitals or Sick Quarters for which Crime they have incurr'd the Loss of their Wages, and according to Law, they are punishable with Death by a Court Martial;
</text>

<text id="131od10732100116">
<textF no="1700-1706" no="1707-1713" no="1714-1720" no="1721-1727" no="1728-1734" no="1735-1741" no="1742-1748" no="1749-1755" no="1756-1762" no="1763-1769" no="1770-1776" no="1777-1783" no="1784-1790" no="1791-1797" no="1798-1804" no="1805-1811" no="1812-1818" no="1819-1825" no="1826-1832" no="1833-1839" no="1840-1846" no="1847-1853" no="1854-1860" no="1861-1867" no="1868-1874" no="1875-1881" no="1882-1888" no="1889-1895" no="1896-1902" no="1903-1909" no="1910-1916" no="1917-1923" no="1924-1930" no="1931-1937" no="1938-1944" no="1945-1951" no="1952-1958" no="1959-1965" no="1966-1972" no="1973-1979" no="1980-1986" no="1987-1993" no="1994-2000" no="2001-2007" no="2008-2014">
