<textC no="1707-1727" no="1728-1748" no="1749-1769" no="1770-1790" no="1791-1811" no="1812-1832" no="1833-1853" no="1854-1874" no="1875-1895" no="1896-1916" no="1917-1937" no="1938-1958" no="1959-1979" no="1980-2000" no="2001-2021">
Thursday last Bowen, the Grave Digger, sentenc'd for sending a dead Body our off the Ground to be Anatomiz'd , was Whipp'd From Newgate to Smithfield Bars.
</text>

<text id="357bs10811611032">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1702-1714" no="1715-1727" no="1728-1740" no="1741-1753" no="1754-1766" no="1767-1779" no="1780-1792" no="1793-1805" no="1806-1818" no="1819-1831" no="1832-1844" no="1845-1857" no="1858-1870" no="1871-1883" no="1884-1896" no="1897-1909" no="1910-1922" no="1923-1935" no="1936-1948" no="1949-1961" no="1962-1974" no="1975-1987" no="1988-2000" no="2001-2013">
<textC no="1702-1722" no="1723-1743" no="1744-1764" no="1765-1785" no="1786-1806" no="1807-1827" no="1828-1848" no="1849-1869" no="1870-1890" no="1891-1911" no="1912-1932" no="1933-1953" no="1954-1974" no="1975-1995" no="1996-2016">
Don Carlos melted the bells into cannon, and the Queen sold them for old copper. The consignees of the bells have received orders to sell them at cost. One of the oldest and most experienced bell founders of Philadelphia has been to New York and examined them, and says they are such as cannot be made in this country or probably any where at this time.
</text>

<text id="538os11032101121">
<textF no="1698-1704" no="1705-1711" no="1712-1718" no="1719-1725" no="1726-1732" no="1733-1739" no="1740-1746" no="1747-1753" no="1754-1760" no="1761-1767" no="1768-1774" no="1775-1781" no="1782-1788" no="1789-1795" no="1796-1802" no="1803-1809" no="1810-1816" no="1817-1823" no="1824-1830" no="1831-1837" no="1838-1844" no="1845-1851" no="1852-1858" no="1859-1865" no="1866-1872" no="1873-1879" no="1880-1886" no="1887-1893" no="1894-1900" no="1901-1907" no="1908-1914" no="1915-1921" no="1922-1928" no="1929-1935" no="1936-1942" no="1943-1949" no="1950-1956" no="1957-1963" no="1964-1970" no="1971-1977" no="1978-1984" no="1985-1991" no="1992-1998" no="1999-2005" no="2006-2012" no="2013-2019">
<textM no="1696-1708" no="1709-1721" no="1722-1734" no="1735-1747" no="1748-1760" no="1761-1773" no="1774-1786" no="1787-1799" no="1800-1812" no="1813-1825" no="1826-1838" no="1839-1851" no="1852-1864" no="1865-1877" no="1878-1890" no="1891-1903" no="1904-1916" no="1917-1929" no="1930-1942" no="1943-1955" no="1956-1968" no="1969-1981" no="1982-1994" no="1995-2007" no="2008-2020">
<textC no="1698-1718" no="1719-1739" no="1740-1760" no="1761-1781" no="1782-1802" no="1803-1823" no="1824-1844" no="1845-1865" no="1866-1886" no="1887-1907" no="1908-1928" no="1929-1949" no="1950-1970" no="1971-1991" no="1992-2012" no="2013-2033">
CHLORODYNE.—Dr. J . C. BROWNE(late Army Medical Staff) DISCOVERED a REMEDY to denote which he coined the word CHLORODYNE. Dr. Browne is the SOLE INVENTOR and, as the composition of Chlorodyne cannot possibly be discovered by Analysis (organic substances defying elimination), and since the formula has never been published, it is evident that any statement to the effect that a compound is identicalwith Dr. Browne's Chlorodyne must be false.This caution is necessary, as many persons deceive purchasers by false re- presentations.
</text>

<text id="363gc13101115111">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1700-1712" no="1713-1725" no="1726-1738" no="1739-1751" no="1752-1764" no="1765-1777" no="1778-1790" no="1791-1803" no="1804-1816" no="1817-1829" no="1830-1842" no="1843-1855" no="1856-1868" no="1869-1881" no="1882-1894" no="1895-1907" no="1908-1920" no="1921-1933" no="1934-1946" no="1947-1959" no="1960-1972" no="1973-1985" no="1986-1998" no="1999-2011" no="2012-2024">
<textC no="1709-1729" no="1730-1750" no="1751-1771" no="1772-1792" no="1793-1813" no="1814-1834" no="1835-1855" no="1856-1876" no="1877-1897" no="1898-1918" no="1919-1939" no="1940-1960" no="1961-1981" no="1982-2002" no="2003-2023">
The new Levies the Regent has ordered to be made, are carried on with all imaginable success. They prepare the Field Equipage of the Prince de Conty with all Expedition, and the Officers belonging to the Troops that are to be employ'd against Spain, have received Orders forth- with to repair to their respective Commands , upon Pain of being Cashier'd.
</text>

<text id="713am11210432115">
<textF no="1698-1704" no="1705-1711" no="1712-1718" no="1719-1725" no="1726-1732" no="1733-1739" no="1740-1746" no="1747-1753" no="1754-1760" no="1761-1767" no="1768-1774" no="1775-1781" no="1782-1788" no="1789-1795" no="1796-1802" no="1803-1809" no="1810-1816" no="1817-1823" no="1824-1830" no="1831-1837" no="1838-1844" no="1845-1851" no="1852-1858" no="1859-1865" no="1866-1872" no="1873-1879" no="1880-1886" no="1887-1893" no="1894-1900" no="1901-1907" no="1908-1914" no="1915-1921" no="1922-1928" no="1929-1935" no="1936-1942" no="1943-1949" no="1950-1956" no="1957-1963" no="1964-1970" no="1971-1977" no="1978-1984" no="1985-1991" no="1992-1998" no="1999-2005" no="2006-2012" no="2013-2019">
<textM no="1696-1708" no="1709-1721" no="1722-1734" no="1735-1747" no="1748-1760" no="1761-1773" no="1774-1786" no="1787-1799" no="1800-1812" no="1813-1825" no="1826-1838" no="1839-1851" no="1852-1864" no="1865-1877" no="1878-1890" no="1891-1903" no="1904-1916" no="1917-1929" no="1930-1942" no="1943-1955" no="1956-1968" no="1969-1981" no="1982-1994" no="1995-2007" no="2008-2020">
<textC no="1698-1718" no="1719-1739" no="1740-1760" no="1761-1781" no="1782-1802" no="1803-1823" no="1824-1844" no="1845-1865" no="1866-1886" no="1887-1907" no="1908-1928" no="1929-1949" no="1950-1970" no="1971-1991" no="1992-2012" no="2013-2033">
Austria protected the Russians on the Bessarabianfrontier after their defeat, we were forced at a late period of the year to make a descent upon the Crimea." . . . . Then followed the series of disasters, which in a great measure were attributable to miscalculation, and produced emergencies for which the army were entirely unprepared. Most people will agree with the writer that " t h e successes gained were not due to the skill of the Government thatdirected the struggle. On the contrary, our statesmanship had little or no claim upon our regard on that occasion. And yet, notwithstanding, the war brought many compensations to the nation, to make up for the lack of political forethought thendisclosed.
</text>

<text id="286ap10197115110">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1700-1712" no="1713-1725" no="1726-1738" no="1739-1751" no="1752-1764" no="1765-1777" no="1778-1790" no="1791-1803" no="1804-1816" no="1817-1829" no="1830-1842" no="1843-1855" no="1856-1868" no="1869-1881" no="1882-1894" no="1895-1907" no="1908-1920" no="1921-1933" no="1934-1946" no="1947-1959" no="1960-1972" no="1973-1985" no="1986-1998" no="1999-2011" no="2012-2024">
<textC no="1709-1729" no="1730-1750" no="1751-1771" no="1772-1792" no="1793-1813" no="1814-1834" no="1835-1855" no="1856-1876" no="1877-1897" no="1898-1918" no="1919-1939" no="1940-1960" no="1961-1981" no="1982-2002" no="2003-2023">
s I have had the Hapiness to see those Engagements formed which unite the King my Master with your Majesty I shall think myself very fortunate if by my Endeavours I may any way contribute to the keeping up of this happy Union and to rendring it more perfect between the two Nations.
</text>

<text id="793hg97117119105">
<textF no="1704-1710" no="1711-1717" no="1718-1724" no="1725-1731" no="1732-1738" no="1739-1745" no="1746-1752" no="1753-1759" no="1760-1766" no="1767-1773" no="1774-1780" no="1781-1787" no="1788-1794" no="1795-1801" no="1802-1808" no="1809-1815" no="1816-1822" no="1823-1829" no="1830-1836" no="1837-1843" no="1844-1850" no="1851-1857" no="1858-1864" no="1865-1871" no="1872-1878" no="1879-1885" no="1886-1892" no="1893-1899" no="1900-1906" no="1907-1913" no="1914-1920" no="1921-1927" no="1928-1934" no="1935-1941" no="1942-1948" no="1949-1955" no="1956-1962" no="1963-1969" no="1970-1976" no="1977-1983" no="1984-1990" no="1991-1997" no="1998-2004" no="2005-2011" no="2012-2018">
<textM no="1704-1716" no="1717-1729" no="1730-1742" no="1743-1755" no="1756-1768" no="1769-1781" no="1782-1794" no="1795-1807" no="1808-1820" no="1821-1833" no="1834-1846" no="1847-1859" no="1860-1872" no="1873-1885" no="1886-1898" no="1899-1911" no="1912-1924" no="1925-1937" no="1938-1950" no="1951-1963" no="1964-1976" no="1977-1989" no="1990-2002" no="2003-2015">
<textC no="1704-1724" no="1725-1745" no="1746-1766" no="1767-1787" no="1788-1808" no="1809-1829" no="1830-1850" no="1851-1871" no="1872-1892" no="1893-1913" no="1914-1934" no="1935-1955" no="1956-1976" no="1977-1997" no="1998-2018">
The Manchester Guardian of Wednesday gives a more gloomy account of the state of trade. "The little increase of demand for manufactured goods that appeared last week, arising from the execution of the orders brought by the steamer from the United States, appears to have now died away ; and the pressure for money continuing unabated, the market has now relapsed into its former state of dulness and inactivity. The yarn-market was also injuriously affected by unfavourable accounts from Germany ; where sales of yarn appear to have been checked by hostile rumours, and several orders for purchases in this country have been countermanded. On the whole, the market was very gloomy, and exhibited little promise of change until an improvement takes place in the state of the money-market.'
</text>

<text id="316lo32111105101">
<textF no="1700-1706" no="1707-1713" no="1714-1720" no="1721-1727" no="1728-1734" no="1735-1741" no="1742-1748" no="1749-1755" no="1756-1762" no="1763-1769" no="1770-1776" no="1777-1783" no="1784-1790" no="1791-1797" no="1798-1804" no="1805-1811" no="1812-1818" no="1819-1825" no="1826-1832" no="1833-1839" no="1840-1846" no="1847-1853" no="1854-1860" no="1861-1867" no="1868-1874" no="1875-1881" no="1882-1888" no="1889-1895" no="1896-1902" no="1903-1909" no="1910-1916" no="1917-1923" no="1924-1930" no="1931-1937" no="1938-1944" no="1945-1951" no="1952-1958" no="1959-1965" no="1966-1972" no="1973-1979" no="1980-1986" no="1987-1993" no="1994-2000" no="2001-2007" no="2008-2014">
<textM no="1704-1716" no="1717-1729" no="1730-1742" no="1743-1755" no="1756-1768" no="1769-1781" no="1782-1794" no="1795-1807" no="1808-1820" no="1821-1833" no="1834-1846" no="1847-1859" no="1860-1872" no="1873-1885" no="1886-1898" no="1899-1911" no="1912-1924" no="1925-1937" no="1938-1950" no="1951-1963" no="1964-1976" no="1977-1989" no="1990-2002" no="2003-2015">
<textC no="1700-1720" no="1721-1741" no="1742-1762" no="1763-1783" no="1784-1804" no="1805-1825" no="1826-1846" no="1847-1867" no="1868-1888" no="1889-1909" no="1910-1930" no="1931-1951" no="1952-1972" no="1973-1993" no="1994-2014">
Some of my Correspondents desire me to be always serious, and others to be always merry. Some of them entreat me to go to Bed . and fall into a Dream, and like me better when I am asleep than when I am awake : Others advice me stay all Night upon the Stars, and be more frequent in my Astrological Observations ;
</text>

<text id="445rk11810732110">
<textF no="1704-1710" no="1711-1717" no="1718-1724" no="1725-1731" no="1732-1738" no="1739-1745" no="1746-1752" no="1753-1759" no="1760-1766" no="1767-1773" no="1774-1780" no="1781-1787" no="1788-1794" no="1795-1801" no="1802-1808" no="1809-1815" no="1816-1822" no="1823-1829" no="1830-1836" no="1837-1843" no="1844-1850" no="1851-1857" no="1858-1864" no="1865-1871" no="1872-1878" no="1879-1885" no="1886-1892" no="1893-1899" no="1900-1906" no="1907-1913" no="1914-1920" no="1921-1927" no="1928-1934" no="1935-1941" no="1942-1948" no="1949-1955" no="1956-1962" no="1963-1969" no="1970-1976" no="1977-1983" no="1984-1990" no="1991-1997" no="1998-2004" no="2005-2011" no="2012-2018">
<textM no="1695-1707" no="1708-1720" no="1721-1733" no="1734-1746" no="1747-1759" no="1760-1772" no="1773-1785" no="1786-1798" no="1799-1811" no="1812-1824" no="1825-1837" no="1838-1850" no="1851-1863" no="1864-1876" no="1877-1889" no="1890-1902" no="1903-1915" no="1916-1928" no="1929-1941" no="1942-1954" no="1955-1967" no="1968-1980" no="1981-1993" no="1994-2006" no="2007-2019">
<textC no="1711-1731" no="1732-1752" no="1753-1773" no="1774-1794" no="1795-1815" no="1816-1836" no="1837-1857" no="1858-1878" no="1879-1899" no="1900-1920" no="1921-1941" no="1942-1962" no="1963-1983" no="1984-2004" no="2005-2025">
We have been talking things over, coming home,” said Olivia, acting as spokeswoman, “ and we have decided to say, once for all, that we refuse to look upon Mr. Davenport as a suitor any longer. In fact, we have, this evening, met gentlemen much more agreeable to us, as well as suitable in point of age. They are all three going to call, and we hope we shall not be expected to entertain Mr. Daven port.	We shall have pleasanter company
</text>

<text id="387kh3210111532">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">
<textM no="1700-1712" no="1713-1725" no="1726-1738" no="1739-1751" no="1752-1764" no="1765-1777" no="1778-1790" no="1791-1803" no="1804-1816" no="1817-1829" no="1830-1842" no="1843-1855" no="1856-1868" no="1869-1881" no="1882-1894" no="1895-1907" no="1908-1920" no="1921-1933" no="1934-1946" no="1947-1959" no="1960-1972" no="1973-1985" no="1986-1998" no="1999-2011" no="2012-2024">
<textC no="1701-1721" no="1722-1742" no="1743-1763" no="1764-1784" no="1785-1805" no="1806-1826" no="1827-1847" no="1848-1868" no="1869-1889" no="1890-1910" no="1911-1931" no="1932-1952" no="1953-1973" no="1974-1994" no="1995-2015">
One of the great Evils of a Salt Tax, I may say the greatest, because it strikes at our Constitution, if the great Number of Officers which must be employed in collecting that small Branch of the Revenue. These Officers all named by the Crown and being spread over the Country must have a great Influence in Elections: This, Sir throws a greater Power into the Hands of the Crown,
</text>

<text id="279mg111116110112">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1707-1719" no="1720-1732" no="1733-1745" no="1746-1758" no="1759-1771" no="1772-1784" no="1785-1797" no="1798-1810" no="1811-1823" no="1824-1836" no="1837-1849" no="1850-1862" no="1863-1875" no="1876-1888" no="1889-1901" no="1902-1914" no="1915-1927" no="1928-1940" no="1941-1953" no="1954-1966" no="1967-1979" no="1980-1992" no="1993-2005" no="2006-2018">
<textC no="1699-1719" no="1720-1740" no="1741-1761" no="1762-1782" no="1783-1803" no="1804-1824" no="1825-1845" no="1846-1866" no="1867-1887" no="1888-1908" no="1909-1929" no="1930-1950" no="1951-1971" no="1972-1992" no="1993-2013">
It is to beregretted that gentlemen by position should makethese indecorous exhibitions of themselves, as the French are apt to judge ex pede Herculem, and are never better pleased than when they can point out such features of what they call “ les mœurs Britanniques.”
</text>

<text id="110ti11632103112">
<textF no="1700-1706" no="1707-1713" no="1714-1720" no="1721-1727" no="1728-1734" no="1735-1741" no="1742-1748" no="1749-1755" no="1756-1762" no="1763-1769" no="1770-1776" no="1777-1783" no="1784-1790" no="1791-1797" no="1798-1804" no="1805-1811" no="1812-1818" no="1819-1825" no="1826-1832" no="1833-1839" no="1840-1846" no="1847-1853" no="1854-1860" no="1861-1867" no="1868-1874" no="1875-1881" no="1882-1888" no="1889-1895" no="1896-1902" no="1903-1909" no="1910-1916" no="1917-1923" no="1924-1930" no="1931-1937" no="1938-1944" no="1945-1951" no="1952-1958" no="1959-1965" no="1966-1972" no="1973-1979" no="1980-1986" no="1987-1993" no="1994-2000" no="2001-2007" no="2008-2014">
<textM no="1704-1716" no="1717-1729" no="1730-1742" no="1743-1755" no="1756-1768" no="1769-1781" no="1782-1794" no="1795-1807" no="1808-1820" no="1821-1833" no="1834-1846" no="1847-1859" no="1860-1872" no="1873-1885" no="1886-1898" no="1899-1911" no="1912-1924" no="1925-1937" no="1938-1950" no="1951-1963" no="1964-1976" no="1977-1989" no="1990-2002" no="2003-2015">
<textC no="1700-1720" no="1721-1741" no="1742-1762" no="1763-1783" no="1784-1804" no="1805-1825" no="1826-1846" no="1847-1867" no="1868-1888" no="1889-1909" no="1910-1930" no="1931-1951" no="1952-1972" no="1973-1993" no="1994-2014">
and that when I am in the greatest Repute within the Liberties, I dwindle at the Court End of the Town.
</text>

<text id="135kh32112114100">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">
<textM no="1705-1717" no="1718-1730" no="1731-1743" no="1744-1756" no="1757-1769" no="1770-1782" no="1783-1795" no="1796-1808" no="1809-1821" no="1822-1834" no="1835-1847" no="1848-1860" no="1861-1873" no="1874-1886" no="1887-1899" no="1900-1912" no="1913-1925" no="1926-1938" no="1939-1951" no="1952-1964" no="1965-1977" no="1978-1990" no="1991-2003" no="2004-2016">
<textC no="1701-1721" no="1722-1742" no="1743-1763" no="1764-1784" no="1785-1805" no="1806-1826" no="1827-1847" no="1848-1868" no="1869-1889" no="1890-1910" no="1911-1931" no="1932-1952" no="1953-1973" no="1974-1994" no="1995-2015">
abounds with the Spirit of Mirth and good Humour, which is natural to that Place, I shall set it down Word by Word as it came to me.
</text>

<text id="552aq10911099101">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1707-1719" no="1720-1732" no="1733-1745" no="1746-1758" no="1759-1771" no="1772-1784" no="1785-1797" no="1798-1810" no="1811-1823" no="1824-1836" no="1837-1849" no="1850-1862" no="1863-1875" no="1876-1888" no="1889-1901" no="1902-1914" no="1915-1927" no="1928-1940" no="1941-1953" no="1954-1966" no="1967-1979" no="1980-1992" no="1993-2005" no="2006-2018">
<textC no="1702-1722" no="1723-1743" no="1744-1764" no="1765-1785" no="1786-1806" no="1807-1827" no="1828-1848" no="1849-1869" no="1870-1890" no="1891-1911" no="1912-1932" no="1933-1953" no="1954-1974" no="1975-1995" no="1996-2016">
From my experiments I am inclined to believe, that Must is a taint produced by damp upon the amylaceous part of the grain or starch ; that the portion of starch nearest to the husk is that which is first tainted ; and that the greater or less degree of Must is in proportion to thetaint having penetrated more or less into the substance of the grain. In most cases, however, the taint is only superficial; but, nevertheless, if not removed, it is sufficient to contaminate the odour and flavour of the whole, especially when converted into flour.
</text>

<text id="279pm1141019997">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1703-1715" no="1716-1728" no="1729-1741" no="1742-1754" no="1755-1767" no="1768-1780" no="1781-1793" no="1794-1806" no="1807-1819" no="1820-1832" no="1833-1845" no="1846-1858" no="1859-1871" no="1872-1884" no="1885-1897" no="1898-1910" no="1911-1923" no="1924-1936" no="1937-1949" no="1950-1962" no="1963-1975" no="1976-1988" no="1989-2001" no="2002-2014">
<textC no="1699-1719" no="1720-1740" no="1741-1761" no="1762-1782" no="1783-1803" no="1804-1824" no="1825-1845" no="1846-1866" no="1867-1887" no="1888-1908" no="1909-1929" no="1930-1950" no="1951-1971" no="1972-1992" no="1993-2013">
The First Thing we took Notice of, was a Nobleman, of a goodly and frank Aspect, with his generous Birth and Temper visible in it, playing at Cards with a Creature of a black and horrid Countenance wherein were plainly delineated the Arts of his Mind, Cousenage and Falshood.
</text>

<text id="450jm44100114121">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1696-1708" no="1709-1721" no="1722-1734" no="1735-1747" no="1748-1760" no="1761-1773" no="1774-1786" no="1787-1799" no="1800-1812" no="1813-1825" no="1826-1838" no="1839-1851" no="1852-1864" no="1865-1877" no="1878-1890" no="1891-1903" no="1904-1916" no="1917-1929" no="1930-1942" no="1943-1955" no="1956-1968" no="1969-1981" no="1982-1994" no="1995-2007" no="2008-2020">
<textC no="1709-1729" no="1730-1750" no="1751-1771" no="1772-1792" no="1793-1813" no="1814-1834" no="1835-1855" no="1856-1876" no="1877-1897" no="1898-1918" no="1919-1939" no="1940-1960" no="1961-1981" no="1982-2002" no="2003-2023">
RUGBY, DERBY, AND MANCHESTER. Yesterday a special general meeting of the shareholders inthis undertaking was held at the London Tavern, for the purpose of receiving a report from the committee of management, and deciding upon the steps it would be advisable toadopt with reference to the prosecution of the undertaking in the next session of Parliament, or otherwise.Matthew Pierpoint, Esq., chairman of the committee of management, presided.
</text>

<text id="206em11110144110">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1706-1718" no="1719-1731" no="1732-1744" no="1745-1757" no="1758-1770" no="1771-1783" no="1784-1796" no="1797-1809" no="1810-1822" no="1823-1835" no="1836-1848" no="1849-1861" no="1862-1874" no="1875-1887" no="1888-1900" no="1901-1913" no="1914-1926" no="1927-1939" no="1940-1952" no="1953-1965" no="1966-1978" no="1979-1991" no="1992-2004" no="2005-2017">
<textC no="1702-1722" no="1723-1743" no="1744-1764" no="1765-1785" no="1786-1806" no="1807-1827" no="1828-1848" no="1849-1869" no="1870-1890" no="1891-1911" no="1912-1932" no="1933-1953" no="1954-1974" no="1975-1995" no="1996-2016">
the most delicate Cambricks, Muslins and Linnens. I could not but congratulated my Friend on the Buyable I hoped beneficial use he had made of his Talents, and I wish I could be a Patron of his Trade.
</text>

<text id="225tm1101003249">
<textF no="1703-1709" no="1710-1716" no="1717-1723" no="1724-1730" no="1731-1737" no="1738-1744" no="1745-1751" no="1752-1758" no="1759-1765" no="1766-1772" no="1773-1779" no="1780-1786" no="1787-1793" no="1794-1800" no="1801-1807" no="1808-1814" no="1815-1821" no="1822-1828" no="1829-1835" no="1836-1842" no="1843-1849" no="1850-1856" no="1857-1863" no="1864-1870" no="1871-1877" no="1878-1884" no="1885-1891" no="1892-1898" no="1899-1905" no="1906-1912" no="1913-1919" no="1920-1926" no="1927-1933" no="1934-1940" no="1941-1947" no="1948-1954" no="1955-1961" no="1962-1968" no="1969-1975" no="1976-1982" no="1983-1989" no="1990-1996" no="1997-2003" no="2004-2010" no="2011-2017">
<textM no="1702-1714" no="1715-1727" no="1728-1740" no="1741-1753" no="1754-1766" no="1767-1779" no="1780-1792" no="1793-1805" no="1806-1818" no="1819-1831" no="1832-1844" no="1845-1857" no="1858-1870" no="1871-1883" no="1884-1896" no="1897-1909" no="1910-1922" no="1923-1935" no="1936-1948" no="1949-1961" no="1962-1974" no="1975-1987" no="1988-2000" no="2001-2013">
<textC no="1703-1723" no="1724-1744" no="1745-1765" no="1766-1786" no="1787-1807" no="1808-1828" no="1829-1849" no="1850-1870" no="1871-1891" no="1892-1912" no="1913-1933" no="1934-1954" no="1955-1975" no="1976-1996" no="1997-2017">
STOLEN OR STRAY'D An Iron Grey MARE 13 Hands high with a Brush Tail three black spots on the near Side by the Flank about a Bigness of a Farthing. By the black Spots within the Skin there is a Lump as big as a Wallnut.
</text>

<text id="526pr1011039732">
<textF no="1703-1709" no="1710-1716" no="1717-1723" no="1724-1730" no="1731-1737" no="1738-1744" no="1745-1751" no="1752-1758" no="1759-1765" no="1766-1772" no="1773-1779" no="1780-1786" no="1787-1793" no="1794-1800" no="1801-1807" no="1808-1814" no="1815-1821" no="1822-1828" no="1829-1835" no="1836-1842" no="1843-1849" no="1850-1856" no="1857-1863" no="1864-1870" no="1871-1877" no="1878-1884" no="1885-1891" no="1892-1898" no="1899-1905" no="1906-1912" no="1913-1919" no="1920-1926" no="1927-1933" no="1934-1940" no="1941-1947" no="1948-1954" no="1955-1961" no="1962-1968" no="1969-1975" no="1976-1982" no="1983-1989" no="1990-1996" no="1997-2003" no="2004-2010" no="2011-2017">
<textM no="1696-1708" no="1709-1721" no="1722-1734" no="1735-1747" no="1748-1760" no="1761-1773" no="1774-1786" no="1787-1799" no="1800-1812" no="1813-1825" no="1826-1838" no="1839-1851" no="1852-1864" no="1865-1877" no="1878-1890" no="1891-1903" no="1904-1916" no="1917-1929" no="1930-1942" no="1943-1955" no="1956-1968" no="1969-1981" no="1982-1994" no="1995-2007" no="2008-2020">
<textC no="1696-1716" no="1717-1737" no="1738-1758" no="1759-1779" no="1780-1800" no="1801-1821" no="1822-1842" no="1843-1863" no="1864-1884" no="1885-1905" no="1906-1926" no="1927-1947" no="1948-1968" no="1969-1989" no="1990-2010" no="2011-2031">
The Duke of BUCKINGHAM, when appealed to by his friend the • Bishop, expressed his extreme surprise to see in the Times certain verbatim extracts from this celebrated letter ; and Lord GREY was also surprised to find there, one account says a notice, another an extract. This was Act First. Comparisons are odorous, and we make none; but the language of RADICAL and that of a well-known gentleman in another comedy (not so pleasant a one) are so much alike, that we confess- we think RADICAL must have had him in his eye
</text>

<text id="440sg11210111832">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1703-1715" no="1716-1728" no="1729-1741" no="1742-1754" no="1755-1767" no="1768-1780" no="1781-1793" no="1794-1806" no="1807-1819" no="1820-1832" no="1833-1845" no="1846-1858" no="1859-1871" no="1872-1884" no="1885-1897" no="1898-1910" no="1911-1923" no="1924-1936" no="1937-1949" no="1950-1962" no="1963-1975" no="1976-1988" no="1989-2001" no="2002-2014">
<textC no="1699-1719" no="1720-1740" no="1741-1761" no="1762-1782" no="1783-1803" no="1804-1824" no="1825-1845" no="1846-1866" no="1867-1887" no="1888-1908" no="1909-1929" no="1930-1950" no="1951-1971" no="1972-1992" no="1993-2013">
But my Pain made me exalt my Voice above hers, which brought up the Nurie, (the Witch I first saw) and myGrandmother. The Girl is turn'd down Stairs, and I strip'd again, as well to find what hurt me, as to satisfy my Grannam's further Curiosity. This good old Woman's visit was the Cause of all my Troubles. You are to understand, that I was hitherto bred to Hand, and any Body that stood next gave me Pap, if I did but open my Lips;
</text>

<text id="204ka1003297110">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">
<textM no="1700-1712" no="1713-1725" no="1726-1738" no="1739-1751" no="1752-1764" no="1765-1777" no="1778-1790" no="1791-1803" no="1804-1816" no="1817-1829" no="1830-1842" no="1843-1855" no="1856-1868" no="1869-1881" no="1882-1894" no="1895-1907" no="1908-1920" no="1921-1933" no="1934-1946" no="1947-1959" no="1960-1972" no="1973-1985" no="1986-1998" no="1999-2011" no="2012-2024">
<textC no="1701-1721" no="1722-1742" no="1743-1763" no="1764-1784" no="1785-1805" no="1806-1826" no="1827-1847" no="1848-1868" no="1869-1889" no="1890-1910" no="1911-1931" no="1932-1952" no="1953-1973" no="1974-1994" no="1995-2015">
The Land-Tax, Sir, is but an annual Diminution of a Gentleman's Estate , and have one of the Two now under Consideration necessary, we ought now to examine strictly which of the two is the least Evil.
</text>

<text id="257jo1173299114">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">
<textM no="1707-1719" no="1720-1732" no="1733-1745" no="1746-1758" no="1759-1771" no="1772-1784" no="1785-1797" no="1798-1810" no="1811-1823" no="1824-1836" no="1837-1849" no="1850-1862" no="1863-1875" no="1876-1888" no="1889-1901" no="1902-1914" no="1915-1927" no="1928-1940" no="1941-1953" no="1954-1966" no="1967-1979" no="1980-1992" no="1993-2005" no="2006-2018">
<textC no="1708-1728" no="1729-1749" no="1750-1770" no="1771-1791" no="1792-1812" no="1813-1833" no="1834-1854" no="1855-1875" no="1876-1896" no="1897-1917" no="1918-1938" no="1939-1959" no="1960-1980" no="1981-2001" no="2002-2022">
Last Thursday came on the Election of a Representative in Parliament for Leicestershire, at the County Town, where, at a great Appearance of Gentlemen of Family and Fortunes, Lord Guernsey, eldest Son to the Earl of Aylesford, was unanimously chosen.
</text>

<text id="437lh3210811732">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1707-1719" no="1720-1732" no="1733-1745" no="1746-1758" no="1759-1771" no="1772-1784" no="1785-1797" no="1798-1810" no="1811-1823" no="1824-1836" no="1837-1849" no="1850-1862" no="1863-1875" no="1876-1888" no="1889-1901" no="1902-1914" no="1915-1927" no="1928-1940" no="1941-1953" no="1954-1966" no="1967-1979" no="1980-1992" no="1993-2005" no="2006-2018">
<textC no="1702-1722" no="1723-1743" no="1744-1764" no="1765-1785" no="1786-1806" no="1807-1827" no="1828-1848" no="1849-1869" no="1870-1890" no="1891-1911" no="1912-1932" no="1933-1953" no="1954-1974" no="1975-1995" no="1996-2016">
To be SOLD, the LEASE and FURNITURE of an eligible and yery airy RESIDENCE, near St. James’s Park, having breakfast, eating,-and drawing rooms, five bedchambers, two dressing rooms, entrance hall, sufficient offices, and good garden at the back, fit for immediate occupation, and instant possesion can be had.— Particulars, &c. to be had of Mr. Palmer Estate Agent, 98, Wimpole-street, Cavendish-square. Letters to be post free.
</text>

<text id="420fg115110103103">
<textF no="1703-1709" no="1710-1716" no="1717-1723" no="1724-1730" no="1731-1737" no="1738-1744" no="1745-1751" no="1752-1758" no="1759-1765" no="1766-1772" no="1773-1779" no="1780-1786" no="1787-1793" no="1794-1800" no="1801-1807" no="1808-1814" no="1815-1821" no="1822-1828" no="1829-1835" no="1836-1842" no="1843-1849" no="1850-1856" no="1857-1863" no="1864-1870" no="1871-1877" no="1878-1884" no="1885-1891" no="1892-1898" no="1899-1905" no="1906-1912" no="1913-1919" no="1920-1926" no="1927-1933" no="1934-1940" no="1941-1947" no="1948-1954" no="1955-1961" no="1962-1968" no="1969-1975" no="1976-1982" no="1983-1989" no="1990-1996" no="1997-2003" no="2004-2010" no="2011-2017">
<textM no="1700-1712" no="1713-1725" no="1726-1738" no="1739-1751" no="1752-1764" no="1765-1777" no="1778-1790" no="1791-1803" no="1804-1816" no="1817-1829" no="1830-1842" no="1843-1855" no="1856-1868" no="1869-1881" no="1882-1894" no="1895-1907" no="1908-1920" no="1921-1933" no="1934-1946" no="1947-1959" no="1960-1972" no="1973-1985" no="1986-1998" no="1999-2011" no="2012-2024">
<textC no="1696-1716" no="1717-1737" no="1738-1758" no="1759-1779" no="1780-1800" no="1801-1821" no="1822-1842" no="1843-1863" no="1864-1884" no="1885-1905" no="1906-1926" no="1927-1947" no="1948-1968" no="1969-1989" no="1990-2010" no="2011-2031">
Commission of Bankrupt being awarded against Robert Barnewell, late of London, Merchant and he having surrendred himself to the Commissioners, and been examined : These are to give Notice, That he will attend them on Friday the 6th of December next, at 9 at Say's Coffee-house on Ludgate-hill, to finish his Examination, when and where his Creditors may attend, to shew Cause why a Certificate should not be signed.
</text>

<text id="166ts1161099832">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1696-1708" no="1709-1721" no="1722-1734" no="1735-1747" no="1748-1760" no="1761-1773" no="1774-1786" no="1787-1799" no="1800-1812" no="1813-1825" no="1826-1838" no="1839-1851" no="1852-1864" no="1865-1877" no="1878-1890" no="1891-1903" no="1904-1916" no="1917-1929" no="1930-1942" no="1943-1955" no="1956-1968" no="1969-1981" no="1982-1994" no="1995-2007" no="2008-2020">
<textC no="1709-1729" no="1730-1750" no="1751-1771" no="1772-1792" no="1793-1813" no="1814-1834" no="1835-1855" no="1856-1876" no="1877-1897" no="1898-1918" no="1919-1939" no="1940-1960" no="1961-1981" no="1982-2002" no="2003-2023">
he leant on the arm of the Noble Earl by his side and was borne on board the boat while loud cries of "God bless him" May God restore his health again fill the air
</text>

<text id="633rl11132102100">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1707-1719" no="1720-1732" no="1733-1745" no="1746-1758" no="1759-1771" no="1772-1784" no="1785-1797" no="1798-1810" no="1811-1823" no="1824-1836" no="1837-1849" no="1850-1862" no="1863-1875" no="1876-1888" no="1889-1901" no="1902-1914" no="1915-1927" no="1928-1940" no="1941-1953" no="1954-1966" no="1967-1979" no="1980-1992" no="1993-2005" no="2006-2018">
<textC no="1702-1722" no="1723-1743" no="1744-1764" no="1765-1785" no="1786-1806" no="1807-1827" no="1828-1848" no="1849-1869" no="1870-1890" no="1891-1911" no="1912-1932" no="1933-1953" no="1954-1974" no="1975-1995" no="1996-2016">
Might not the same twisting of the threads, which is found to give compactness and strength to hemp and flax, be employed with advantage to increase the tenacity of the particles of iron r Is there not something analogous to this in the waved structure of the gun-barrel, which is known to be particularly tough ? And may not the superior quality of the Damascus sword blades, which is still a problem to our manufacturers, be owing to some such management ? Their structure would answer exactly to the idea of small rods of iron and steel welded and twist- ed together, and afterwards beat out. The experiment is worth the trial.
</text>

<text id="262it99329732">
<textF no="1704-1710" no="1711-1717" no="1718-1724" no="1725-1731" no="1732-1738" no="1739-1745" no="1746-1752" no="1753-1759" no="1760-1766" no="1767-1773" no="1774-1780" no="1781-1787" no="1788-1794" no="1795-1801" no="1802-1808" no="1809-1815" no="1816-1822" no="1823-1829" no="1830-1836" no="1837-1843" no="1844-1850" no="1851-1857" no="1858-1864" no="1865-1871" no="1872-1878" no="1879-1885" no="1886-1892" no="1893-1899" no="1900-1906" no="1907-1913" no="1914-1920" no="1921-1927" no="1928-1934" no="1935-1941" no="1942-1948" no="1949-1955" no="1956-1962" no="1963-1969" no="1970-1976" no="1977-1983" no="1984-1990" no="1991-1997" no="1998-2004" no="2005-2011" no="2012-2018">
<textM no="1695-1707" no="1708-1720" no="1721-1733" no="1734-1746" no="1747-1759" no="1760-1772" no="1773-1785" no="1786-1798" no="1799-1811" no="1812-1824" no="1825-1837" no="1838-1850" no="1851-1863" no="1864-1876" no="1877-1889" no="1890-1902" no="1903-1915" no="1916-1928" no="1929-1941" no="1942-1954" no="1955-1967" no="1968-1980" no="1981-1993" no="1994-2006" no="2007-2019">
<textC no="1704-1724" no="1725-1745" no="1746-1766" no="1767-1787" no="1788-1808" no="1809-1829" no="1830-1850" no="1851-1871" no="1872-1892" no="1893-1913" no="1914-1934" no="1935-1955" no="1956-1976" no="1977-1997" no="1998-2018">
Merchants, and others, that they may be furnish'd by Josias Green, Hat-maker, next Door to the Catherine- Whel Inn, in the Borough, Southwark, with good Beaverets for 12s per Hat, with Silk Linings 5 also Carolina's Cloth Beaver Carolina for 7s 6d Each.

<text id="452rn10011134101">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1698-1710" no="1711-1723" no="1724-1736" no="1737-1749" no="1750-1762" no="1763-1775" no="1776-1788" no="1789-1801" no="1802-1814" no="1815-1827" no="1828-1840" no="1841-1853" no="1854-1866" no="1867-1879" no="1880-1892" no="1893-1905" no="1906-1918" no="1919-1931" no="1932-1944" no="1945-1957" no="1958-1970" no="1971-1983" no="1984-1996" no="1997-2009" no="2010-2022">
<textC no="1695-1715" no="1716-1736" no="1737-1757" no="1758-1778" no="1779-1799" no="1800-1820" no="1821-1841" no="1842-1862" no="1863-1883" no="1884-1904" no="1905-1925" no="1926-1946" no="1947-1967" no="1968-1988" no="1989-2009" no="2010-2030">
He has done good work in his "time. Since 1808 he has not ceased to intrigue against his comrades of the International, and to hold them up to the European Governments as the most atrocious rascals everbanded together for revolutionary purposes. Hefounded an opposition even in the very midst of the International itself, called the "Alliance of Socialist Democracy," .whose propaganda was even more bloodthirsty than any International ever founded
</text>

<text id="486fl100104108101">
<textF no="1703-1709" no="1710-1716" no="1717-1723" no="1724-1730" no="1731-1737" no="1738-1744" no="1745-1751" no="1752-1758" no="1759-1765" no="1766-1772" no="1773-1779" no="1780-1786" no="1787-1793" no="1794-1800" no="1801-1807" no="1808-1814" no="1815-1821" no="1822-1828" no="1829-1835" no="1836-1842" no="1843-1849" no="1850-1856" no="1857-1863" no="1864-1870" no="1871-1877" no="1878-1884" no="1885-1891" no="1892-1898" no="1899-1905" no="1906-1912" no="1913-1919" no="1920-1926" no="1927-1933" no="1934-1940" no="1941-1947" no="1948-1954" no="1955-1961" no="1962-1968" no="1969-1975" no="1976-1982" no="1983-1989" no="1990-1996" no="1997-2003" no="2004-2010" no="2011-2017">
<textM no="1700-1712" no="1713-1725" no="1726-1738" no="1739-1751" no="1752-1764" no="1765-1777" no="1778-1790" no="1791-1803" no="1804-1816" no="1817-1829" no="1830-1842" no="1843-1855" no="1856-1868" no="1869-1881" no="1882-1894" no="1895-1907" no="1908-1920" no="1921-1933" no="1934-1946" no="1947-1959" no="1960-1972" no="1973-1985" no="1986-1998" no="1999-2011" no="2012-2024">
<textC no="1710-1730" no="1731-1751" no="1752-1772" no="1773-1793" no="1794-1814" no="1815-1835" no="1836-1856" no="1857-1877" no="1878-1898" no="1899-1919" no="1920-1940" no="1941-1961" no="1962-1982" no="1983-2003" no="2004-2024">
The cold weather which prevails has the effect of favouring the consumption of house coal, so that business is better than is usually the case at this period of the year. The Midland and Great Northern Railway Companies are collecting and forwarding a very fair tonnage of Silkstone and Barnsley thick seam coal to the metropolis. Merchants carrying on business in the eastern counties are drawing about average supplies of house and other kinds of coal from the district collieries.
</text>

<text id="422jo9711599116">
<textF no="1703-1709" no="1710-1716" no="1717-1723" no="1724-1730" no="1731-1737" no="1738-1744" no="1745-1751" no="1752-1758" no="1759-1765" no="1766-1772" no="1773-1779" no="1780-1786" no="1787-1793" no="1794-1800" no="1801-1807" no="1808-1814" no="1815-1821" no="1822-1828" no="1829-1835" no="1836-1842" no="1843-1849" no="1850-1856" no="1857-1863" no="1864-1870" no="1871-1877" no="1878-1884" no="1885-1891" no="1892-1898" no="1899-1905" no="1906-1912" no="1913-1919" no="1920-1926" no="1927-1933" no="1934-1940" no="1941-1947" no="1948-1954" no="1955-1961" no="1962-1968" no="1969-1975" no="1976-1982" no="1983-1989" no="1990-1996" no="1997-2003" no="2004-2010" no="2011-2017">
<textM no="1702-1714" no="1715-1727" no="1728-1740" no="1741-1753" no="1754-1766" no="1767-1779" no="1780-1792" no="1793-1805" no="1806-1818" no="1819-1831" no="1832-1844" no="1845-1857" no="1858-1870" no="1871-1883" no="1884-1896" no="1897-1909" no="1910-1922" no="1923-1935" no="1936-1948" no="1949-1961" no="1962-1974" no="1975-1987" no="1988-2000" no="2001-2013">
<textC no="1703-1723" no="1724-1744" no="1745-1765" no="1766-1786" no="1787-1807" no="1808-1828" no="1829-1849" no="1850-1870" no="1871-1891" no="1892-1912" no="1913-1933" no="1934-1954" no="1955-1975" no="1976-1996" no="1997-2017">
This Day is publish'd, THE Compleat Attorney's Practice in English, in the Courts of King's-Bench and Common Pleas at Westminster : Containing the best Rules and Methods of Practice therein from the Commencement of the Action to the Execution and also Forms of Original and Judicial Writs and Process Pleadings, Demurrers, Issues and Records or Trial, Judgments, Writs of Error, &C. of any Book hitherto publish'd.
</text>

<text id="738dk1014497101">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1696-1708" no="1709-1721" no="1722-1734" no="1735-1747" no="1748-1760" no="1761-1773" no="1774-1786" no="1787-1799" no="1800-1812" no="1813-1825" no="1826-1838" no="1839-1851" no="1852-1864" no="1865-1877" no="1878-1890" no="1891-1903" no="1904-1916" no="1917-1929" no="1930-1942" no="1943-1955" no="1956-1968" no="1969-1981" no="1982-1994" no="1995-2007" no="2008-2020">
<textC no="1709-1729" no="1730-1750" no="1751-1771" no="1772-1792" no="1793-1813" no="1814-1834" no="1835-1855" no="1856-1876" no="1877-1897" no="1898-1918" no="1919-1939" no="1940-1960" no="1961-1981" no="1982-2002" no="2003-2023">
Mahomed Ali'son , Ibrahim Pacha left Perpignan for Vernet, Hautes Pyrenees. and the weather beingfine a large crowd followed the Egyptian cortège beyond the town. Lieutemant-General Castellane, Commander-in- Chief of the 6th Military Divison, accompanied by the prefect of the department, and followed by a numerous st , rode by the side of the Pacha's carriage, and on dismounting to bid him farewell, his Highness insisted upon descending to receive their adieux, which he did with all the sententious courtesy of a true oriental. On the 6th he dined with the Count de Castellane, and charmed the company by his manners, which appear to be a happy mélengeo Frenchpoliteness and chattiness and eastern gravity and hyperbole,
</text>

<text id="147gn11410811797">
<textF no="1704-1710" no="1711-1717" no="1718-1724" no="1725-1731" no="1732-1738" no="1739-1745" no="1746-1752" no="1753-1759" no="1760-1766" no="1767-1773" no="1774-1780" no="1781-1787" no="1788-1794" no="1795-1801" no="1802-1808" no="1809-1815" no="1816-1822" no="1823-1829" no="1830-1836" no="1837-1843" no="1844-1850" no="1851-1857" no="1858-1864" no="1865-1871" no="1872-1878" no="1879-1885" no="1886-1892" no="1893-1899" no="1900-1906" no="1907-1913" no="1914-1920" no="1921-1927" no="1928-1934" no="1935-1941" no="1942-1948" no="1949-1955" no="1956-1962" no="1963-1969" no="1970-1976" no="1977-1983" no="1984-1990" no="1991-1997" no="1998-2004" no="2005-2011" no="2012-2018">

<textC no="1704-1724" no="1725-1745" no="1746-1766" no="1767-1787" no="1788-1808" no="1809-1829" no="1830-1850" no="1851-1871" no="1872-1892" no="1893-1913" no="1914-1934" no="1935-1955" no="1956-1976" no="1977-1997" no="1998-2018">
The French Consul has discours'd several Moors upon that Point, who all say they have been there but they do not agree in their Account of it.
</text>

<text id="185mt11132112105">
<textF no="1704-1710" no="1711-1717" no="1718-1724" no="1725-1731" no="1732-1738" no="1739-1745" no="1746-1752" no="1753-1759" no="1760-1766" no="1767-1773" no="1774-1780" no="1781-1787" no="1788-1794" no="1795-1801" no="1802-1808" no="1809-1815" no="1816-1822" no="1823-1829" no="1830-1836" no="1837-1843" no="1844-1850" no="1851-1857" no="1858-1864" no="1865-1871" no="1872-1878" no="1879-1885" no="1886-1892" no="1893-1899" no="1900-1906" no="1907-1913" no="1914-1920" no="1921-1927" no="1928-1934" no="1935-1941" no="1942-1948" no="1949-1955" no="1956-1962" no="1963-1969" no="1970-1976" no="1977-1983" no="1984-1990" no="1991-1997" no="1998-2004" no="2005-2011" no="2012-2018">

From Rome we hear that the Epidemical Distemper begins to abate. We hear that a Distemper rages at [resent at Paris which they call Gripes, that carries off great Numbers of People.
</text>

<text id="212qn323210797">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">

as however many spurious and inferior preparations are sold under the same and similar names the public are requested to observes as the only proof of its being genuine that he name of Henry Manchester are engraved on the stamp.

<text id="291ql1014932115">
<textF no="1703-1709" no="1710-1716" no="1717-1723" no="1724-1730" no="1731-1737" no="1738-1744" no="1745-1751" no="1752-1758" no="1759-1765" no="1766-1772" no="1773-1779" no="1780-1786" no="1787-1793" no="1794-1800" no="1801-1807" no="1808-1814" no="1815-1821" no="1822-1828" no="1829-1835" no="1836-1842" no="1843-1849" no="1850-1856" no="1857-1863" no="1864-1870" no="1871-1877" no="1878-1884" no="1885-1891" no="1892-1898" no="1899-1905" no="1906-1912" no="1913-1919" no="1920-1926" no="1927-1933" no="1934-1940" no="1941-1947" no="1948-1954" no="1955-1961" no="1962-1968" no="1969-1975" no="1976-1982" no="1983-1989" no="1990-1996" no="1997-2003" no="2004-2010" no="2011-2017">
<textM no="1702-1714" no="1715-1727" no="1728-1740" no="1741-1753" no="1754-1766" no="1767-1779" no="1780-1792" no="1793-1805" no="1806-1818" no="1819-1831" no="1832-1844" no="1845-1857" no="1858-1870" no="1871-1883" no="1884-1896" no="1897-1909" no="1910-1922" no="1923-1935" no="1936-1948" no="1949-1961" no="1962-1974" no="1975-1987" no="1988-2000" no="2001-2013">
<textC no="1703-1723" no="1724-1744" no="1745-1765" no="1766-1786" no="1787-1807" no="1808-1828" no="1829-1849" no="1850-1870" no="1871-1891" no="1892-1912" no="1913-1933" no="1934-1954" no="1955-1975" no="1976-1996" no="1997-2017">
On Wednesday the 31ft of July next a Purse of Thirty Pounds in Money by any Horse Mare or Gelding nor exceeding six Years old last Grass carrying 10 Stone paying one Guinea and half Entrance, the second best to have the Srakes. Certificates to be produc'd under the Hands of the Breeders.
</text>

<text id="529kj11232105104">
<textF no="1702-1708" no="1709-1715" no="1716-1722" no="1723-1729" no="1730-1736" no="1737-1743" no="1744-1750" no="1751-1757" no="1758-1764" no="1765-1771" no="1772-1778" no="1779-1785" no="1786-1792" no="1793-1799" no="1800-1806" no="1807-1813" no="1814-1820" no="1821-1827" no="1828-1834" no="1835-1841" no="1842-1848" no="1849-1855" no="1856-1862" no="1863-1869" no="1870-1876" no="1877-1883" no="1884-1890" no="1891-1897" no="1898-1904" no="1905-1911" no="1912-1918" no="1919-1925" no="1926-1932" no="1933-1939" no="1940-1946" no="1947-1953" no="1954-1960" no="1961-1967" no="1968-1974" no="1975-1981" no="1982-1988" no="1989-1995" no="1996-2002" no="2003-2009" no="2010-2016">
<textM no="1707-1719" no="1720-1732" no="1733-1745" no="1746-1758" no="1759-1771" no="1772-1784" no="1785-1797" no="1798-1810" no="1811-1823" no="1824-1836" no="1837-1849" no="1850-1862" no="1863-1875" no="1876-1888" no="1889-1901" no="1902-1914" no="1915-1927" no="1928-1940" no="1941-1953" no="1954-1966" no="1967-1979" no="1980-1992" no="1993-2005" no="2006-2018">
<textC no="1702-1722" no="1723-1743" no="1744-1764" no="1765-1785" no="1786-1806" no="1807-1827" no="1828-1848" no="1849-1869" no="1870-1890" no="1891-1911" no="1912-1932" no="1933-1953" no="1954-1974" no="1975-1995" no="1996-2016">
or by applying the wax (sometimes by machinery) to the surface of the calico, or other cloth, in the same or in a manner similar to that by which the flint is applied in the process of glazing ; that is to say : The calico remained stationary while the wax applied to it was kept in motion, or the web was made to move slowly along the table, the wax being at the same time kept in motion ; but by my said invention, the calico, or any other cloth, to be waxed, is made to rub against the wax while the wax is kept stationary.
</text>

<text id="368gi11197110105">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1697-1709" no="1710-1722" no="1723-1735" no="1736-1748" no="1749-1761" no="1762-1774" no="1775-1787" no="1788-1800" no="1801-1813" no="1814-1826" no="1827-1839" no="1840-1852" no="1853-1865" no="1866-1878" no="1879-1891" no="1892-1904" no="1905-1917" no="1918-1930" no="1931-1943" no="1944-1956" no="1957-1969" no="1970-1982" no="1983-1995" no="1996-2008" no="2009-2021">
<textC no="1706-1726" no="1727-1747" no="1748-1768" no="1769-1789" no="1790-1810" no="1811-1831" no="1832-1852" no="1853-1873" no="1874-1894" no="1895-1915" no="1916-1936" no="1937-1957" no="1958-1978" no="1979-1999" no="2000-2020">
Session of Parliament then next followingthat the Commissioners of the Treachery, or the Lord High Treasury for the Time being, be impower'd, out of the publick Supplies granted in this Session of Parliament, to furnish so much as, together with the Coinage-Duty., may make up up any Sum nor exceeding fifteen Thousand Pounds per annum, to carry on the Coinage.
</text>

<text id="310ak117111105114">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1704-1716" no="1717-1729" no="1730-1742" no="1743-1755" no="1756-1768" no="1769-1781" no="1782-1794" no="1795-1807" no="1808-1820" no="1821-1833" no="1834-1846" no="1847-1859" no="1860-1872" no="1873-1885" no="1886-1898" no="1899-1911" no="1912-1924" no="1925-1937" no="1938-1950" no="1951-1963" no="1964-1976" no="1977-1989" no="1990-2002" no="2003-2015">
<textC no="1699-1719" no="1720-1740" no="1741-1761" no="1762-1782" no="1783-1803" no="1804-1824" no="1825-1845" no="1846-1866" no="1867-1887" no="1888-1908" no="1909-1929" no="1930-1950" no="1951-1971" no="1972-1992" no="1993-2013">
And though a Hindoowould shrink with horror from the idea of directly slaying a cow, which is a sacredanimal among them; yet be who drive, one in his cart, galled and excoriated as she often is by the yoke, beast her un-mercifully from hour to hour, without, any care or consideration of the consequence.
</text>

<text id="356mc971153232">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">
<textM no="1699-1711" no="1712-1724" no="1725-1737" no="1738-1750" no="1751-1763" no="1764-1776" no="1777-1789" no="1790-1802" no="1803-1815" no="1816-1828" no="1829-1841" no="1842-1854" no="1855-1867" no="1868-1880" no="1881-1893" no="1894-1906" no="1907-1919" no="1920-1932" no="1933-1945" no="1946-1958" no="1959-1971" no="1972-1984" no="1985-1997" no="1998-2010" no="2011-2023">
<textC no="1708-1728" no="1729-1749" no="1750-1770" no="1771-1791" no="1792-1812" no="1813-1833" no="1834-1854" no="1855-1875" no="1876-1896" no="1897-1917" no="1918-1938" no="1939-1959" no="1960-1980" no="1981-2001" no="2002-2022">
Wednesday at A Session of the High Court of Admiralty at the Old Baily, one Henry Jackson a Mariner was try' d for a Mutiny on board the Ship Hocknell, Capt. Short, bound to the Plantations with thirty Preston Prisoners, whom they set on Shoar at St. Martins in France, and disposed of the Cargo : He was found Guilty, and received Sentence of Death.
</text>

<text id="286ie10211110697">
<textF no="1703-1709" no="1710-1716" no="1717-1723" no="1724-1730" no="1731-1737" no="1738-1744" no="1745-1751" no="1752-1758" no="1759-1765" no="1766-1772" no="1773-1779" no="1780-1786" no="1787-1793" no="1794-1800" no="1801-1807" no="1808-1814" no="1815-1821" no="1822-1828" no="1829-1835" no="1836-1842" no="1843-1849" no="1850-1856" no="1857-1863" no="1864-1870" no="1871-1877" no="1878-1884" no="1885-1891" no="1892-1898" no="1899-1905" no="1906-1912" no="1913-1919" no="1920-1926" no="1927-1933" no="1934-1940" no="1941-1947" no="1948-1954" no="1955-1961" no="1962-1968" no="1969-1975" no="1976-1982" no="1983-1989" no="1990-1996" no="1997-2003" no="2004-2010" no="2011-2017">

<textC no="1703-1723" no="1724-1744" no="1745-1765" no="1766-1786" no="1787-1807" no="1808-1828" no="1829-1849" no="1850-1870" no="1871-1891" no="1892-1912" no="1913-1933" no="1934-1954" no="1955-1975" no="1976-1996" no="1997-2017">
It was further resolved that J. H. St Vrain, the manager of the Tacoma club, for his action in refusing to abide by the mandates of the national board, and in permitting himself to be used by Charles Frank, be penalized in the sum of $100, and stay suspended until the fine is paid.
</text>

<text id="302nh97101108114">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1703-1715" no="1716-1728" no="1729-1741" no="1742-1754" no="1755-1767" no="1768-1780" no="1781-1793" no="1794-1806" no="1807-1819" no="1820-1832" no="1833-1845" no="1846-1858" no="1859-1871" no="1872-1884" no="1885-1897" no="1898-1910" no="1911-1923" no="1924-1936" no="1937-1949" no="1950-1962" no="1963-1975" no="1976-1988" no="1989-2001" no="2002-2014">
<textC no="1706-1726" no="1727-1747" no="1748-1768" no="1769-1789" no="1790-1810" no="1811-1831" no="1832-1852" no="1853-1873" no="1874-1894" no="1895-1915" no="1916-1936" no="1937-1957" no="1958-1978" no="1979-1999" no="2000-2020">
Yesterday Joseph Perry, a well-known character, was examined before R. Ford, Esq. oncarge of picking the pocket of George Welch, Esq. of a gold watch, the precedingnight, in a street near Drury-Lane Theatre. The Prisoner, who "positively denied thecharge, was committed for further examination.
</text>

<text id="127ak11511649119">
<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">
<textM no="1700-1712" no="1713-1725" no="1726-1738" no="1739-1751" no="1752-1764" no="1765-1777" no="1778-1790" no="1791-1803" no="1804-1816" no="1817-1829" no="1830-1842" no="1843-1855" no="1856-1868" no="1869-1881" no="1882-1894" no="1895-1907" no="1908-1920" no="1921-1933" no="1934-1946" no="1947-1959" no="1960-1972" no="1973-1985" no="1986-1998" no="1999-2011" no="2012-2024">
<textC no="1701-1721" no="1722-1742" no="1743-1763" no="1764-1784" no="1785-1805" no="1806-1826" no="1827-1847" no="1848-1868" no="1869-1889" no="1890-1910" no="1911-1931" no="1932-1952" no="1953-1973" no="1974-1994" no="1995-2015">
Part was an Account of about 1400l. allowed him for Charges expended Session of Parliament, and the Remainder was in Mcney.
</text>

<text id="1022ac1173232101">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1704-1716" no="1717-1729" no="1730-1742" no="1743-1755" no="1756-1768" no="1769-1781" no="1782-1794" no="1795-1807" no="1808-1820" no="1821-1833" no="1834-1846" no="1847-1859" no="1860-1872" no="1873-1885" no="1886-1898" no="1899-1911" no="1912-1924" no="1925-1937" no="1938-1950" no="1951-1963" no="1964-1976" no="1977-1989" no="1990-2002" no="2003-2015">
<textC no="1706-1726" no="1727-1747" no="1748-1768" no="1769-1789" no="1790-1810" no="1811-1831" no="1832-1852" no="1853-1873" no="1874-1894" no="1895-1915" no="1916-1936" no="1937-1957" no="1958-1978" no="1979-1999" no="2000-2020">
A serious deadlock has arisen between Sweden and Norway over the question of the separate Consular service which Norway seeks to establish. Both Governments admit that the negotiations cannot be continued on the stipulated basis, and the King in Council, while ordering them to be suspended, appeals to his subjects in both countries not to allow any difference of opinion in the matter to weaken the bond of union between them. That this is no mere form of words is shown by the significant speech delivered by Dr. Hagerup, Minister of State, before the Storthing on Wednesday at Christiania. The Norwegians, he declares, are most anxious to maintain peaceful relations and a good understanding with the Swedes, but " the present conditions of union are indefensible, and cannot continue without endangering such relations. It is therefore our task to see that unrestricted provision shall be made for the assumption by Norway of the national and international position to which she is entitled as a sovereign State."
</text>

<text id="332on101329732">
<textF no="1703-1709" no="1710-1716" no="1717-1723" no="1724-1730" no="1731-1737" no="1738-1744" no="1745-1751" no="1752-1758" no="1759-1765" no="1766-1772" no="1773-1779" no="1780-1786" no="1787-1793" no="1794-1800" no="1801-1807" no="1808-1814" no="1815-1821" no="1822-1828" no="1829-1835" no="1836-1842" no="1843-1849" no="1850-1856" no="1857-1863" no="1864-1870" no="1871-1877" no="1878-1884" no="1885-1891" no="1892-1898" no="1899-1905" no="1906-1912" no="1913-1919" no="1920-1926" no="1927-1933" no="1934-1940" no="1941-1947" no="1948-1954" no="1955-1961" no="1962-1968" no="1969-1975" no="1976-1982" no="1983-1989" no="1990-1996" no="1997-2003" no="2004-2010" no="2011-2017">
<textM no="1696-1708" no="1709-1721" no="1722-1734" no="1735-1747" no="1748-1760" no="1761-1773" no="1774-1786" no="1787-1799" no="1800-1812" no="1813-1825" no="1826-1838" no="1839-1851" no="1852-1864" no="1865-1877" no="1878-1890" no="1891-1903" no="1904-1916" no="1917-1929" no="1930-1942" no="1943-1955" no="1956-1968" no="1969-1981" no="1982-1994" no="1995-2007" no="2008-2020">
<textC no="1710-1730" no="1731-1751" no="1752-1772" no="1773-1793" no="1794-1814" no="1815-1835" no="1836-1856" no="1857-1877" no="1878-1898" no="1899-1919" no="1920-1940" no="1941-1961" no="1962-1982" no="1983-2003" no="2004-2024">
the Nature of the Power and Dignity of the Emperor of Germany. THE dividing the Estate among the Males is still practised in some Families; in others, the younger Sons have small Manors, by way of Appendages, which, however, do not much hurt the Principal : In others, they have nothing else to live on but the Sword.
</text>

<text id="217tp10111010532">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1697-1709" no="1710-1722" no="1723-1735" no="1736-1748" no="1749-1761" no="1762-1774" no="1775-1787" no="1788-1800" no="1801-1813" no="1814-1826" no="1827-1839" no="1840-1852" no="1853-1865" no="1866-1878" no="1879-1891" no="1892-1904" no="1905-1917" no="1918-1930" no="1931-1943" no="1944-1956" no="1957-1969" no="1970-1982" no="1983-1995" no="1996-2008" no="2009-2021">
<textC no="1706-1726" no="1727-1747" no="1748-1768" no="1769-1789" no="1790-1810" no="1811-1831" no="1832-1852" no="1853-1873" no="1874-1894" no="1895-1915" no="1916-1936" no="1937-1957" no="1958-1978" no="1979-1999" no="2000-2020">
The late Lord Bolingbroke is in hopes of a full Pardon, and Liberty to return to his Native Country a He lives at a high rate, wanting no Money ; but is said to be indebted to several Merchants above 300003 Livres.
</text>

<text id="304cc1173211150">
<textF no="1699-1705" no="1706-1712" no="1713-1719" no="1720-1726" no="1727-1733" no="1734-1740" no="1741-1747" no="1748-1754" no="1755-1761" no="1762-1768" no="1769-1775" no="1776-1782" no="1783-1789" no="1790-1796" no="1797-1803" no="1804-1810" no="1811-1817" no="1818-1824" no="1825-1831" no="1832-1838" no="1839-1845" no="1846-1852" no="1853-1859" no="1860-1866" no="1867-1873" no="1874-1880" no="1881-1887" no="1888-1894" no="1895-1901" no="1902-1908" no="1909-1915" no="1916-1922" no="1923-1929" no="1930-1936" no="1937-1943" no="1944-1950" no="1951-1957" no="1958-1964" no="1965-1971" no="1972-1978" no="1979-1985" no="1986-1992" no="1993-1999" no="2000-2006" no="2007-2013">
<textM no="1707-1719" no="1720-1732" no="1733-1745" no="1746-1758" no="1759-1771" no="1772-1784" no="1785-1797" no="1798-1810" no="1811-1823" no="1824-1836" no="1837-1849" no="1850-1862" no="1863-1875" no="1876-1888" no="1889-1901" no="1902-1914" no="1915-1927" no="1928-1940" no="1941-1953" no="1954-1966" no="1967-1979" no="1980-1992" no="1993-2005" no="2006-2018">
<textC no="1699-1719" no="1720-1740" no="1741-1761" no="1762-1782" no="1783-1803" no="1804-1824" no="1825-1845" no="1846-1866" no="1867-1887" no="1888-1908" no="1909-1929" no="1930-1950" no="1951-1971" no="1972-1992" no="1993-2013">
The suite of the Em press consists of 200 persons, The Grand Duchess Helena, the widow of the Grand Duke Michael, who is to inhabit the villa Bermond, wTill have with her a suite of eighty persons. It is asserted that the Grand Duke Constantine will shortly ar rive at Nice on a visit to his mother.
</text>

<textF no="1701-1707" no="1708-1714" no="1715-1721" no="1722-1728" no="1729-1735" no="1736-1742" no="1743-1749" no="1750-1756" no="1757-1763" no="1764-1770" no="1771-1777" no="1778-1784" no="1785-1791" no="1792-1798" no="1799-1805" no="1806-1812" no="1813-1819" no="1820-1826" no="1827-1833" no="1834-1840" no="1841-1847" no="1848-1854" no="1855-1861" no="1862-1868" no="1869-1875" no="1876-1882" no="1883-1889" no="1890-1896" no="1897-1903" no="1904-1910" no="1911-1917" no="1918-1924" no="1925-1931" no="1932-1938" no="1939-1945" no="1946-1952" no="1953-1959" no="1960-1966" no="1967-1973" no="1974-1980" no="1981-1987" no="1988-1994" no="1995-2001" no="2002-2008" no="2009-2015">

In all those Articles by which the Gross Amount is made to exceed the Gross Produce, the Accounts of the Office are carried on by way of Debt or and Creditor ;there can be nothing to tempt the Avarice , or to encourage the Frauds of Knavish Dealers.

<textC no="1698-1718" no="1719-1739" no="1740-1760" no="1761-1781" no="1782-1802" no="1803-1823" no="1824-1844" no="1845-1865" no="1866-1886" no="1887-1907" no="1908-1928" no="1929-1949" no="1950-1970" no="1971-1991" no="1992-2012" no="2013-2033">
LAUSANNE, SWITZERLAND (VILLA MEDICIS).—Mr3. STEPHENSON, assisted by resident French and German Governesses, receives in her comfortable home a limited number of GIRLS, to whom she offers all the advantages of a thoroughly good English and Continental Education. Highest references. Pees for Scholastic year, including Christmas and Easter holidays, 70 Guineas. Liberal arrangements made for Children from India and the Colonies. Prospectuses to be obtained at the Office of this Paper, where photograph of house may be seen.
</text>

The value of grain, &c. imported into Glasgow this year amounted to 65,300l. The grain was sold to the inhabitants belowprime cost, and the loss amounted to about fifteen per cent, which the subscribers are to pay.—The same beneficent plan is to be adopted next year,

<textC no="1708-1728" no="1729-1749" no="1750-1770" no="1771-1791" no="1792-1812" no="1813-1833" no="1834-1854" no="1855-1875" no="1876-1896" no="1897-1917" no="1918-1938" no="1939-1959" no="1960-1980" no="1981-2001" no="2002-2022">
